choices.text: Between point A and point B
Between point B and point C
Between point C and point D

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70 beats/min, arterial pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, and body temperature is normal. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is shown below. When does the second heart sound occur in the ventricular pressure–volume relationship?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At point D

 

  • The second heart sound (S2) is caused by the closure of the aortic (and pulmonary) valves at the end of systole when ventricular ejection ends. Let's review the cardiac cycle phases in the pressure-volume loop:
    • Point B to C: Isovolumetric contraction → Ventricular pressure rises but volume remains constant.
    • Point C to D: Ejection phase → Aortic valve is open, blood leaves the ventricle, volume decreases.
    • Point D: End of systole → Aortic valve closes, marking the second heart sound (S2).
    • Point D to A: Isovolumetric relaxation.
    • Point A to B: Diastolic filling → Mitral valve opens, volume increases.
  • Therefore, point D corresponds to aortic valve closure, which produces the second heart sound (S2).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The second heart sound (S2) occurs at point D of the pressure-volume loop, corresponding to closure of the aortic valve at the end of systole. 
  • It marks the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation of the left ventricle.

choices.text: Founder effect in an island population
Introduction of new alleles due to migration
Random mating within a large gene pool
Increased survival of heterozygotes compared to homozygotes

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is least likely to violate Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Random mating within a large gene pool

 

  • Random mating within a large gene pool does not violate equilibrium. This is exactly what Hardy-Weinberg assumes—random mating in a large population ensures that allele frequencies remain stable.
  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium holds true in populations where five key conditions are met:
    1. Large population size (no genetic drift)
    2. Random mating (no assortative mating or inbreeding)
    3. No mutations
    4. No natural selection
    5. No migration/gene flow

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Founder effect in an island population: Violates equilibrium. The founder effect involves a small number of individuals establishing a new population. This results in a reduced gene pool and increases genetic drift, violating the “large population” assumption.

 

Option B. Introduction of new alleles due to migration: Violates equilibrium. Migration leads to gene flow, introducing new alleles into the population, violating the “no gene flow” assumption.

 

Option D. Increased survival of heterozygotes compared to homozygotes: Violates equilibrium. This is an example of natural selection (specifically, heterozygote advantage), which disrupts genotype frequencies across generations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Random mating in a large gene pool is a core assumption of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium and is least likely to violate it, while evolutionary forces such as migration, selection, and genetic drift cause significant deviations.

questions.text: Which enzyme is not involved in shuttling fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for β-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acyl Co-A dehydrogenase

 

 

  • The diagram shows the carnitine shuttle system, which is responsible for transporting long-chain fatty acids from the cytosol into the mitochondrial matrix, where β-oxidation occurs.
  • Acyl Co-A Dehydrogenase
    • Location: Mitochondrial matrix
    • Function: Catalyzes the first step of β-oxidation, dehydrogenating Acyl-CoA to form a trans double bond between the α and β carbons.
  • Involved in shuttle? No – it acts after the fatty acid has already entered the matrix.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carnitine palmitoyl transferase I: 

 

  • Location: Outer mitochondrial membrane
  • Function: Converts Acyl-CoA to Acyl-carnitine by transferring the fatty acid to carnitine.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

Option C. Carnitine palmitoyl transferase II:

 

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane (matrix side)
  • Function: Converts Acyl-carnitine back to Acyl-CoA and carnitine, allowing the fatty acid to enter β-oxidation.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

Option D. Carnitine acylcarnitine translocase:

 

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane
  • Function: Transports Acyl-carnitine into the mitochondrial matrix while moving free carnitine back to the cytosol in a counter-transport manner.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The carnitine shuttle system, is essential for the mitochondrial import of long-chain fatty acids.
  • Key enzymes involved include CPT I, CPT II, and the translocase. 
  • Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is not involved in transport—it functions after the fatty acid enters the matrix, initiating β-oxidation.

choices.text: TPP is a coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
TPP interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.text: A malnourished patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, muscle weakness, and neurological impairment. Laboratory investigations suggest decreased energy production due to a vitamin deficiency. The deficiency affects thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), which plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. Which of the following best explains how TPP deficiency leads to reduced ATP production?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TPP is a coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

  • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is converted in the body to its active form, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). TPP functions as a coenzyme for several key enzymes involved in aerobic energy metabolism, particularly:
    • Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
    • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: A critical enzyme in the citric acid cycle, converting α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA.
    • Branched chain alpha ketoacid dehydrogenase.
  • Without sufficient TPP, both pathways are impaired, leading to:
    • Decreased acetyl-CoA production
    • Reduced TCA cycle activity
    • Decreased ATP synthesis, especially in tissues with high energy demands like the brain and heart
  • This explains the energy deficit and neurological manifestations seen in thiamine deficiency disorders such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TPP interferes with transketolase activity: Incorrect. While TPP does act as a coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway, this is not the primary reason for reduced ATP/energy production. The main effect is due to impaired function of dehydrogenase enzymes in central energy pathways.

 

Option C. TPP interferes with energy production from amino acids: Incorrect. TPP is not primarily involved in amino acid catabolism. Its main roles are in carbohydrate metabolism and TCA cycle enzymes.

 

Option D. TPP interferes with alcohol metabolism: Incorrect. TPP does not directly affect alcohol metabolism. However, alcoholism can cause thiamine deficiency, but this is a risk factor, not a mechanism of energy loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine deficiency leads to impaired energy production because TPP serves as a coenzyme for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, enzymes essential for aerobic glucose metabolism and ATP synthesis.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is false, but R is true
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Reverse triage is often applied in military or disaster settings to prioritize the most severely wounded for treatment.

 

Reason (R): This strategy ensures that scarce medical resources are reserved for those with the highest survival chances.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is false, but R is true

 

  • Assertion (A) is false because reverse triage does not prioritize the most severely injured. In fact, it deprioritizes or delays care for severely injured individuals when resources are limited and focuses instead on treating the less severely injured who can recover quickly or return to essential roles (e.g., combat, healthcare).
  • Reason (R) is true. The purpose of reverse triage is to maximize the use of scarce medical resources by treating individuals who have a high probability of survival with limited intervention. It aims to increase the total number of lives saved or preserve operational capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reverse triage is a strategic method used in mass casualty, war, or resource-scarce settings where those most likely to benefit from limited resources are prioritized, often deferring care for the critically injured.

choices.text: Only A, C, D and E are true
Only A, B and C are true
Only B, C and D are true
All statements (A to E) are true

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the nasopharynx are true? 

 

  1. Thornwaldt cyst arises from the same area as the nasopharyngeal bursa, which is a remnant of the notochord.
  2. The fossa of Rosenmuller is located anterior to the torus tubarius and is the most common site of origin of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).
  3. The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the pterygoid part of sphenoid bone and the perpendicular plate of palatine bone.
  4. The pterygopalatine fossa connects laterally with the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure and medially with the nasopharynx via the sphenopalatine foramen.
  5. Passavant’s ridge helps in preventing nasal regurgitation during swallowing by separating nasopharynx from oropharynx.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only A, C, D and E are true

 

Statement A. Thornwaldt cyst arises from the same area as the nasopharyngeal bursa, which is a remnant of the notochord: This is true, as the Thornwaldt cyst originates from the nasopharyngeal bursa, which is a remnant of the notochord. 

 

Statement C. The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the pterygoid part of sphenoid bone and the perpendicular plate of palatine bone: This is correct. The sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the pterygoid part of the sphenoid bone and the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone. 

 

Statement D. The pterygopalatine fossa connects laterally with the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure and medially with the nasopharynx via the sphenopalatine foramen: This is also true. The pterygopalatine fossa connects medially to the nasopharynx through the sphenopalatine foramen and laterally to the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure, making it a crucial communication pathway. 

 

Statement E. Passavant’s ridge helps in preventing nasal regurgitation during swallowing by separating nasopharynx from oropharynx: This is correct. The Passavant’s ridge plays a key role in swallowing by separating the nasopharynx from the oropharynx and preventing nasal regurgitation of food.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement B. The fossa of Rosenmuller is located anterior to the torus tubarius and is the most common site of origin of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA): This is false because the fossa of Rosenmuller lies posterior to the torus tubarius and is actually the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). JNA typically arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thornwaldt cyst originates from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a remnant of the notochord.
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller is posterior to torus tubarius and is the common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not JNA. JNA arises from the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by pterygoid part of sphenoid and perpendicular plate of palatine bone.
  • Pterygopalatine fossa connects medially to nasopharynx (via sphenopalatine foramen) and laterally to infratemporal fossa (via pterygomaxillary fissure).
  • Passavant’s ridge blocks nasopharynx during swallowing, preventing nasal regurgitation.

questions.text:
Match each child placement institution (Column A) with the age group or eligibility criteria it most appropriately serves (Column B): 

 

Column A – Institutions

 

  1. Borstal
  2. Remand Home
  3. Foster Home
  4. Orphanage
  5. Adoption

 

Column B – Age Group / Eligibility

 

  1. Newborns to older children in need of permanent family
  2. Children temporarily removed from guardians due to crisis or neglect
  3. Boys over 16 years with serious behavioral issues
  4. Children temporarily held under court supervision, often awaiting trial
  5. Abandoned or orphaned children requiring group housing
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-5, E-1

 

A. Borstal → 3. Boys over 16 years with serious behavioral issues: Borstals are juvenile reform institutions for males aged 16 and above who cannot be managed in certified schools. They aim to rehabilitate through structured training and discipline, often for 3 years.

 

B. Remand Home → 4. Children temporarily held under court supervision, often awaiting trial: Remand homes are meant for temporary custody during judicial processes. Children are observed and supported while under investigation, not yet sentenced.

 

C. Foster Home → 2. Children temporarily removed from guardians due to crisis or neglect: Foster care places children in temporary family-like settings, especially during abuse, neglect, or legal disputes, without transferring legal parental rights.

 

D. Orphanage → 5. Abandoned or orphaned children requiring group housing: Orphanages are long-term institutional setups for children without family support, providing shelter, basic education, and care, often in a non-family environment.

 

E. Adoption → 1. Newborns to older children in need of permanent family: Legal adoption is a permanent arrangement for children (from infancy to adolescence) needing full familial and legal integration, including inheritance rights.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Child Placement & Juvenile Institutions:

choices.text: To promote child rights in schools and education systems
To serve as a multisectoral roadmap for preventing all forms of child abuse
To regulate international adoption and child relocation policies
To promote inclusive schooling under the Right to Education Act

questions.text: A public health policymaker is reviewing a global strategy “INSPIRE” as supported by organizations like WHO, UNICEF, and the World Bank. Which of the following best describes the overarching purpose of the INSPIRE framework?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To serve as a multisectoral roadmap for preventing all forms of child abuse

 

  • The INSPIRE framework is a globally endorsed package of seven strategies for ending violence against children. Developed by leading international organizations, it provides a comprehensive, multisectoral roadmap to address all forms of abuse, including physical, sexual, and emotional violence.
  • The acronym INSPIRE stands for:
    • I – Implementation and enforcement of laws
    • N – Norms and values
    • S – Safe environment
    • P – Parent and caregiver support
    • I – Income and economic strengthening
    • R – Response and support services
    • E – Education and life skills
  • These strategies span legal, social, educational, and economic domains, ensuring a holistic, prevention-focused approach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To promote child rights in schools and education systems: This is a subset of one of the seven strategies (education and life skills) but not the overall purpose of the framework.

 

Option C. To regulate international adoption and child relocation policies: This is unrelated. INSPIRE does not focus on adoption or international legal protocols—it focuses on violence prevention.

 

Option D. To promote inclusive schooling under the Right to Education Act: This is an Indian legislative goal, not the scope of INSPIRE, which is a global multisectoral prevention tool, not specific to schooling access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSPIRE framework is a WHO-led global strategy designed as a multisectoral, evidence-based approach to prevent and respond to violence against children, addressing law, norms, environments, families, economics, services, and education.

questions.text: A community health survey identifies a high prevalence of iron-deficiency anemia among women of reproductive age. Incorporating which millet into their diet could help alleviate this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pearl Millet

 

  • Pearl millet (Pennisetum glaucum), commonly known as bajra, is notably rich in iron, making it an effective dietary component for combating iron-deficiency anemia, especially among women of reproductive age.
    • Iron Content: Biofortified varieties of pearl millet contain approximately 16.9 mg of iron per 100g, which is about double the iron content found in other major cereal staples.
    • Bioavailability: Studies have shown that the iron in pearl millet is highly bioavailable, with absorption rates sufficient to meet a significant portion of daily iron requirements.
    • Health Impact: Regular consumption of iron-rich pearl millet has been demonstrated to improve iron status and cognitive performance, and to reverse iron deficiency among schoolchildren and women. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foxtail Millet: While nutritious, foxtail millet has a lower iron content compared to pearl millet and is less effective in addressing iron-deficiency anemia. It provides 2.8 mg of iron per 100 g.

 

Option B. Finger Millet (Ragi): Finger millet is exceptionally high in calcium but does not match pearl millet in iron content. It provides 3.9 mg of iron per 100 g.

 

Option D. Little Millet: This millet has moderate nutritional value but is not particularly high in iron. It provides 9.3 mg of iron per 100 g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pearl millet stands out among millets for its high iron content and bioavailability, making it an effective dietary intervention for combating iron-deficiency anemia, particularly in women of reproductive age.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis for the past 3 days. Imaging reveals an ill-defined inflammatory mass in the right lower abdomen, consistent with appendicular phlegmon. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and observation

 

  • Conservative management of Oschner Sherrin with antibiotics and observation is the standard initial approach for appendicular phlegmon. 
  • This allows the acute inflammation to subside, reducing the risk of complications such as bowel injury or difficult dissection during immediate surgery. 
  • Elective appendectomy is performed after the inflammation resolves to prevent recurrent episodes, usually after 4-6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate laparoscopic appendectomy: Even though minimally invasive, laparoscopic surgery during acute inflammation is risky due to poor tissue planes, high complication rates, and potential bowel injury. Immediate surgery is not recommended for phlegmon.

 

Option B. Immediate open appendectomy: Open surgery in the acute phase carries similar risks as laparoscopic surgery, including complications and difficulties in distinguishing inflamed from normal tissues. It is not the first-line approach for phlegmon.

 

Option C. Elective appendectomy after 6 months: Elective surgery is an important part of the management plan but is not the initial strategy. It is performed after successful conservative treatment to prevent recurrence usually after 4-6 weeks, making it a secondary step in management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Appendicular phlegmon refers to a localized inflammatory mass resulting from acute appendicitis. It forms when the inflamed appendix is surrounded by adjacent organs, omentum, and bowel loops, effectively "walling off" the infection to prevent widespread peritonitis. 
  • The initial approach involves conservative treatment with antibiotics and observation. This helps reduce inflammation and allows the phlegmon to resolve. After recovery, elective appendectomy is recommended to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following infections listed by WHO as likely to cause future major epidemics shares the most epidemiological characteristics with Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rift Valley fever

 

  • Zika virus and Rift Valley Fever (RVF) both share important epidemiological features:
    • Vector-borne transmission:
      • Zika: Spread by Aedes aegypti and A. albopictus.
      • RVF: Spread by Aedes and Culex mosquitoes.
    • Zoonotic potential:
      • Both viruses can infect animals and humans.
    • Vertical transmission and teratogenic potential:
      • Zika: Vertical transmission can lead to microcephaly and other congenital anomalies.
      • RVF: Can cause miscarriage in livestock and humans.
    • Outbreak-prone behavior with climate-related triggers:
      • Both infections are influenced by seasonal patterns like rainfall (which increases mosquito breeding).
  • These shared characteristics make Rift Valley fever the closest epidemiological match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lassa fever: Transmitted via rodent excreta or direct contact with infected humans, not vector borne. It causes hemorrhagic fever and does not involve vertical mosquito-based transmission.

 

Option B. Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF): Transmitted via ticks or contact with infected blood/tissue; causes severe hemorrhagic fever. No perinatal effects like Zika.

 

Option C. Nipah virus: Transmitted via fruit bats and direct contact; causes encephalitis and respiratory symptoms, not mosquito-borne, and doesn’t show the same congenital effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among WHO-listed high-risk emerging infections, Rift Valley fever shares the closest epidemiologic resemblance to Zika virus, particularly due to mosquito-borne transmission, zoonotic nature, and potential to cause vertical transmission and fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging neck mass and symptoms of fatigue and cold intolerance. On physical examination, her thyroid is firm, immobile, and described as "hard as wood." The gland is nontender, and there is evidence of mild tracheal deviation. Laboratory testing shows elevated TSH and low free T4. Imaging reveals fibrosis extending into surrounding neck structures. A biopsy demonstrates dense fibrosis and chronic inflammation without atypical cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis

 

  • Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis is a rare form of chronic thyroiditis characterized by extensive fibrosis of the thyroid gland. 
  • It presents in middle-aged adults (typically in their 40s) with a "hard as wood" thyroid that is painless and fixed. 
  • The fibrosis can extend to local structures, leading to airway or esophageal compression. 
  • Importantly, malignant cells are absent on biopsy, which distinguishes it from anaplastic carcinoma, a highly aggressive thyroid cancer. 
  • The disease often leads to hypothyroidism, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary thyroid carcinoma: Incorrect. This is the most common thyroid cancer and typically presents as a painless thyroid nodule, not as a diffusely hard gland with fibrosis. It shows characteristic nuclear features and often has psammoma bodies on histology.

 

Option B. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: Incorrect. While this malignancy can present with a rapidly enlarging, hard thyroid mass that invades local structures, it is typically seen in older patients (>60 years) and would show highly atypical malignant cells on biopsy. The fibrosis extends to the extra-thyroidal structures.

 

Option D. Hashimoto thyroiditis: Incorrect. Hashimoto’s also leads to hypothyroidism, but the gland is typically painless, diffusely enlarged, and not rock-hard. Histology shows lymphoid aggregates with germinal centers, not extensive fibrosis into local tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis presents as a "hard as wood" nontender thyroid with fibrosis that may invade surrounding structures; it mimics anaplastic carcinoma but occurs in younger patients and lacks malignant cells.

choices.text: The body is small and wider from side to side than anteroposteriorly
The vertebral foramen is large and triangular
The transverse processes contain transverse foramina
The articular processes contain superior facets directed inferoanteriorly

questions.text: Which of the following is not a distinctive characteristic of a typical cervical vertebra?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The articular processes contain superior facets directed inferoanteriorly

 

Typical cervical vertebrae (C3–C6) have the following features:

 

 

  • The superior articular facets of cervical vertebrae are actually directed superoposteriorly, not inferoanteriorly. 
  • This orientation helps facilitate neck flexion, extension, and lateral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The body is small and wider from side to side than anteroposteriorly: Correct. Cervical vertebral bodies are small and wider transversely than anteroposteriorly, which helps support head movement.

 

Option B. The vertebral foramen is large and triangular: Correct. The vertebral foramen is large and triangular, accommodating the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. The transverse processes contain transverse foramina: Correct. Cervical transverse processes have foramina transversaria, which transmit the vertebral arteries and veins (except sometimes in C7).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Typical cervical vertebrae (C3–C6) are characterized by small bodies, bifid spinous processes, foramina transversaria, and large triangular vertebral foramina. 
  • Their superior articular facets are directed superoposteriorly, which is critical for their functional biomechanics. 
  • Misidentifying the facet orientation can lead to confusion with thoracic or lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with developmental delay is brought in due to behavioral disturbances. On examination, he has multiple scars on lips and hands, consistent with self-mutilation. There is a positive family history of a similar condition in a male relative. Which of the following laboratory tests would be most valuable in guiding diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uric acid

 

  • The child presents with classical features suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), an enzyme involved in the purine salvage pathway.
  • Key features include:
    • Self-mutilation (biting of lips and fingers)
    • Neurological abnormalities (dystonia, developmental delay)
    • Family history (X-linked inheritance)
    • Hyperuricemia due to accumulation of uric acid
    • Urate crystals in diaper or urate deposits in skin and joints
  • Because of HGPRT deficiency, hypoxanthine and guanine are not salvaged, leading to increased purine degradation, which produces excess uric acid. Thus, measuring uric acid levels is the most valuable diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum amylase: Serum amylase is elevated in pancreatic inflammation and is unrelated to neurologic or self-injurious symptoms. It offers no diagnostic value in the context of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Option B. Alkaline phosphatase: This enzyme is elevated in bone or hepatobiliary disorders, but it is not elevated in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and provides no diagnostic insight for this condition.

 

Option C. Creatine kinase: While CK is used in the evaluation of muscular dystrophies and muscle injury, it is not useful in diagnosing purine metabolism disorders like Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked disorder of purine metabolism due to HGPRT deficiency, and is characterized by self-mutilation, neurological symptoms, and hyperuricemia. Measurement of uric acid is the most important diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for her routine annual examination. She is asymptomatic and has no significant medical history. She is not on any hormonal medications and has regular menstrual cycles. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform a cervical biopsy

 

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a growth is seen (cervical polyp), so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform a pap smear: A pap smear is done when there is no visible lesion on the cervix

 

Option C and D. Refer to a gynecologic oncologist and obtain a computed tomography (CT) scan: Imaging studies and referral to a gynecologist have a role in cervical cancer once a diagnosis is made.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a lesion is seen on the cervix, a biopsy should always be taken using a punch biopsy forceps
  • In this image, a lesion is seen, so a biopsy should be taken from the periphery of the lesion

questions.text: In a region with a total population of 10,000 individuals, serological surveys show that 7,500 individuals have antibodies to a particular infection. If the infection is in an endemic steady state, what is the basic reproduction number (R₀) for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4.0

 

  • This is based on Hill’s criterion of temporality and endemic equilibrium, which follows the formula:
    • R0 × S = 1 
    • Where:
      • R₀ = Basic Reproduction Number
      • S = Proportion of the population that is susceptible to infection
  • Calculation:
    • Total population = 10,000
    • Individuals with antibodies (immune) = 7,500
    • Therefore, Susceptibles (S) = 10,000 – 7,500 = 2,500
    • Proportion susceptible = 2,500 / 10,000 = 0.25
  • At endemic steady state:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To test the application of the endemic steady state formula R₀ × S = 1, reinforcing how immunity levels in the population (e.g., post-infection or vaccination) influence transmission dynamics of infections.
  • In endemic conditions, the product of R₀ and proportion susceptible (S) must equal 1. Knowing the immunity status of the population allows you to back-calculate R₀, which is vital for forecasting and control of infectious diseases.

questions.text: A previously healthy 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever, headache, nausea, and neck stiffness. He rapidly develops altered mental status. Lumbar puncture is performed, and wet mount examination of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals motile, unicellular organisms. What is the most likely causative organism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naegleria fowleri

 

  • The scenario describes acute meningoencephalitis in a previously healthy individual, with motile unicellular organisms on wet mount CSF microscopy. This is characteristic of Naegleria fowleri, a free-living amoeba, which causes Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM)
  • Infection occurs after nasal exposure to contaminated freshwater, especially during swimming. The amoebae invade through the cribriform plate to reach the brain
  • CSF analysis may show motile trophozoites on wet mount, a diagnostic clue
  • PAM progresses rapidly and is usually fatal, making early detection crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes intestinal amoebiasis and occasionally liver abscess but does not cause primary meningoencephalitis. It is non-motile in CSF and not found in CSF wet mounts.

 

Option C. Trypanosoma cruzi: Causes Chagas disease, which may lead to chronic cardiomyopathy and mega syndromes, and rarely CNS disease. It does not present acutely in CSF with motile trophozoites.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii: Causes congenital defects in a child born to mother infected during first trimester of pregnancy, Unlike Naegleria, it does not show motile organisms in CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naegleria fowleri causes rapidly progressive primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), diagnosed by identifying motile trophozoites in CSF wet mount in an acutely ill patient.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the muscle whose paralysis leads to this sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior gluteal nerve

 

  • The Trendelenburg sign is positive when the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius on the standing side.
  • The gluteus medius (along with gluteus minimus) is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.
  • This nerve arises from the dorsal divisions of L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves.
  • It plays a critical role in hip abduction and pelvic stabilization during gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior gluteal nerve: Supplies gluteus maximus, involved in hip extension, not abduction or pelvic stability.

 

Option B. Obturator nerve: Supplies medial thigh adductors, not gluteal muscles.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: Supplies anterior thigh muscles (e.g., quadriceps), involved in hip flexion and knee extension, not hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign is caused by weakness/paralysis of gluteus medius, supplied by the superior gluteal nerve, which is responsible for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization during single-leg stance.

choices.text: Administer 2 doses of Td—one now and one 1 month later
Administer a single Td dose only
Defer Td until after delivery and administer 2 doses 1 month apart
Administer one Td dose and 750 IU antitoxin post-delivery for neonatal protection

questions.text: A primigravida woman reports to the health subcenter at 9 months of pregnancy (POG) with no prior antenatal visits or Td immunization. The ANM suggests giving one Td dose due to anticipated early labor. The medical officer (MO) intervenes. Which is the most appropriate public health action, assuming delivery is likely within 3 days?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administer 2 doses of Td—one now and one 1 month later

 

  • According to National Immunization Schedule (NIS) and MoHFW guidelines:
    • Pregnant women who report late in pregnancy (including 9th month or just before delivery) and are unimmunized, must be given two Td doses.
    • The first Td dose is given immediately, and the second is scheduled 1 month later, even if it is after delivery.
    • This ensures partial protection for the current pregnancy and full protection for the next 3 years.
    • The aim is not just maternal protection but also building immunity for future pregnancies.
  • Giving only one dose limits effectiveness and misses the opportunity to build sustained immunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer a single Td dose only: Incorrect. One dose may offer some protection, but two doses are mandatory for effective immunization and long-term protection.

 

Option C. Defer Td until after delivery and administer 2 doses 1 month apart: Incorrect. While two postnatal doses are valid if not given earlier, the first dose should not be delayed. Immediate initiation is crucial.

 

Option D. Administer one Td dose and 750 IU antitoxin post-delivery: Incorrect. Td vaccine is the preferred preventive measure. The antitoxin (heterologous serum) is used only for neonates born to unimmunized mothers within 6 hours of birth for passive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unimmunized pregnant women reporting late (even at 9 months or just before delivery) must receive 2 Td doses—first immediately and second 1 month later—to ensure both maternal and future pregnancy protection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete undergoes intense physical exercise without proper hydration. During this period, significant sweating occurs. A graphical representation of his body fluid compartments and osmolarity is obtained. Which of the following best describes the type of body fluid disturbance in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoosmotic fluid loss

 

  • Sweating results in the loss of hypoosmotic fluid relative to plasma because sweat contains less sodium and more water. When excessive sweating occurs:
    • Water is lost in greater proportion than solute (Na⁺).
    • As a result, plasma osmolarity increases.
  • This causes water to shift from the intracellular to the extracellular compartment, leading to:
    • A decrease in intracellular fluid volume
    • A decrease in extracellular fluid volume
    • An increase in osmolarity of both compartments
  • This pattern is classically referred to as hyperosmotic volume contraction, a subset of hyperosmotic fluid loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isosmotic fluid loss: Seen in hemorrhage or diarrhea where fluid lost has osmolarity equal to plasma—no change in osmolarity occurs.

 

Option C. Hyperosmotic fluid loss: Incorrect terminology. Hyperosmotic fluids are not lost in sweating; rather, body fluid becomes hyperosmotic.

 

Option D. Hypoosmotic fluid gain: Seen in water intoxication or SIADH where free water is retained, leading to decreased osmolarity and increased volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sweating leads to a hyperosmotic volume contraction due to loss of hypoosmotic sweat. 
  • This results in decreased ECF and ICF volumes with increased osmolarity. 
  • Such disturbances must be corrected by water intake with electrolyte replacement to restore fluid balance.

choices.text: Isolation of virus in Aedes albopictus C6/36 cell culture
Detection of viral RNA via RT-PCR

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents on the third day of high-grade fever, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Dengue fever is suspected based on clinical grounds. Which of the following diagnostic methods is least appropriate for confirmation of dengue infection at this stage of illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgM antibody detection by ELISA

 

  • At day 3 of illness in suspected dengue cases, direct detection methods are preferred because viral replication is at its peak during the first 5 days of illness. 
  • Therefore, NS1 antigen detection, RT-PCR, and viral culture in Aedes albopictus C6/36 cell line are useful during this early viremic phase.
  • IgM antibodies, detected by ELISA, are part of the host’s adaptive immune response and typically appear after day 5 of infection. 
  • Hence, antibody detection is not reliable on day 3 and may yield false-negative results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Detection of viral antigen NS1: True. Appropriate on day 3. NS1 is a non-structural protein secreted by infected cells and can be detected early (days 1–5). Its presence correlates with active viral replication.

 

Option B. Isolation of virus in Aedes albopictus C6/36 cell culture: True. Though labor-intensive, viral culture using mosquito cell lines like C6/36 is feasible in early dengue infection, especially during the viremic phase (first 5 days). Not routinely done due to technical challenges but still valid.

 

Option C. Detection of viral RNA via RT-PCR: True. Highly sensitive and specific during the acute phase (days 1–5). It detects dengue viral RNA in serum and is ideal in the early stages of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the early phase of dengue infection (days 1–5), direct detection methods such as NS1 antigen, RT-PCR, and viral culture are appropriate; IgM ELISA is not useful this early, as antibodies typically appear after day 5.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding. On speculum examination, a friable, cauliflower-like lesion is observed on the cervix. The lesion bleeds on touch. A biopsy is planned for histopathological confirmation. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for obtaining a biopsy sample in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Punch biopsy forceps

 

  • The lesion described is highly suggestive of cervical carcinoma. 
  • In such cases, direct visualization followed by biopsy is the most appropriate step. 
  • The instrument used to obtain a tissue biopsy from a visible lesion on the cervix is the Punch biopsy forceps, which allows for precise removal of a small tissue sample for histopathological analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ayre's spatula: Incorrect. It is used for Pap smear collection, which involves surface cell scraping for cytology, not for biopsy of lesions.

 

Option C. Cervical brush (Cytobrush): Incorrect. Also used in Pap smears, especially for endocervical sampling; it does not collect adequate tissue for histopathological diagnosis.

 

Option D. Endocervical curette: Incorrect. Used to sample endocervical canal tissue, not exophytic lesions on the ectocervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with visible cervical lesions and abnormal bleeding, punch biopsy using biopsy forceps is the investigation of choice. 
  • Cytological tools like spatulas and brushes are used in screening but are inadequate for diagnosing invasive disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the biochemical properties of Shigella species are incorrect? 

 

  1. All Shigella species are non-motile.
  2. Shigella sonnei is a non-lactose fermenter that may later ferment lactose on prolonged incubation.
  3. Shigella dysenteriae type 1 is catalase-positive, like all other Shigella species.
  4. Shigella dysenteriae does not ferment mannitol, unlike other Shigella species.
  5. Shigella flexneri is mannitol non-fermenting and catalase negative.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 3 and 5

 

Incorrect Statements: 

 

Statement 3. Shigella dysenteriae type 1 is catalase-positive, like all other Shigella species: Incorrect. Shigella dysenteriae type 1 is catalase-negative, unlike other Shigella species, which are catalase-positive.

 

Statement 5. Shigella flexneri is mannitol non-fermenting and catalase negative: Incorrect. Shigella flexneri is mannitol-fermenting and catalase-positive, so this statement is false.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. All Shigella species are non-motile: Correct. All Shigella spp. are non-motile, which helps distinguish them from other Enterobacteriaceae.

 

Statement 2. Shigella sonnei is a non-lactose fermenter that may later ferment lactose on prolonged incubation: Correct. Shigella sonnei is a late lactose fermenter (LLF). While initially non-lactose fermenting, it can appear to ferment lactose after prolonged incubation.

 

Statement 4. Shigella dysenteriae does not ferment mannitol, unlike other Shigella species: Correct. Shigella dysenteriae is mannitol non-fermenting, while other Shigella species ferment mannitol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shigella spp. are non-motile; S. sonnei is a late lactose fermenter, while S. dysenteriae is distinctively catalase-negative and mannitol non-fermenting.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of confusion. Over the past week, she had increasing dysuria and left-sided flank pain. On examination, her blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is elevated with shallow breathing. Her extremities are warm to touch, and she appears acutely ill. Which of the following mediators is most likely responsible for this patient’s hypotension and systemic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TNF-α

 

  • This patient shows signs of septic shock, characterized by hypotension, fever, tachycardia, warm extremities (suggesting distributive shock), and confusion, in the setting of suspected urinary tract infection. 
  • These findings are most consistent with sepsis progressing to septic shock, commonly due to gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli.
  • Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a proinflammatory cytokine produced primarily by activated macrophages in response to endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide, LPS) from gram-negative bacteria. TNF-α plays a central role in the pathogenesis of septic shock by:
    • Increasing vascular permeability
    • Inducing nitric oxide production (causing vasodilation and hypotension)
    • Promoting fever via hypothalamic stimulation
    • Activating coagulation pathways (can lead to DIC)
  • All the systemic findings in this patient (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, warm extremities, altered mental status) are classic effects of elevated TNF-α in sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-10: This is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that downregulates the immune response. It is produced by macrophages and T-cells to limit inflammation and prevent host damage. IL-10 does not cause fever, hypotension, or vasodilation. Hence, it is not responsible for the patient’s current systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. IL-4: IL-4 is a cytokine associated with the promotion of Th2 immune responses, class switching to IgE, and eosinophil recruitment in allergic reactions. It is required for mast cell activation. It plays no role in bacterial sepsis or in producing hypotension, fever, or altered mental status. It is not relevant in the pathogenesis of septic shock.

 

Option D. Leukotriene B4: This lipid mediator is derived from arachidonic acid and is a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils. While it contributes to local inflammation by recruiting leukocytes to the site of infection, it does not cause systemic hypotension or fever, making it an incorrect choice in this systemic presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TNF-α is a key proinflammatory cytokine that mediates the systemic manifestations of septic shock, including hypotension, fever, and altered sensorium.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true under the National Sickle Cell Anaemia Elimination Mission? 

 

  1. The mission aims to eliminate SCD by 2035
  2. Penicillin 125 mg/day is used after age 1 year
  3. Folic acid is started only above 2 years of age
  4. Cards are color-coded by gender, not by disease status
  5. Hydroxyurea is initiated in all patients at diagnosis
  6. The program is under National Health Mission
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 4 and 6 only

 

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2. Penicillin 125 mg/day is used after age 1 year: True. As per guidelines, penicillin prophylaxis starts with 62.5 mg BD for <1 year, then increases to 125 mg/day after age 1 year, and is escalated further to 250 mg/day till 5 years.

 

Statement 4. Cards are color-coded by gender, not by disease status: True. The color of the sickle cell cards indicates gender — blue for males and pink for females — while the text on the card indicates whether the individual is normal, carrier, or diseased.

 

Statement 6. The program is under National Health Mission: True. The National Sickle Cell Anaemia Elimination Mission is a part of the larger National Health Mission (NHM) and operates under its umbrella.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. The mission aims to eliminate SCD by 2035: Incorrect. The actual goal is to eliminate sickle cell disease as a public health problem in India before 2047, not 2035.

 

Statement 3. Folic acid is started only above 2 years of age: Incorrect. Folic acid is started much earlier:

 

  • 2.5 mg daily for children below 1 year
  • 5 mg daily for those above 1 year

 

Statement 5. Hydroxyurea is initiated in all patients at diagnosis: Incorrect. Hydroxyurea is not universally started at diagnosis. It is initiated in:

 

  • Patients with >3 crises per year, or
  • Those with repeated episodes of ACS (acute chest syndrome)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Sickle Cell Anaemia Elimination Mission, under the National Health Mission, uses gender-based color-coded cards (blue for males, pink for females) and provides prophylactic penicillin from infancy. 
  • Hydroxyurea and folic acid therapy are started based on age and severity. The target year for elimination is 2047.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with prior MI presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness. He discontinued statins 3 weeks ago due to symptoms, but weakness has worsened. CK is elevated at 12× ULN. Which test best confirms the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti–HMG-CoA reductase antibody

 

  • Statin-induced immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy is confirmed by anti–HMG-CoA reductase antibodies. 
  • Persistent symptoms despite stopping statins and markedly elevated CK suggest autoimmune etiology requiring immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibody: Nonspecific and not diagnostic for this condition.
 

Option C. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with interstitial lung disease and dermatomyositis.
 

Option D. Anti–signal recognition particle antibody: Found in another subtype of necrotizing myopathy but less associated with statins.

 

Educational Objective:


Anti–HMG-CoA reductase antibodies confirm statin-induced autoimmune necrotizing myopathy, especially when symptoms persist after statin discontinuation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with redness in one eye that has developed gradually over a few days. There is no significant pain, and vision is unaffected. Instillation of 5% phenylephrine eye drops causes marked blanching of the redness. Based on this response, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Episcleritis

 

  • Episcleritis is a benign, self-limiting inflammation of the episcleral tissue (a layer between the conjunctiva and sclera). It commonly presents with:
    • Mild redness
    • Minimal discomfort or irritation
    • No visual impairment
  • The hallmark diagnostic clue is the blanching of redness with topical vasoconstrictors such as 5% phenylephrine. 

 

 

  • This occurs because episcleral vessels are superficial and responsive to vasoconstriction, distinguishing it from deeper conditions like scleritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjunctival hemorrhage: Appears as a bright red patch due to ruptured conjunctival vessels but does not blanch with phenylephrine drops. It is painless and resolves on its own.

 

Subconjunctival hemorrhage

 

Option C. Uveitis: Involves inflammation of the uveal tract, typically associated with photophobia, pain, and vision loss. Redness is ciliary and does not blanch with vasoconstrictors.

 

Option D. Acute angle-closure glaucoma: Presents with severe pain, headache, nausea, and blurred vision. The redness is diffuse and deeper, and it does not blanch with phenylephrine.

 

Additional information:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can be clinically distinguished by blanching of redness with 5% phenylephrine, due to its involvement of superficial episcleral vessels.

choices.text: Power was adequate; null hypothesis is definitively true
The result may represent a Type II error due to low power
Type I error occurred due to incorrect P-value threshold
The study needs to reduce its alpha to improve precision

questions.text: In a study of a new chemotherapy regimen, the investigators set α = 0.05 and β = 0.20. During analysis, they find no statistically significant difference in overall survival. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the negative finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The result may represent a Type II error due to low power

 

  • A Type II error occurs when a real difference exists, but the study fails to detect it, often due to insufficient power.
  • In this case, β = 0.20, which means the power = 1 - β = 0.80, i.e., 80%.
  • Although 80% is conventionally acceptable, if no statistically significant difference was found, and if the true effect exists but went undetected, this raises the possibility of a Type II error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Power was adequate; null hypothesis is definitively true: Incorrect. Even with 80% power, a non-significant result does not definitively prove the null hypothesis; it may still be a false negative.

 

Option C. Type I error occurred due to incorrect P-value threshold: Incorrect. Type I error (false positive) occurs when a difference is found but doesn't truly exist. In this case, no difference was found, so Type I error doesn't apply.

 

Option D. The study needs to reduce its alpha to improve precision: Incorrect. Reducing alpha (e.g., from 0.05 to 0.01) makes it harder to find significance, thus increasing the risk of Type II error, not improving precision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a study yields no statistically significant result, always consider the possibility of a Type II error, especially if the study may be underpowered to detect a meaningful difference.

choices.text: Children with Down syndrome are at higher risk of developing this condition
Azacitidine can improve cytopenias and prolong survival
Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is contraindicated
Higher blast percentages in bone marrow are associated with worse prognosis

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss, and exertional dyspnea. Labs show pancytopenia, macrocytic anemia, and 4% blasts on peripheral smear. A peripheral smear image is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding his likely diagnosis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is contraindicated

 

  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a clonal bone marrow disorder with risk of AML transformation. 
  • Allogeneic HSCT is the only curative option. 
  • Azacitidine improves survival in high-risk MDS. 
  • Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of MDS/AML. 
  • Prognosis correlates with blast percentage.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Children with Down syndrome are at higher risk of developing this condition: True. Down syndrome is a known risk factor.
 

Option B. Azacitidine can improve cytopenias and prolong survival: True. Azacitidine is a standard epigenetic therapy.
 

Option D. Higher blast percentages in bone marrow are associated with worse prognosis: True. Higher blasts predict progression to AML.

 

Educational Objective:


Stem cell transplantation remains the only curative therapy for eligible MDS patients; it is not contraindicated.

choices.text: Mineral oils in overhead tanks + Paris green in storm drains
Intermittent irrigation + poecilia fish stocking in sewage lines
Source reduction of artificial containers + removal of aquatic weeds + larvivorous fish in ponds
Abate + Malathion alternating weekly in all surface water sources

questions.text: You are designing an urban vector control strategy for a Smart City project. Budget constraints prevent frequent chemical interventions. Which combination of cost-effective and sustainable anti-larval measures would best address multiple mosquito species without compromising water resource utility?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Source reduction of artificial containers + removal of aquatic weeds + larvivorous fish in ponds

 

  • This is a public health systems thinking question that integrates sustainability, cost-effectiveness, vector biology, and urban ecosystem management.
  • It applies a multi-pronged biological and environmental control approach that is:
    • Sustainable: Does not require frequent chemical input.
    • Eco-friendly: Safe for aquatic ecosystems and potable water sources.
  • Species-specific:
    • Aedes (dengue, chikungunya): Controlled via source reduction of artificial containers.
    • Mansonia (filariasis): Controlled via removal of aquatic vegetation (they lay eggs on aquatic plants).
    • Culex/Anopheles: Controlled via larvivorous fish like Gambusia, Lebistes, or Poecilia in water bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mineral oils in overhead tanks + Paris green in storm drains: Not eco-friendly, mineral oils are toxic to fish and render water unfit for human consumption. Paris green is only effective if consumed by larvae and requires targeted application, which is difficult in storm drains.

 

Option B. Intermittent irrigation + poecilia in sewage lines: Poecilia and other larvivorous fish cannot survive in polluted sewage. Intermittent irrigation is suitable only for agricultural Anopheles breeding sites, not urban settings.

 

Option D. Abate + Malathion alternating weekly in all surface water sources: Highly chemical-intensive, not sustainable under budget constraints, and may harm aquatic ecosystems and generate resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Integrated Vector Management (IVM) relies on selecting the right mix of biological and environmental measures. In urban, resource-limited settings:
    • Use larvivorous fish for natural control.
    • Prioritize source reduction for Aedes.
    • Remove aquatic vegetation for Mansonia.
  • This multi-species approach is more economical, sustainable, and scalable than over-reliance on larvicides.

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Zoledronic acid helps reduce bone breakdown and fracture risk in patients with osteoporosis.

 

Reason (R): Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate that binds to hydroxyapatite and stimulates osteoblast activity to promote bone formation.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false

 

  • Zoledronic acid is a potent bisphosphonate that binds to hydroxyapatite in bone and inhibits osteoclasts, thereby reducing bone resorption and lowering fracture risk—making the assertion true.
  • However, it does not stimulate osteoblasts or directly promote bone formation, making the reason false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoledronic acid reduces fracture risk in osteoporosis by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. It does not promote bone formation or stimulate osteoblasts.

questions.text: Match the Following (Muscles and Functions):
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–1, C–4, D–3

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: An anti-arrhythmic drug with a plasma half-life of 10 seconds used for acute treatment of PSVT
An anti-inflammatory drug with a plasma half-life of 24 hr
A hypnotic drug with a plasma half-life of 2 hours
An anti-hypertensive with a plasma half-life of 3 hours

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be given in sustained release oral dosage form?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) An anti-hypertensive with a plasma half-life of 3 hours

 

  • Sustained release (SR) oral dosage forms are designed to release the drug over an extended period to maintain therapeutic drug concentrations in the blood for a longer duration. 
  • Therefore, the ideal candidates for making a sustained release formulation are: 
    • Drugs with a short plasma half-life
    • The drug used for a condition where prolonged therapy is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. An anti-arrhythmic drug with a plasma half-life of 10 seconds used for acute treatment of PSVT: Would not be suitable for a sustained release oral dosage form since it needs to act quickly in an acute situation. An anti-inflammatory drug with a plasma half-life of 24 hours will not require a SR formulation because the drug already has a long half-life. 

 

Option B. An anti-inflammatory drug with a plasma half-life of 24 hr: An anti-inflammatory drug with a plasma half-life of 24 hours will not require a SR formulation because the drug already has a long half-life. 

 

Option C. A hypnotic drug with a plasma half-life of 2 hours: Would not be suitable for a sustained release oral dosage form since hypontics are required to work for 5-6 hours only and an SR form may result in prolonged sleep. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs with short to intermediate half-lives used for chronic conditions (e.g., antihypertensives) are ideal candidates for sustained release oral dosage forms to improve compliance and maintain steady therapeutic levels.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with a history of a fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

  • To calculate the GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils) score for the patient, we will assess the eye, verbal, and motor responses, and then adjust for pupil reactivity.
    1. Eye response: The patient opens eyes to knuckle pressure (pain), which scores a 2.
    2. Verbal response: The patient is making incomprehensible sounds, which scores a 2.
    3. Motor response: The patient has a completely flexed posture, which is consistent with decorticate posturing, which scores a 3.

 

Adding these together:

 

  • Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response=2+2+3=7
  • Now, for the pupillary response:
    • One pupil is unreactive to light, which subtracts 1 from the GCS score.
    • GCS Score−Pupillary Score=7−1=6
    • The final GCS-P score is 6.

The correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response. It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries. 
  • The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the brachial plexus are correct? 

 

  1. The brachial plexus is formed by the ventral rami of C5 to T1.
  2. The roots of the brachial plexus and the subclavian artery pass through the gap between the anterior and middle scalene muscles.
  3. Gray rami communicantes supply sympathetic fibers to each root of the brachial plexus.
  4. Each of the three trunks divides into anterior and posterior divisions.
  5. The cords of the brachial plexus surround the brachial artery.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, and 4 only

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. The brachial plexus is formed by the ventral rami of C5 to T1: Correct. The brachial plexus is formed by ventral rami of C5–T1, known as the roots.

 

Statement 2. The roots of the brachial plexus and the subclavian artery pass through the gap between the anterior and middle scalene muscles: Correct. These roots and the subclavian artery pass through the interscalene gap (between the anterior and middle scalene muscles).

 

Statement 3. Gray rami communicantes supply sympathetic fibers to each root of the brachial plexus: Correct. Each root receives sympathetic fibers via gray rami communicantes.

 

Statement 4. Each of the three trunks divides into anterior and posterior divisions: Correct. The upper, middle, and lower trunks each divide into anterior and posterior divisions.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 5. The cords of the brachial plexus surround the brachial artery:  Incorrect. The cords of the brachial plexus surround the axillary artery, not the brachial artery. The brachial artery is distal to the lower border of the teres major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachial plexus has a precise and consistent anatomical organization. Understanding its formation, divisions, and spatial relationships—especially with major vessels like the axillary artery—is essential for clinical applications such as nerve blocks, surgical planning, and diagnosing nerve injuries.

questions.text: A 38-year-old immunocompromised man is hospitalized with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis confirmed by imaging and fungal biomarkers. He is started on caspofungin due to intolerance to azole therapy. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the antifungal agent prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of cell wall synthesis

 

  • Caspofungin, an echinocandin antifungal, inhibits β-(1,3)-D-glucan synthase, thereby disrupting the synthesis of β-glucan, a critical structural component of the fungal cell wall. 
  • This weakens the fungal cell wall and leads to cell death, especially in Candida and Aspergillus species. 
  • It is particularly useful for treating azole-resistant infections or when amphotericin B cannot be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disruption of microtubule polymerization: This describes the action of griseofulvin, used for dermatophyte skin infections, not for systemic or invasive fungal infections like aspergillosis.

 

Option B. Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis: Azole antifungals like voriconazole and fluconazole work via this mechanism by inhibiting lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in the ergosterol biosynthesis pathway.

 

Option D. Inhibition of cell membrane synthesis: This is the mechanism of polyenes like amphotericin B, which bind ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, causing increased permeability and cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caspofungin acts by inhibiting fungal cell wall synthesis through β-glucan synthase blockade, a unique mechanism among antifungal classes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding GAPPD targets are correct? 

 

  1. GAPPD aims to reduce pneumonia deaths to fewer than 3 per 1,000 live births by 2025.
  2. The plan sets a target of at least 50% exclusive breastfeeding during the first six months of life.
  3. GAPPD recommends 90% coverage for vaccines against pertussis, measles, Hib, pneumococcus, and rotavirus.
  4. The goal is to reduce diarrhoea deaths to fewer than 2 per 1,000 live births by 2025.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All statements are correct

 

  • The Integrated Global Action Plan for Prevention and Control of Pneumonia and Diarrhoea (GAPPD) by WHO and UNICEF aims to end preventable childhood deaths due to pneumonia and diarrhoea through integrated strategies.

 

Statement 1. GAPPD aims to reduce pneumonia deaths to fewer than 3 per 1,000 live births by 2025: Correct. GAPPD targets reducing pneumonia mortality to <3 per 1000 live births by 2025, particularly in children under 5 years of age.

 

Statement 2. The plan sets a target of at least 50% exclusive breastfeeding during the first six months of life: Correct. Promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months is a cornerstone of the GAPPD strategy. The target is to achieve at least 50% exclusive breastfeeding coverage.

 

Statement 3. GAPPD recommends 90% coverage for vaccines against pertussis, measles, Hib, pneumococcus, and rotavirus: Correct. The GAPPD recommends achieving at least 90% coverage of key childhood vaccines — including pertussis, measles, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), pneumococcus, and rotavirus — as these directly prevent pneumonia and diarrhoea.

 

Statement 4. The goal is to reduce diarrhoea deaths to fewer than 2 per 1,000 live births by 2025: Correct. The diarrhoea mortality reduction goal is to bring it down to <2 deaths per 1000 live births by 2025.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The GAPPD provides a unified framework aiming to reduce childhood deaths due to pneumonia and diarrhoea using a combination of preventive, protective, and treatment strategies. 
  • It sets quantifiable global targets such as <3/1000 live births for pneumonia and <2/1000 for diarrhoea, supported by 90% vaccine coverage and 50% exclusive breastfeeding—all vital benchmarks in child survival programs.

choices.text: It enhances growth of candida and staphylococcus species
It prevents swarming by proteus organisms
It assists in identification of pseudomonas by pigment production
It differentiates between lactose fermenters and non-lactose fermenters

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fever, dysuria, and urinary frequency. A midstream urine sample is sent for culture and sensitivity testing. The microbiology lab chooses Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient (CLED) agar for primary culture instead of MacConkey agar. What is the primary reason for selecting CLED medium in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It prevents swarming by Proteus organisms

 

  • CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) agar is a differential medium designed specifically for the culture of urinary pathogens. It is preferred over MacConkey agar when processing urine cultures, particularly for one crucial reason:
    • It inhibits the swarming motility of Proteus species, which are highly motile uropathogens.
  • Proteus species, especially Proteus mirabilis, tend to overgrow on standard agar plates due to swarming, making it difficult to isolate other organisms.
  • CLED medium contains electrolyte-deficient composition, which prevents this swarming behavior without inhibiting growth.
  • Additionally, CLED also allows:
    • Differentiation of lactose fermenters (yellow colonies) and non-lactose fermenters (blue colonies), although this is not its unique property.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It enhances growth of Candida and Staphylococcus species: While CLED supports the growth of various urinary pathogens, it is not specifically designed to promote Candida or Staphylococcus. Other enriched media are preferred for those organisms.

 

Option C. It assists in identification of Pseudomonas by pigment production: Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces pigments (e.g., pyocyanin) more distinctly on nutrient agar or King’s A/B media, not on CLED.

 

Option D. It differentiates between lactose fermenters and non-lactose fermenters: While CLED can differentiate LF and NLF, this is also true for MacConkey agar. The unique advantage of CLED in urine cultures lies in its inhibition of Proteus swarming, which MacConkey agar does not prevent effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLED agar is preferred in urine cultures because it prevents swarming of Proteus species, which can otherwise obscure growth of other urinary pathogens.

questions.text:
Concerning the pathophysiology and toxic mechanisms of the poisoning caused by the seeds shown in the image below, which of the following statements are incorrect? 

 

 

  1. This causes direct irritant injury to gastrointestinal mucosa.
  2. Toxin inhibits cellular ribosomal protein synthesis.
  3. Death results primarily from cardiotoxicity.
  4. Fluid and electrolyte loss contributes to circulatory collapse.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

The seeds in the image are Croton tiglium (Jamalgota).

 

Statement 2. Toxin inhibits cellular ribosomal protein synthesis: 

 

  • Crotin inhibits cellular ribosomal protein synthesis. Incorrect.
    • Although crotin is a toxalbumin like ricin and abrin, its primary clinical action in Croton tiglium poisoning is mucosal irritation, not systemic ribosomal inhibition leading to widespread cytotoxicity.
    • Ribosomal inhibition is the hallmark of poisons like ricin (castor beans) and abrin (rosary peas), not croton poisoning.

 

Statement 3. Death results primarily from cardiotoxicity: 

 

  • Death results primarily from cardiotoxicity. Incorrect.
    • Death results from hypovolemic shock due to massive gastrointestinal fluid losses, not from direct cardiac toxicity.
    • Cardiotoxic deaths are typically associated with aconitine, oleander, cerbera (suicide tree), and not Croton tiglium.

 

Correct Statements: 

 

Statement 1. This causes direct irritant injury to gastrointestinal mucosa: 

 

  • This causes direct irritant injury to gastrointestinal mucosa. Correct.
    • Crotonoside, a glycoside found in Croton tiglium, acts as a direct mucosal irritant, leading to burning, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and hemorrhagic enteritis.

 

Statement 4. Fluid and electrolyte loss contributes to circulatory collapse: 

 

  • Fluid and electrolyte loss contributes to circulatory collapse. Correct.
    • Hypovolemia from persistent vomiting and bloody diarrhea leads to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, prostration, and circulatory failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croton tiglium poisoning causes death by direct mucosal irritation leading to fluid loss and circulatory collapse, it does not act primarily via ribosomal inhibition or cardiotoxicity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man recently diagnosed with HIV infection and a CD4 count of 180 cells/mm³ begins antiretroviral therapy (ART). Two weeks later, he returns with complaints of intense vivid dreams, nightmares, dizziness, and difficulty concentrating, especially during the night. His symptoms are interfering with sleep and daytime function. Which of the following medications in his ART regimen is most likely responsible for these neuropsychiatric side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Efavirenz

 

  • Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) that is well known for causing neuropsychiatric side effects, particularly during the first few weeks of treatment. Common symptoms include:
    • Vivid dreams or nightmares
    • Dizziness
    • Confusion or poor concentration
    • Insomnia
    • Occasionally hallucinations or mood disturbances
  • These effects are usually worse at night and may improve with time, though some patients may require a change in therapy.
  • Efavirenz has good central nervous system penetration, which contributes to both its efficacy and its CNS-related adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abacavir: Can cause myocardial infarction and hypersensitivity reactions, particularly in patients with the HLA-B*5701 allele, but is not associated with neuropsychiatric side effects like vivid dreams or dizziness.

 

Option C. Emtricitabine: A well-tolerated nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), often used in combination therapies. It rarely causes CNS effects. It causes tree like pigmentation on hand and feet.

 

Option D. Ritonavir: A protease inhibitor mainly used to boost other PIs via CYP3A4 inhibition. Common side effects include GI upset, lipid abnormalities, hepatotoxicity and Lipodystrophy syndromes, but not typically 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efavirenz is associated with neuropsychiatric side effects such as vivid dreams, insomnia, dizziness, and impaired concentration, especially early in treatment. These effects are dose-related and usually occur within the first few weeks of initiation.

questions.text: Identify the cartilage given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White fibrocartilage 

 

  • The given image shows a dense arrangement of collagen fibers in bundles with rows of round chondrocytes embedded between them. These histological features are characteristic of white fibrocartilage.
  • Fibrocartilage displays:
    • Type I collagen fibers in abundance, giving it a highly fibrous, eosinophilic appearance.
    • Chondrocytes arranged in rows between the collagen bundles.
    • Absence of perichondrium, which differentiates it from hyaline and elastic cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: Contains Type II collagen, appears glassy and lacks the thick collagen bundles seen here.

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: Although also lacks perichondrium, it does not show the fibrous texture with distinct bundles of collagen seen in fibrocartilage.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): Contains elastic fibers and appears more loosely arranged with a yellowish tinge, typically found in ear pinna and epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • White fibrocartilage is a tough, durable cartilage designed to withstand pressure and shearing forces. 
  • It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, articular discs, and tendon insertions, and is rich in Type I collagen but lacks a perichondrium, which distinguishes it microscopically from hyaline and elastic cartilage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of deep, aching pain in her left buttock that radiates down the posterior thigh. The pain is exacerbated by prolonged sitting, climbing stairs, and running, but it is relieved by walking. The patient denies any history of trauma or direct injury to the hip. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the region of the left buttock, overlying the piriformis muscle. The Straight Leg Raise test is negative, but a Patrick’s test (FABER test) is positive for pain reproduction. There is no weakness or sensory loss in the lower limb, and neurological examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piriformis syndrome

 

  • Buttock pain radiating down the posterior thigh, worsened by sitting, stair climbing, and running, with tenderness over the piriformis and a negative Straight Leg Raise (SLR) but positive FABER test — is classic for piriformis syndrome.
  • Piriformis syndrome Caused by irritation or compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle in the buttock.
  • Classic features include:
    • Deep buttock pain that may radiate down the posterior thigh (sciatic nerve distribution).
    • Worsened by sitting, running, or climbing stairs.
    • Tenderness over the piriformis muscle.
    • Normal neurological exam (no true radiculopathy).
    • Negative SLR, but positive FABER or FAIR test can reproduce the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lumbar radiculopathy:

  • Caused by nerve root compression in the lumbar spine (e.g., due to degenerative disc disease or disc herniation).
  • Symptoms often include:
    • Radiating pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness in a dermatomal distribution.
    • Positive Straight Leg Raise test.
  • In this case:
    • Neurological exam is normal.
    • SLR is negative, which makes lumbar radiculopathy unlikely.
    • Pain is localized to the buttock, not the lower back.

 

Option B. Sciatica due to herniated disc:

  • While this can cause pain radiating down the posterior leg (sciatica), it typically originates from lumbar disc herniation.
  • Features would include:
    • Low back pain, neurological deficits, positive SLR, and possibly motor weakness.
  • This patient has no back pain, no sensory loss, no weakness, and normal SLR — which argues against disc herniation.

 

Option D. Trochanteric bursitis:

  • Involves inflammation of the bursa over the greater trochanter (outer hip).
  • Presents with:
    • Lateral hip pain (not buttock pain).
    • Pain with lying on the affected side, walking, or climbing stairs.
    • Tenderness over the lateral aspect of the hip.
  • This patient has medial buttock pain, not lateral hip pain, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of buttock pain, radiation down the thigh, pain with sitting and activity, localized tenderness over the piriformis, and normal neurological findings strongly supports piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man undergoing induction chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia presents with fever and cough for 4 days. He is profoundly neutropenic. CT chest findings is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis
