  • The CT image demonstrates a "halo sign" — a central nodular opacity surrounded by ground-glass attenuation — a classic early radiographic finding in angioinvasive aspergillosis. 
  • The clinical setting of neutropenia further supports the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lung abscess: Lung abscess typically shows air-fluid levels and thick-walled cavitation, usually in alcoholics or aspirators.

 

Option C. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary TB presents with diffuse, millet-sized nodules, not a single halo lesion.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism with infarction: Pulmonary infarcts appear as wedge-shaped peripheral opacities, not as nodules with ground-glass halo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neutropenic patients, a nodular lung lesion with surrounding ground-glass opacity on CT (halo sign) strongly suggests angioinvasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 6 x 4 cm right breast lump in the upper medial quadrant. The lump is fixed to the pectoralis major. Examination reveals no axillary nodes but a left-sided supraclavicular node. Investigation confirms it to be an invasive ductal carcinoma. Her TNM stage is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T3N0M1

 

  • A 6 cm tumor implies T3. Fixity to P. Major doesn’t affect the T stage
  • Absence of ipsilateral nodal metastasis is seen- N0.
  • Any contralateral nodal involvement is M1 disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A clinical laboratory reports serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels from a sample of 100 ambulatory adult patients undergoing routine thyroid function testing. The following summary statistics are observed: 

 

  • Mean = 3.1 mIU/L,
  • Median = 2.5 mIU/L, 
  • Mode = 1.8 mIU/L.

 

Based on this data, which of the following best describes the shape of the distribution of serum TSH levels in this sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right-skewed

 

  • Skewness describes the asymmetry of a distribution:
    • In a right-skewed distribution (positively skewed), the mean > median > mode because extreme high values pull the mean to the right.
    • In a left-skewed distribution (negatively skewed), the mean < median < mode due to extreme low values.
    • In a symmetric distribution, the mean ≈ median ≈ mode.
  • In this case:
    • Mean (3.1) > Median (2.5) > Mode (1.8). This pattern reflects a right-skewed (positively skewed) distribution, meaning that most values are clustered on the lower end, but a few higher values are pulling the mean upward.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symmetric: Incorrect. In a symmetric distribution, the mean, median, and mode are approximately equal, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Left-skewed: Incorrect. A left-skewed distribution would show mean < median < mode. Here, the opposite is true.

 

Option D. U-shaped distribution: Incorrect. A U-shaped distribution has two peaks (bimodal) with fewer values in the center, and this cannot be determined from summary statistics alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skewness can be inferred from the relative positions of the mean, median, and mode:
    • Mean > Median > Mode → Right (positive) skew
    • Mean < Median < Mode → Left (negative) skew
    • Mean ≈ Median ≈ Mode → Symmetric distribution

choices.text: This includes all pregnancies born after 280 days of pregnancy
Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia
Amniocentesis should be routinely done to confirm fetal lung maturity prior to induction of labor
Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents at 41 weeks and 3 days of gestation for a routine antenatal check-up. She has no complications during pregnancy thus far, and fetal growth parameters have been within normal limits. She expresses concern about the risks associated with continuing the pregnancy beyond her due date and inquires whether additional testing or interventions are needed. Which amongst the following is a true statement regarding post term pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia

 

Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia - True.


Post-term pregnancy (defined as ≥42 weeks of gestation) is associated with increased risks of:

 

  • Oligohydramnios: Decreased amniotic fluid due to placental aging and reduced fetal urine output.
  • Fetal macrosomia: Excessive fetal growth, increasing the risk of shoulder dystocia, labor complications, and cesarean section.

 

These are well-established and clinically significant complications of prolonged pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This includes all pregnancies born after 280 days of pregnancy: Incorrect. 280 days corresponds to 40 weeks, which is the estimated due date (EDD). However, post-term pregnancy is defined as lasting 42 weeks (294 days) or more. Therefore, this statement misrepresents the actual definition of post-term pregnancy.

 

Option C. Amniocentesis should be routinely done to confirm fetal lung maturity prior to induction of labor: Incorrect. Routine amniocentesis for fetal lung maturity is not indicated in pregnancies beyond term. At or after 39 weeks, fetal lungs are presumed to be mature, and decisions about induction rely on gestational age and fetal surveillance, not on lung maturity testing.

 

Option D. Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation: Incorrect. While fetal surveillance (e.g., nonstress test and amniotic fluid assessment) may be initiated at or after 41 weeks, it is not universally recommended across all guidelines. Surveillance becomes standard and strongly advised after 42 weeks, i.e., when the pregnancy becomes truly post-term. Therefore, the blanket statement that it is recommended after 41 weeks is too strong and not universally accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complications of a post term pregnancy (> 42 weeks) include:

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance. He has never smoked. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion. Pulmonary function tests show an obstructive pattern. A liver biopsy shows pink, PAS-positive globules in hepatocytes. Which of the following best explains the underlying cause of this patient's disease? 

 

  1. Excess elastase activity causes centriacinar emphysema predominantly in the upper lobes.
  2. Mutated antiprotease accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage and panacinar emphysema.
  3. Chronic tobacco smoke exposure increases goblet cell hyperplasia and submucosal gland hypertrophy.
  4. Autoimmune destruction of alveolar walls leads to honeycombing of the lung bases.
  5. Bronchial obstruction leads to air trapping and recurrent infections with mucus plugging.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B only 

 

  • This patient has Alpha-1 Antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency, a rare cause of emphysema. A1AT is an antiprotease that protects alveolar walls from protease-mediated damage, particularly elastase released by neutrophils. In its absence, unopposed protease activity damages the air sacs, resulting in panacinar emphysema, which is most severe in the lower lobes of the lung.
  • In addition to lung disease, liver cirrhosis may also be present. This occurs because A1AT deficiency is due to misfolding of the mutated protein, which causes the mutant A1AT to accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, leading to hepatocellular injury. 
  • On liver biopsy, these accumulations appear as pink, PAS-positive globules.

 

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

A. Excess elastase activity causes centriacinar emphysema predominantly in the upper lobes: Incorrect. This describes smoking-related emphysema, not A1AT deficiency. In A1AT deficiency, emphysema is panacinar and affects the lower lobes.

 

C. Chronic tobacco smoke exposure increases goblet cell hyperplasia and submucosal gland hypertrophy: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of chronic bronchitis, not A1AT deficiency. Also, this patient has never smoked, and the biopsy findings point to A1AT accumulation, not mucus overproduction.

 

D. Autoimmune destruction of alveolar walls leads to honeycombing of the lung bases: Incorrect. This describes idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, not A1AT deficiency. There’s no mention of autoimmune features, fibrosis, or honeycombing in this case.

 

E. Bronchial obstruction leads to air trapping and recurrent infections with mucus plugging: Incorrect. This is characteristic of bronchiectasis or obstructive airway disease due to infections or tumors, not A1AT deficiency. There's no mention of mucus plugging, and the pathology described points to protein accumulation in hepatocytes, not airway blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency causes panacinar emphysema (most severe in the lower lobes) and liver cirrhosis due to misfolded A1AT protein accumulating in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, seen as pink, PAS-positive globules on biopsy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension is being considered for a new antihypertensive medication. His physician is weighing various options, taking into consideration their potential impact on plasma renin activity, which could have downstream effects on blood pressure control. All of the following drugs increase plasma renin activity except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clonidine

 

  • All antihypertensive drugs result in compensatory increase in sympathetic activity.
  • This tends to increase plasma renin levels and plasma renin activity due to stimulation of beta 1 receptors in JG cells of kidney. 
  • However, those antihypertensive drugs will decrease plasma renin levels that work by stopping sympathetic activity like beta blockers and alpha 2 agonists. 
  • Clonidine is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist similar to clonidine. 
  • It decreases sympathetic nervous system activity, which generally results in a decrease in renin release from the juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney.
  • This leads to lower plasma renin activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: This calcium channel blocker reduces arterial pressure and typically triggers a compensatory increase in renin release to restore blood pressure, thereby increasing plasma renin activity.

 

Option C. Enalapril: This angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor reduces levels of angiotensin II, reflux increase in renin activity.

 

Option D. Prazosin: This alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist reduces vascular tone, leading to a compensatory increase in renin release to restore blood pressure, thereby increasing plasma renin activity. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine decreases plasma renin activity by reducing central sympathetic outflow, distinguishing it from other antihypertensive agents that increase plasma renin activity.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with severe, deep, boring pain and redness in the left eye. The pain is persistent and intense enough to disturb sleep. Ocular ultrasonography (B-scan) reveals a ‘T-sign’ involving the outer coats of the eyeball. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior scleritis

 

  • Posterior scleritis is an inflammatory disease of the posterior sclera that classically presents with:
    • Severe deep, boring ocular pain
    • Redness
    • Pain may be severe enough to disturb sleep
    • In the mild form, there is thickening. 
    • In the severe form, there is increased inflammation and separation of layers, resulting in characteristic T-sign on B-scan ultrasonography.
  • On imaging, ultrasound B-scan often reveals a ‘T-sign’, due to fluid in Tenon’s space separating the sclera from the choroid and optic nerve shadow.

 

 

  • This diagnosis must be considered in elderly patients with deep eye pain and no clear anterior pathology, especially when imaging findings are supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Presents with photophobia, ciliary injection, and pain, but typically involves the anterior segment. It does not produce a ‘T-sign’ on B-scan and lacks the deep, boring quality of pain typical in posterior scleritis.

 

Option C. Scleromalacia perforans: A painless, necrotizing form of scleritis, often associated with rheumatoid arthritis. There is no redness, no pain, and no T-sign, making it inconsistent with this presentation. There is thinning of the sclera with the underlying uvea shining through.

 

 

Option D. Acute angle-closure glaucoma: Presents with sudden onset of severe ocular pain, mid-dilated pupil, corneal edema, and increased intraocular pressure. It is not associated with a ‘T-sign’, and while pain is severe, the imaging findings and history differ significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior scleritis is characterized by deep, boring ocular pain and the presence of a T-sign on B-scan ultrasonography, indicating inflammation and fluid in Tenon’s space.

questions.text: A 33-year-old traveler returns from a beach vacation in Southeast Asia and presents with intensely itchy, serpiginous, erythematous tracks on the soles of his feet. The lesions appear to be slowly migrating. Based on clinical suspicion, cutaneous larva migrans is diagnosed. Which of the following hookworm species is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

  • Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) is a zoonotic parasitic skin disease caused by the intraepidermal migration of nematode larvae, most commonly dog and cat hookworms. Key points include:
    • It presents with itchy, creeping, serpiginous skin lesions, often on feet, buttocks, or thighs.
    • The most common causative organisms are:
      • Ancylostoma braziliense (most common)
      • Ancylostoma caninum
      • Ancylostoma ceylanicum
  • These animal hookworms cannot penetrate deeply into human tissue, so they remain trapped in the epidermis, causing the classic cutaneous pattern.
  • Ancylostoma duodenale is a human hookworm that penetrates the skin, enters the bloodstream, and causes systemic infection, including iron-deficiency anemia, not cutaneous larva migrans. It does not get trapped in the skin to cause the serpiginous tracks. It causes gastroenteritic symptoms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ancylostoma caninum: This is a dog hookworm that can occasionally infect humans. It is primarily known to cause cutaneous larva migrans (CLM), a skin condition resulting from the migration of larvae through the epidermis, leading to serpiginous, itchy lesions.

 

Option B. Ancylostoma ceylanicum: Can infect both animals and humans; known to cause cutaneous larva migrans and occasionally enteric symptoms.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma braziliense: The most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans in tropical and subtropical regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by animal hookworms such as Ancylostoma braziliense, caninum, and ceylanicum, but not by Ancylostoma duodenale, which is a human hookworm that causes systemic disease.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. On physical examination, the child’s height and weight are below the expected growth percentile. Laboratory investigations show a positive result for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following dietary modifications would be most appropriate for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

  • This child's presentation, including chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and growth retardation, is consistent with Celiac Disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. 
  • The presence of HLA-DQ2 class II antigen further supports this diagnosis, as it is commonly associated with Celiac Disease.
  • The primary treatment for Celiac Disease is a strict gluten-free diet, which leads to improvement in symptoms and prevention of long-term complications such as nutritional deficiencies and growth impairment. 
  • The gluten-free diet helps manage inflammation and damage in the small intestine caused by gluten exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not the recommended diet for Celiac Disease. A fat-free diet is typically used for managing conditions related to fat malabsorption, such as pancreatic insufficiency or gallbladder disease. It would not address the underlying cause of the child’s symptoms related to gluten intolerance.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While lactose intolerance is common in individuals with Celiac Disease, it is not the primary concern in this case. A lactose-free diet might help alleviate some gastrointestinal symptoms temporarily, but it will not address the root cause, which is gluten sensitivity.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: A low carbohydrate diet is not indicated for Celiac Disease. This type of diet is more relevant in managing conditions like obesity or type 2 diabetes, not for gluten-induced autoimmune disorders like Celiac Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Celiac Disease, the definitive treatment is a gluten-free diet, which helps alleviate symptoms and prevent long-term complications. 
  • Positive findings for HLA-DQ2 are a strong indicator of genetic susceptibility to the disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with psoriasis develops new joint pain and a rash as shown in the image below. She was on infliximab for the past 3 months. ANA is positive at 1:320. Which autoantibody is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-Histone & Anti-dsDNA

 

  • This patient likely has drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), triggered by infliximab, a TNF-α inhibitor known to cause lupus-like syndrome. 
  • The most commonly positive antibody in DILE is anti-histone, seen in >90% of cases. 
  • However, TNF-inhibitor-induced lupus is somewhat unique—it may also present with anti-dsDNA positivity, which is more typical of idiopathic SLE. 
  • ANA is usually positive in high titers in both forms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Anti-Histone & Anti-Sm: Anti-Sm is specific for idiopathic SLE, not drug-induced lupus. It is not typically seen in TNF-inhibitor-induced lupus.
 

Option C. Anti-Histone & Anti-Ro: Anti-Ro (SSA) is more commonly seen in subacute cutaneous lupus and Sjogren’s syndrome, not in drug-induced lupus.
 

Option D. Anti-Histone & Anti-TPO: Anti-TPO is a marker of autoimmune thyroid disease (like Hashimoto’s thyroiditis), unrelated to lupus or drug-induced lupus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infliximab and other TNF-α inhibitors can cause a unique form of drug-induced lupus characterized by high-titer ANA, anti-histone, and occasionally anti-dsDNA positivity—distinguishing it from classic DILE. 
  • Always monitor patients on biologics for lupus-like symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Staphylococcus aureus-specific enzymes are incorrect? 

 

  1. The coagulase test is used to differentiate S. aureus from coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS).
  2. Thermonuclease produced by S. aureus is heat-stable and can digest DNA.
  3. The DNase test is positive in both S. aureus and CoNS species.
  4. Phosphatase activity is absent in S. aureus, which differentiates it from other Gram-positive cocci.
  5. All listed enzyme activities are typically absent in CoNS.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both 3 and 4

 

Incorrect Statements: 

 

Statement 3. The DNase test is positive in both S. aureus and CoNS species: Incorrect. The DNase test is positive for S. aureus, but negative in most CoNS, making this a key differentiating test.

 

Statement 4. Phosphatase activity is absent in S. aureus, which differentiates it from other Gram-positive cocci: Incorrect. S. aureus is phosphatase -positive, not negative. The phosphatase test helps distinguish S. aureus from CoNS, where CoNS are typically phosphatase negative.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. The coagulase test is used to differentiate S. aureus from coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS): Correct. The coagulase test (both slide and tube method) is classically used to differentiate S. aureus (coagulase-positive) from CoNS (coagulase-negative staphylococci).

 

Statement 2. Thermonuclease produced by S. aureus is heat-stable and can digest DNA: Correct. Thermonuclease is a heat-stable enzyme produced by S. aureus that can degrade DNA and remains active even after boiling, which helps in diagnostic testing.

 

Statement 5. All listed enzyme activities are typically absent in CoNS: Correct. CoNS generally lack all the listed enzyme activities, including coagulase, thermonuclease, DNase, and phosphatase, making these features specific for S. aureus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S. aureus is uniquely positive for coagulase, heat-stable thermonuclease, DNase, and phosphatase; these enzyme activities are typically absent in coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), making them useful for laboratory differentiation.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Maneuvers for Shoulder Dystocia and Their Descriptions:

 

Column A (Maneuver)

  1. McRoberts maneuver
  2. Suprapubic pressure
  3. Rubin II maneuver
  4. Woods’ screw maneuver
  5. Gaskin maneuver

 

Column B (Description)

  1. Rotation of the anterior shoulder to posterior to dislodge impacted shoulder
  2. Maternal hip hyperflexion to flatten the lumbar spine and widen pelvic outlet
  3. Posterior-directed pressure on the anterior shoulder to move fetus into oblique angle
  4. Changing maternal position to hands-and-knees to increase pelvic dimensions
  5. Pressure applied over pubic area toward the posterior aspect of fetal anterior shoulder
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–5, C–3, D–1, E–4

 

Explanation:

 

A–2. McRoberts maneuver: Involves hyperflexion of the maternal hips onto the abdomen to flatten the lumbar spine and widen the pelvic outlet.

 

B–5. Suprapubic pressure: Pressure is directed posteriorly and laterally over the pubic area to assist in dislodging the anterior fetal shoulder.

 

C–3. Rubin II maneuver: Posterior-directed pressure on the anterior fetal shoulder to rotate it into an oblique plane.

 

D–1. Woods’ screw maneuver: Simultaneous pressure on the posterior shoulder to rotate the fetus, effectively turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior.

 

E–4. Gaskin maneuver: Positioning the mother on all fours (hands and knees), increasing pelvic dimensions and facilitating delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that requires prompt maneuvering to release the impacted fetal shoulder. 
  • A systematic approach using well-established maneuvers—such as McRoberts, suprapubic pressure, Rubin II, Woods' screw, and Gaskin—is essential to safely resolve the obstruction and minimize fetal and maternal morbidity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, known case of cirrhosis of the liver, presents with an abdominal lump. Imaging reveals a solitary 3 x 4 cm nodule with rapid washout of contrast in the venous phase. Serum AFP levels are elevated. Which clinical criteria would decide suitability for liver transplant in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Milan criteria

 

  • Milan criteria are utilised to ascertain suitability for liver transplant in patients with cirrhosis and hepatoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child’s score: Severity of chronic liver disease

 

Option B. LIRADS score: LI-RADS stands for Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System, a standardized system used in radiology to evaluate liver lesions in patients with risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

 

Option D. King’s College criteria: For liver transplant in acute liver failure

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Transplantation for HCC, first described by Mazzaferro in 1996 for patients with tumours ≤5 cm or up to three nodules ≤3 cm, achieved 4-year overall survivals of 75% and recurrence-free survivals of 83%. 
  • These inclusion criteria were adopted as the “Milan criteria”, with angioinvasion and extrahepatic involvement as additional exclusion criteria, and are now universally accepted.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axillary region. Skin scrapings were collected and inoculated on Sabaroud’s Dextrose agar. After incubation, the organism shows the characteristic appearance as seen in the image provided. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

  • Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophyte fungus and the most common cause of tinea infections (dermatophytoses). Key identifying features include:
    • Red pigment production on culture (on Sabouraud’s dextrose agar or cornmeal agar)
    • Pencil-shaped (elongated, smooth-walled) macroconidia, as seen in the image
    • Commonly infects skin, hair, and nails
    • Causes tinea corporis, tinea cruris, and tinea pedis
  • The combination of red pigmentation and microscopic morphology is classic for T. rubrum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton violaceum: Produces violaceous (purple) colonies; lacks distinctive macroconidia. More common in tinea capitis, especially in endemic regions.

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans: A common cause of tinea capitis, especially in children. Characterized by chlamydoconidia and rare macroconidia. It does not produce red pigment, rather it produces whitish colonies.

 

Option D. Trichophyton schoenleinii: Associated with favus, a chronic form of tinea capitis. Shows antler-shaped hyphae (favic chandeliers) rather than macroconidia. The colonies are typically whitish in appearance and do not produce red pigmentation.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by red pigment production in culture and pencil-shaped macroconidia; it is the most common dermatophyte causing tinea infections.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding amyloidosis is/are correct? 

 

  1. Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular deposition of abnormal protein fibrils that interfere with normal tissue function.
  2. Congo red staining under polarized light reveals a characteristic apple-green birefringence, which is considered diagnostic for amyloid deposits.
  3. X-ray crystallography can detect the presence of beta-pleated sheet conformations, which are a hallmark of amyloid fibrils.
  4. The primary form of amyloidosis, known as AL amyloidosis, occurs due to an accumulation of amyloid deposits secondary to chronic inflammation.
  5. The extracellular amyloid deposits primarily consist of misfolded proteins that accumulate within cells, leading to organ dysfunction.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 are correct

 

Statement 1. Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular deposition of abnormal protein fibrils that interfere with normal tissue function: Correct. Amyloidosis is the deposition of abnormal protein fibrils in tissues, primarily in the extracellular space.

 

Statement 2. Congo red staining under polarized light reveals a characteristic apple-green birefringence, which is considered diagnostic for amyloid deposits: Correct. The apple-green birefringence seen with Congo red staining is a classic feature of amyloid deposits under polarized light.

 

Statement 3. X-ray crystallography can detect the presence of beta-pleated sheet conformations, which are a hallmark of amyloid fibrils: Correct. The amyloid fibrils show beta-pleated sheet structures, detectable by X-ray crystallography.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 4. The primary form of amyloidosis, known as AL amyloidosis, occurs due to an accumulation of amyloid deposits secondary to chronic inflammation: Incorrect. AL amyloidosis is a primary form, not secondary. Secondary amyloidosis is linked with chronic inflammatory conditions and is usually associated with AA amyloidosis.

 

Statement 5. The extracellular amyloid deposits primarily consist of misfolded proteins that accumulate within cells, leading to organ dysfunction: Incorrect. Amyloid deposits are extracellular, not intracellular, and cause organ dysfunction through deposition in tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloidosis involves extracellular deposition of misfolded protein fibrils with beta-pleated sheet structure, best identified by Congo red staining (showing apple-green birefringence) and confirmed structurally by X-ray crystallography

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A:

  1. First trimester parameter
  2. Second trimester parameter
  3. Third trimester parameter

 

Column B: (Parameter for assessing gestational age)

  1. Femur length (FL)
  2. Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  3. Crown-rump length (CRL)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1

 

A-3. First trimester parameter — Crown-rump length: CRL is the most accurate parameter for assessing gestational age in the first trimester. It measures the distance from the crown to the rump of the fetus and is highly reliable during this period.

 

B-2. Second trimester parameter — Biparietal diameter: BPD is the most accurate parameter in the second trimester. It is measured in the transthalamic view, from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge in the far field.

 

C-1. Third trimester parameter — Femur length: FL is used in the third trimester to estimate gestational age, especially when other parameters become less reliable due to fetal growth variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The accuracy of fetal parameters for gestational age estimation changes across trimesters:
    • First trimester: CRL is most accurate.
    • Second trimester: BPD provides the best estimate.
    • Third trimester: FL is useful when other measurements are less reliable.

choices.text: Internal sphincter injury doesn’t lead to fecal incontinence if the external sphincter is intact
The external sphincter is a continuation of the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the rectum
Anal canal is derived entirely from proctodaeum
Part of the anus above the dentate line lacks sensations

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about anal anatomy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anal canal is derived entirely from proctodaeum

 

  • Anal canal is derived from cloaca (above dentate line) and proctodaeum (below dentate line).
  • The anal canal has dual embryonic origins; the portion above the dentate line is derived from the endoderm (cloaca), while the area below is from the ectoderm (proctodeum).

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Internal sphincter injury doesn’t lead to fecal incontinence if the external sphincter is intact: Correct. The internal sphincter, made up of smooth muscle, contributes to some amount continence at rest. Injury to this sphincter doesn’t indeed lead to fecal incontinence, if external sphincter is intact.

 

Option B. The external sphincter is a continuation of the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the rectum: Correct. The external sphincter is made up of skeletal muscle, which is under voluntary control and is a continuation of the outer longitudinal muscle of the rectum.

 

Option D. Part of the anus above the dentate line lacks sensations: Correct. The part of the anus above the dentate line lacks sensations such as pain and temperature because it is innervated by visceral sensory fibers, unlike the area below the dentate line, which has somatic innervation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The anal canal has dual embryological origins: the upper part from the hindgut (endoderm) and the lower part from the proctodaeum (ectoderm); it is incorrect to that it is derived entirely from the proctodaeum.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with a 1-week history of a skin rash. The rash started on the face and limbs and progressively spread to the buttocks, forming multiple dusky red papules that later coalesced into plaques. The child is otherwise afebrile and active. On examination, the rash is symmetrically distributed, sparing the trunk and mucosal membranes. There is also mild hepatomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy. The mother reports that the child received routine vaccinations 10 days ago, and his hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gianotti-Crosti Syndrome

 

  • The classic findings here — symmetrically distributed dusky red papules, involvement of face, limbs, and buttocks, sparing of trunk, associated lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and recent viral trigger (HBV) — are hallmark features of Gianotti-Crosti Syndrome (also called papular acrodermatitis).
  • These patients will have some vaccines and acrodermatitis.
  • It often follows a viral illness or vaccination and is linked to viruses such as:
    • Hepatitis B virus
    • Epstein-Barr virus
    • Coxsackievirus A16
    • Parainfluenza virus
  • The condition is self-limiting, and treatment is typically supportive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen Planus: Rare in infants, often affects mucosa and has violaceous flat-topped papules, not seen in this case.

 

Option B. Darier Disease: Genetic disorder with greasy, warty papules in seborrheic areas; not associated with HBV or symmetric rash.

 

Option D. Porokeratosis: Characterized by annular plaques with a keratotic ridge, often chronic and not associated with viral triggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gianotti-Crosti syndrome is a self-limited papular acrodermatitis seen in young children following viral infections (especially HBV) or vaccinations.
  • Key features include:
    • Symmetrical dusky papular rash on face, limbs, and buttocks
    • Sparing of trunk and mucosa
    • Associated lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly
    • Spontaneous resolution without treatment in most cases.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia. Genetic analysis identifies a mutation in the TCIRG1 gene. Skeletal survey reveals the following. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteopetrosis

 

  • The clinical presentation and radiographic findings are classic for infantile malignant osteopetrosis, which is caused by mutations in the TCIRG1 gene. This gene encodes a subunit of the osteoclast proton pump necessary for bone resorption.
  • In autosomal recessive osteopetrosis, defective osteoclasts fail to remodel bone properly, leading to:
    • Diffuse bony sclerosis
    • Marrow cavity obliteration → pancytopenia
    • Extramedullary hematopoiesis → hepatosplenomegaly
    • Cranial nerve compression → visual/hearing loss
  • The autosomal recessive form presents in infancy and is severe, often requiring hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for survival.
  • The x-ray given in the question shows diffusely increased bone density and Erlenmeyer flask deformity (which is non-specific).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher disease: Also presents with hepatosplenomegaly and cytopenias, but radiologically shows Erlenmeyer flask deformities, not generalized sclerosis or “bone-in-bone” appearance. The bone density in Gaucher disease is decreased (osteopenia due to bone marrow infiltration by Gaucher cells).

 

Option C. Infantile cortical hyperostosis (Caffey disease): Presents with fever, irritability, and cortical thickening, particularly of the mandible and long bones, but does not cause marrow failure or “bone-in-bone” X-ray features.

 

Option D. X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets: Causes bowing of legs, growth delay, and hypophosphatemia, but X-rays show metaphyseal cupping and fraying, not sclerosis. There will be decreased bone density.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile malignant osteopetrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by osteoclast dysfunction, leading to bony sclerosis, pancytopenia, and extramedullary hematopoiesis, often presenting in early infancy.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Developmental Milestones and Usual Age: 

 

Column A (Milestone)

 

  1. Holding of objects with both hands
  2. Transfer of objects
  3. Tripod sitting
  4. Pulls to standing
  5. Pincer grasp

 

Column B (Usual Age)

 

  1. 4 months
  2. 7 months
  3. 6 months
  4. 9 months – child begins to stand holding onto furniture
  5. 9 months – fine grasp using thumb and index finger
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A–1, B–2, C–3, D–4, E–5

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Match each pelvic floor defect with its most appropriate corrective surgical procedure:

 

Column A – Deformity

  1. Cystocele
  2. Vault prolapse
  3. Enterocele
  4. Utero-vaginal prolapse

 

Column B – Corrective Surgery

  1. McCall’s repair
  2. Ward Mayo repair
  3. Sacrocolpopexy
  4. Anterior colporrhaphy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1–D, 2–C, 3–A, 4–B

 

1-D. Cystocele (herniation of bladder into vaginal wall) → Anterior colporrhaphy is the standard repair technique.

 

2-C. Vault prolapse (post-hysterectomy prolapse of vaginal apex) → Sacrocolpopexy is preferred to restore pelvic support using mesh.

 

3-A. Enterocele (herniation of pouch of Douglas) → McCall's repair is commonly used at the time of vaginal hysterectomy to prevent or treat it.

 

4-B. Utero-vaginal prolapse: → Ward Mayo repair, a type of vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair, is the classic procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation following a hysterectomy that revealed endometrial carcinoma. Her family history is notable for her mother dying from endometrial cancer at age 50 and her 42-year-old brother recently diagnosed with colorectal carcinoma. Further investigation is pursued to determine if a genetic predisposition is responsible for the pattern of malignancies observed across generations. Which of the following genes is most likely mutated in this family?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MSH2

 

  • This clinical presentation suggests a hereditary cancer syndrome, specifically Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, HNPCC). 
  • Lynch syndrome is associated with germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, most commonly MSH2 (mutS homolog 2) and MLH1.
  • This syndrome significantly increases the risk for colorectal cancer, endometrial carcinoma, and other malignancies. 
  • The woman’s early-onset endometrial cancer, in conjunction with her mother’s history of endometrial cancer at age 50 and her brother’s diagnosis of colon cancer at age 42, fits the pattern of autosomal dominant inheritance seen in Lynch syndrome.
  • MSH2, a critical component of the MMR pathway, is among the most frequently mutated genes in Lynch syndrome families. 
  • Mutations impair DNA repair, increasing the risk of microsatellite instability and cancer development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRCA1: This gene is associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome, not with colon or endometrial cancer. BRCA1 mutations increase the risk for breast, ovarian, pancreatic, and prostate cancers, but are not linked to the familial pattern of endometrial and colorectal cancer seen in this question.

 

Option C. WT-1: The Wilms tumor 1 gene is a tumor suppressor associated with Wilms tumor, a pediatric kidney cancer. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of endometrial or colorectal cancers, nor is it relevant in adults or familial cancer syndromes with the described pattern.

 

Option D. APC: Mutations in the APC gene are characteristic of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which leads to hundreds of colonic adenomas and a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer if untreated. However, FAP is not associated with endometrial carcinoma, which is a key part of the clinical picture in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MSH2 is a DNA mismatch repair gene commonly mutated in Lynch syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome characterized by early-onset colorectal and endometrial cancers.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase (SHMT) are incorrect? 

 

  1. Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase belongs to the class II group of enzymes.
  2. The enzyme catalyzes an irreversible reaction converting serine to glycine.
  3. Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) and folic acid derivatives are essential cofactors for this enzyme’s activity.
  4. The conversion of serine to glycine involves the donation of the β-carbon of serine to tetrahydrofolate (THFA).
  5. The α-carbon of serine is donated to THFA during the reaction.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 2 and 5

 

Incorrect Statements: 

 

Statement 2. The enzyme catalyzes an irreversible reaction converting serine to glycine: Incorrect. The reaction is stated as freely reversible, so saying it is irreversible is false.

 

Statement 5. The α-carbon of serine is donated to THFA during the reaction: Incorrect. The α-carbon is not donated; it remains part of the glycine molecule. The β-carbon is the one transferred to THFA.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase belongs to the class II group of enzymes: Correct. SHMT belongs to class II enzymes, as explicitly stated.

 

Statement 3. Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) and folic acid derivatives are essential cofactors for this enzyme’s activity: Correct. PLP (pyridoxal phosphate) and folic acid are indeed the required vitamin cofactors for SHMT.

 

Statement 4. The conversion of serine to glycine involves the donation of the β-carbon of serine to tetrahydrofolate (THFA): Correct. The β-carbon of serine is donated to THFA, forming a one-carbon unit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase (SHMT) catalyzes a reversible reaction that converts serine to glycine, involving the donation of the β-carbon of serine to THFA, and requires PLP and folic acid as cofactors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas, normal cholesterol levels, and markedly elevated plasma triglycerides (~1500 mg/dL). Laboratory analysis reveals the presence of chylomicrons in fasting plasma. Which of the following deficiencies is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipoprotein lipase

 

  • The clinical presentation is classic for Type I hyperlipoproteinemia (also called familial chylomicronemia syndrome), a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by:
    • Very high plasma triglyceride levels (>1000 mg/dL),
    • Eruptive xanthomas,
    • Lipemia retinalis,
    • Milky white plasma,
    • Recurrent episodes of pancreatitis, and
    • Chylomicron accumulation in fasting plasma.
  • The condition is caused by deficiency of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) or its cofactor ApoC-II, which is required for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL.
  • Without functional LPL:
    • Triglyceride-rich chylomicrons cannot be broken down, leading to accumulation of chylomicrons, and subsequent hypertriglyceridemia, increasing the risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL receptors: Deficiency leads to familial hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa), characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol, not triglycerides, and does not involve chylomicrons. The patient presents with chest pain.

 

Option C. HMG-CoA reductase: This is the rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis and is the target of statin therapy. Its deficiency does not cause hypertriglyceridemia or chylomicronemia.

 

Option D. ApoB-48: ApoB-48 is essential for chylomicron formation. Its deficiency would result in low or absent chylomicrons, not accumulation. Hence, it does not explain chylomicronemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, causing severe hypertriglyceridemia, chylomicronemia, recurrent pancreatitis, and eruptive xanthomas, despite normal cholesterol levels.

choices.text: It can control bleeding from fundic varices
It can be used for 1-2 weeks
It lacks an esophageal aspiration port

questions.text: Identify the incorrect feature of the tube shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It can be used for 1-2 weeks

 

  • The given image shows the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube, used for balloon tamponade in variceal bleeding. It is used for 24-48 hours
  • It can be used for 1-2 weeks This statement is incorrect. 
  • The Blakemore tube is typically used for short-term management, usually for no more than 24-36 hours, due to the risk of complications such as pressure necrosis and perforation if used for extended durations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can control bleeding from fundic varices: This statement is correct. A Blakemore tube has a gastric balloon that can compress bleeding fundic varices by applying pressure, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

 

Option B. It is inserted orally: This statement is correct. The Blakemore tube is inserted through the mouth (orogastrically) to reach the stomach and esophagus for effective tamponade.

 

Option D. It lacks an esophageal aspiration port: This statement is correct. The Blakemore tube lacks an esophageal aspiration port, which differentiates it from the Minnesota tube that includes an esophageal suction port for draining secretions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The triple lumen Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used as a temporary measure to control acute bleeding from esophageal or gastric varices, typically caused by portal hypertension in cirrhotic patients. 
  • It achieves hemostasis by mechanical compression of the bleeding vessels

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with mild COPD and a history of childhood eczema is advised workplace smallpox vaccination. She is otherwise healthy and not on immunosuppressants. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication to smallpox vaccination in the absence of exposure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eczema

 

  • The smallpox vaccine contains live vaccinia virus and is contraindicated in individuals with current or past eczema due to the risk of eczema vaccinatum, a severe complication. 
  • This remains true even if the eczema is currently inactive.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Mild COPD: Not a contraindication unless on systemic steroids.
 

Option C. Early-stage cancer: Only a concern if there’s immunosuppression.
 

Option D. Peripheral artery disease (PAD): Has no impact on immune function or skin reactivity.

 

Educational Objective:


Live vaccinia vaccination is contraindicated in people with current or past eczema due to risk of life-threatening skin reactions.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with dizziness, fainting, and extremely low blood pressure after taking an erectile dysfunction medication the night before. His past medical history includes coronary artery disease, for which he is on multiple medications. On arrival, his blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg. Which of the following medications is most likely to have interacted with his erectile dysfunction drug to cause this episode of severe hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isosorbide dinitrate

 

  • Isosorbide dinitrate is a long-acting nitrate used to manage angina pectoris. It acts by releasing nitric oxide, leading to vasodilation and reduced preload. 
  • When taken in combination with phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors such as sildenafil (commonly used for erectile dysfunction), there is a synergistic vasodilatory effect, leading to profound hypotension and risk of circulatory collapse.
  • This combination is absolutely contraindicated, and patients must be advised to avoid nitrates within 24–48 hours of taking a PDE-5 inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: An antiplatelet agent that does not affect blood pressure or interact with erectile dysfunction medications. No hypotensive effect.

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker that can cause mild hypotension, but it does not have a synergistic vasodilatory interaction with PDE-5 inhibitors like nitrates do. Still safer than nitrate combinations.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker that may lower blood pressure and heart rate, but it does not directly interact with PDE-5 inhibitors to cause severe hypotension like nitrates do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combining nitrates such as isosorbide dinitrate with phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors is contraindicated due to the risk of life-threatening hypotension from synergistic vasodilation.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements about pediatric surgical principles in contrast to adults: 

 

  1. Wider abdomen with reduced vertical distance
  2. The urinary bladder is mainly intraperitoneal
  3. Ribs are more horizontal and rigid
  4. The umbilicus is lower than that of an adult
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Only 3 

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Ribs are more horizontal and rigid: Flexible ribs in children, which don’t easily fracture-> If fractures-> Sign of child abuse

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. Wider abdomen with reduced vertical distance: Wider abdomen with shallow pelvis- horizontal incisions are preferred in children-> EXPOSURE is better

 

Statement 2. The urinary bladder is mainly intraperitoneal: Urinary bladder is intra-peritoneal, liver extends sub-costally-> Easily traumatized in children following blunt trauma

 

Statement 4. The umbilicus is lower than that of an adult: Lower umbilicus-> Difficulty in stoma position in the lower abdomen

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In pediatric patients:

 

  • Wider abdomen and shallower pelvis = better exposure via transverse incisions
  • Intraperitoneal bladder = increased risk in blunt trauma
  • Lower umbilicus = complicates stoma placement
  • Flexible, horizontal ribs = rib fracture may indicate child abuse

 

Recognizing these anatomic and physiological differences is crucial for safe and effective pediatric surgical planning.

questions.text:
A dead body shows the following findings:

 

  • Discoloration over dependent parts
  • Sharply defined margins
  • Color does not change with time
  • Oozing blood easily washed off on incision
  • No surface elevation

 

Which condition can you most confidently exclude?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bruise

 

  • Discoloration over dependent parts: Typical of postmortem staining, where blood pools due to gravity after death.
  • Sharply defined margins: Characteristic of postmortem staining, not bruises. Bruises usually have diffuse and irregular margins.
  • Color does not change with time: Again, matches postmortem staining — bruises change color (red → blue → green → yellow) as hemoglobin breaks down.
  • Oozing blood easily washed off on incision: In postmortem staining, blood is still in vessels (capillo-venous distension) and can ooze out and be washed away easily.
    In bruises, blood is infiltrated into tissues and cannot be easily washed.
  • No surface elevation: Postmortem staining is flat; bruises may cause slight swelling due to blood extravasation.

 

Thus, bruise can be confidently excluded because:

 

  • Bruises have diffuse margins,
  • Color changes with time,
  • Blood infiltrates tissues (cannot be washed away),
  • May be slightly elevated.

 

All the findings here fit postmortem staining, not bruising.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postmortem staining: Matches perfectly with all findings, so cannot be excluded.

 

Option C. Congestion: Congestion involves internal organs (lungs, liver, stomach) and would not typically show sharply defined discoloration of external skin, but it's less confidently excluded than a bruise.

 

Option D. Decomposition changes: Decomposition shows greenish discoloration, marbling, gas formation, and skin slippage, none of which are described here — but based only on given findings, decomposition cannot be fully ruled out without additional signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem staining is characterized by dependent bluish discoloration, sharp margins, blanching early after death, no surface elevation, and blood that can be washed off on incision — whereas bruises involve diffuse margins, color change over time, subcutaneous infiltration, and cannot be washed away.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the orthopaedic clinic with persistent pain and difficulty moving his left leg following a tibia fracture that occurred 6 months ago. The fracture was initially treated with casting, but the patient reports that he has not regained full function of his leg. There is no significant displacement of the bone fragments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delayed union
 

  • A delayed union refers to a fracture that is taking longer than expected to heal, but healing is still ongoing.
  • Generally suspected if healing is not evident by 3–6 months, depending on the fracture and location.
  • Key Features:
    • Persistent pain
    • Impaired function
    • No or minimal fracture displacement
    • Healing process visible on imaging, just slower than usual
  • In this case the patient had a fracture 6 months ago, still has pain and functional limitation, and no major displacement—this fits delayed union.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophic Non-union:

  • A type of non-healing fracture where there is no biological activity at the fracture site, leading to bone resorption and narrowed fracture ends.
  • The x-ray appearance is Tapered or rounded bone ends with no callus formation.
  • Clinical Clues:
    • Usually occurs in older patients or with poor blood supply
    • Often associated with infection, severe trauma, or improper immobilization
    • Bone ends may appear "dead" on imaging
  • As there is no mention of bony resorption, dead bone, or failed healing—only delayed progress.

 

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Non-union:

  • A non-healing fracture characterized by excess callus formation, suggesting the bone is biologically active but mechanically unstable (e.g., poor fixation or movement at the site).
  • The x-ray appearance is large callus formation with visible fracture line.
  • Clinical Clues:
    • Typically associated with inadequate immobilization (e.g., loose cast or hardware failure)
    • "Elephant foot" appearance on radiographs
  • There is no evidence of excess callus or mechanical instability described.

 

Option D. Pseudarthrosis:

  • Literally means “false joint”—a chronic non-union where the fracture ends develop a capsule and synovial-like fluid, mimicking a joint.
  • It occurs after long-standing non-union (often >9 months to 1 year).
  • The x-ray appearance consists of fracture line with sclerosis and sometimes motion at the site.
  • Clinical Clues:
    • Instability, often with a palpable movement at the fracture site
    • Visible "false joint" on imaging
  • The fracture is only 6 months old, and there’s no mention of movement or joint-like features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's symptoms of persistent pain and difficulty moving at 6 months post-fracture, without significant displacement, suggest that the bone is taking longer than usual to heal but hasn't necessarily reached a state of complete non-union or pseudarthrosis.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing dietary modification to improve gut health, inulin-type fructans are introduced as prebiotics. These compounds are resistant to digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract and reach the colon intact. Which of the following best explains this resistance to enzymatic digestion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta configuration of anomeric C2

 

  • Inulin-like fructans are a type of prebiotic fiber composed primarily of fructose units linked together by β(2→1) glycosidic bonds, starting from an initial glucose unit. 
  • The key reason they are not digested in the upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is due to the β-configuration of the anomeric carbon at C2.
  • Human digestive enzymes (e.g., amylases, sucrase, maltase) are specific to α-linkages, such as those found in starch and glycogen.
  • The β(2→1) bonds in inulin are not recognized or broken down by these enzymes, making them resistant to digestion until they reach the colon.
  • Once in the colon, they are fermented by commensal gut microbiota, leading to beneficial effects such as production of short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) and promotion of healthy bacterial growth.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Presence of alpha-glycosidic linkages: This is incorrect because inulin-like fructans do not contain α-osidic linkages. In fact, α-linkages are digestible by human enzymes. It is the β-linkage that confers resistance.

 

Option C. Low pH of the stomach: While the stomach acid (low pH) can denature some proteins and partially digest certain nutrients, it does not significantly affect the β(2→1) glycosidic bonds in inulin. Therefore, acid environment is not the reason for inulin's resistance.

 

Option D. Beta configuration of anomeric C1: Cellulose is digested due to beta configuration at anomeric C1 not inulin.

 

Educational objective: 

 

The β-configuration at the anomeric C2 in inulin-type fructans makes them resistant to digestion by human enzymes, allowing them to act as prebiotics that reach the colon intact and support gut microbiota fermentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with decompensated cirrhosis and recurrent large-volume paracenteses has normal kidney function and sodium. He is not on diuretics. Which intervention is not appropriate in initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Restrict fluid intake to <2 L/day

 

  • Fluid restriction is not needed unless serum sodium is <125–128 mmol/L. 
  • Sodium restriction and diuretics (spironolactone ± furosemide) are first line. Furosemide is used with spironolactone to prevent hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

Option A. Start furosemide 40 mg daily: Appropriate diuretic add-on.
 

Option C Begin sodium restriction to <2 g/day: Essential dietary intervention.
 

Option D. Start spironolactone 100 mg daily: First-line diuretic for ascites.

 

Educational Objective:


Fluid restriction in cirrhotic ascites is only required in significant hyponatremia, sodium restriction and spironolactone form the treatment backbone.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of progressively worsening nasal obstruction and frequent episodes of epistaxis for the past 3 months. He also reports a recent change in facial contour with mild right cheek swelling. On anterior rhinoscopy, a reddish mass is seen in the nasal cavity. Contrast-enhanced CT reveals a large enhancing mass extending from the nasopharynx into the right maxillary sinus, with further involvement of the infratemporal fossa and cheek. There is clear evidence of posterior extension through the pterygomaxillary fissure into the temporal fossa. What is the stage of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma in this patient based on the Radkowski classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage IIC

 

  • According to the Radkowski classification of JNA:
    • Stage IIC indicates extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fissure.
    • In this case, the mass extends into the cheek and temporal fossa through the pterygomaxillary fissure—fulfilling criteria for Stage IIC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IIA: Involves minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minor involvement of the pterygopalatine fossa — less extensive than the findings in this case.

 

Option B. Stage IIB: Includes full occupation of the pterygopalatine fossa with the Holman-Miller sign and may have erosion of orbital bones, but no mention of extension into the cheek or temporal fossa.

 

Option D. Stage IIIA: Characterized by erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial extension. This is more advanced than current findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radkowski Staging of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who recently returned from an endemic region of Bihar, India, presents with fever, significant weight loss, massive splenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is confirmed by bone marrow aspirate showing amastigotes. As part of his management, the attending physician reviews pharmacologic options for treating this parasitic infection. Which of the following drugs is not effective in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spiramycin

 

  • Spiramycin is a macrolide antibiotic primarily used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, especially in pregnant women, and has no role in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis. 
  • It does not act against Leishmania donovani, the causative organism of kala-azar, and is therefore not included in the therapeutic arsenal for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphotericin B: A potent antifungal with broad-spectrum activity, liposomal amphotericin B is highly effective against visceral leishmaniasis and is often used in refractory or severe cases, particularly in HIV co-infected individuals.

 

Option C. Paromomycin: An aminoglycoside antibiotic that also has antileishmanial activity, particularly used in resource-limited settings due to its affordability. It is effective in combination therapy for visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Sodium stibogluconate: This drug, belonging to the class of pentavalent antimonials, has historically served as the first-line therapy for leishmaniasis in many regions. However, the emergence of drug resistance, particularly in areas such as Bihar, India, has significantly reduced its effectiveness and utility. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spiramycin is not used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, whereas amphotericin B, paromomycin, and pentavalent antimonials are established therapeutic agents for this parasitic infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who lost her husband 1 month ago says, “This can't be real; he was just here yesterday. I keep thinking he will walk through that door.” Which stage of grief is she most likely experiencing according to the Kübler-Ross model?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denial

 

  • The woman’s statement reflects difficulty accepting the reality of her husband's death. 
  • Believing “he will walk through that door” and saying “this can’t be real” are classic features of the denial stage of grief. 
  • Denial is often the first reaction in the Kübler-Ross model, serving as a psychological defense mechanism that buffers the immediate shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acceptance: Characterized by coming to terms with the loss and moving forward — not evident in her words.

 

Option B. Depression: Marked by overwhelming sadness, hopelessness, and withdrawal — she is still struggling with accepting the loss.

 

Option D. Bargaining: Involves thinking in “what if” or “if only” terms (e.g., “If I had taken him to the doctor sooner...”) not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Kübler-Ross model outlines five stages of grief: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance (Mnemonic: DABDA). 
  • Denial is an initial coping mechanism that helps individuals gradually process emotional trauma.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old female arrives for her annual physical examination. She complains of itching in her hands, headache and vertigo. A routine complete blood count (CBC) reveals:

 

RBCs: 8.2 million/μl,

 

WBCs: 37,000/μl, 

 

Platelets: 640,000/μl, 

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) levels: Lower than normal

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polycythemia vera

 

  • This patient presents with symptoms (pruritus, headache, vertigo) and lab findings consistent with polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by:
    • Elevated RBC, WBC, and platelets
    • Low erythropoietin (EPO) due to negative feedback from excessive RBCs
    • Pruritus after hot showers due to histamine release from basophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thrombocytopenia: Platelets are elevated, not low.

 

Option B. Relative polycythemia: Due to hemoconcentration (e.g., dehydration) but no actual increase in cell lines and EPO is normal.

 

Option C. Secondary polycythemia: Caused by hypoxia (e.g., lung disease, high altitude) or tumors → EPO would be elevated, not low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polycythemia vera is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells leading to increased production of all three cell lines (RBCs, WBCs, platelets), often driven by a JAK2 mutation. 
  • It is distinguished from secondary causes by low EPO and the presence of symptoms like pruritus, thrombosis, and hyperviscosity-related headaches or dizziness.

questions.text: The image given below is characteristic of which of the following nerve blocks?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supraclavicular block

 

  • The brachial plexus (BP) is seen lateral and superior to the subclavian artery (SA), resting on the first rib, just above the pleura—this sonographic landmark is classic for the supraclavicular approach (giving a “bunch of grapes” appearance).
  • It provides dense anesthesia for the upper limb (especially below the shoulder).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interscalene block: Performed at the root/trunk level between anterior and middle scalene muscles—nerves are more cephalad and dispersed.

 

 

Option C. Infraclavicular block: Plexus cords surround the axillary artery below the clavicle, much deeper and medial.

 

 

Option D. Axillary block: Done at terminal branches in the axilla; nerves surround the axillary artery in a circular pattern.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The supraclavicular block is referred to as the "spinal of the arm" due to its rapid onset and complete anesthesia for the upper extremity. 
  • It requires careful needle placement to avoid pneumothorax due to proximity to the pleura.

questions.text: A 23-year-old postpartum woman develops visual disturbances, headache, and then unresponsiveness. BP is 70/30 mmHg, HR 140/min. Labs show glucose 48 mg/dL, hematocrit is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrocortisone

 

  • Sheehan syndrome is postpartum pituitary infarction which can sometimes cause secondary adrenal insufficiency (but very rare). 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement (IV hydrocortisone) is lifesaving. 
  • Thyroxine may be required but should only be initiated after cortisol levels are stabilized to avoid adrenal crisis.

 

Other Options:

Option B. Thyroxine: Not first-line in acute adrenal insufficiency.
 

Option C. Piperacillin-tazobactam: No evidence of sepsis.
 

Option D. Packed red Blood transfusion: Hematocrit is normal; shock is not due to hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:


In postpartum pituitary failure, IV steroids should be administered urgently to treat life-threatening cortisol deficiency.

choices.text: The immune response targets the streptococcal toxins, leading to a systemic inflammatory response
The M protein of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) induces the production of antibodies that cross-react with human tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage
The body mounts a T-cell-mediated response against the streptococcal capsule, causing tissue necrosis
The bacteria directly invade the heart and joints, leading to acute inflammation

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a recent history of sore throat and fever. Two weeks after the infection resolves, he develops painful swollen joints, a migratory rash, and painless nodules on his skin. The child is diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The M protein of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) induces the production of antibodies that cross-react with human tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.

 

  • Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) is a complication of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) throat infection that occurs 2-4 weeks after the infection. 
  • It is caused by an immune-mediated reaction, where antibodies produced against the M protein of GAS cross-react with similar molecular structures(glycoproteins) in human tissues, particularly in the heart valves, joints, and skin.
  • This cross-reaction triggers an inflammatory response, which results in the symptoms of ARF such as migratory polyarthritis, pancarditis, and erythema marginatum. 
  • This process is a classic example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. The immune response targets the streptococcal toxins, leading to a systemic inflammatory response: Incorrect. Although the immune system reacts to the M protein of the bacteria, ARF is not primarily caused by a response to streptococcal toxins. It is the antibody cross-reactivity with human tissues that leads to inflammation, not the toxins.

 

Option C. The body mounts a T-cell-mediated response against the streptococcal capsule, causing tissue necrosis: Incorrect. The immune response in ARF is primarily antibody-mediated (type II hypersensitivity), not T-cell-mediated. It is not related to capsular antigens, and necrosis is not the primary mechanism.

 

Option D. The bacteria directly invade the heart and joints, leading to acute inflammation: Incorrect. The pathology of ARF is not due to direct bacterial invasion of tissues. The inflammation is due to the immune response to the bacterial antigens, not the presence of the bacteria themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever is characterized by an immune response against the M protein of Group A Streptococcus, leading to the production of antibodies that cross-react with human tissues and cause inflammation.

choices.text: Zavegepant - CGRP receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks
Pembrolizumab – Immune check point inhibitor used for endometrial carcinoma
Ertugliflozin – SGLT2 inhibitor for treatment of diabetes mellitus
Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match with respect to the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ivabradine – Funny current blocker for treatment of decreased visual acuity.

 

  • Ivabradine is indeed a "funny" current (If) blocker, but it is a bradycardiac agent, used for the treatment of certain types of chronic heart failure and angina pectoris (chest pain), but it causes decrease in visual acuity, so cannot used for the patient with vision problem.
  • Therefore, option D is not a correct match concerning the mechanism of action and clinical use of the given drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zavegepant - CGRP receptor antagonist used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks: This is a correct match. Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist. It is used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. CGRP is a neuropeptide that plays a role in the pathophysiology of migraines, and antagonists like Zavegepant block its activity, thereby alleviating symptoms.

 

Option B. Pembrolizumab – Immune check point inhibitor used for endometrial carcinoma: This is also a correct match. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets the PD-1 receptor. It is used for a variety of cancers, including endometrial carcinoma, especially in cases that are MSI-H or dMMR (microsatellite instability-high or mismatch repair deficient).

 

Option C. Ertugliflozin – SGLT2 inhibitor for treatment of diabetes mellitus: This is another correct match. Ertugliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, which is used to manage blood sugar levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, thereby leading to the excretion of glucose in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivabradine is a funny current (If) blocker used for chronic heart failure and angina, not for treating visual disorders like decreased visual acuity.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm
Weakness of flexion at the shoulder joint
Inability to extend the arm at shoulder joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with acute onset pain and swelling in the right shoulder for the past 3 days. The pain is continuous, moderate to severe in intensity, and worsens with movement. He also complains of difficulty abducting the right arm. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness in the deltoid region with marked limitation in shoulder abduction. MRI reveals pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with abscess formation. The patient also gives a history of intramuscular injection of iron in the right deltoid region two weeks earlier. Which of the following is not a likely complication in this case if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

 

  • The deltoid muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve, which also gives off the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm responsible for sensory supply to the upper lateral aspect of the arm. Therefore:
    • Inability to abduct the arm (deltoid function) is a valid complication.
    • Weakness in flexion or extension (due to anterior and posterior fibers of deltoid) are possible.
    • However, loss of sensation in the lower lateral aspect of the arm is not expected, as that area is not innervated by the axillary nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The axillary nerve supplies the deltoid muscle (abduction, flexion, extension of shoulder) and provides sensation to the upper lateral arm. 
  • Injury to this nerve causes motor deficits and sensory loss over upper lateral arm, but not the lower lateral aspect.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor 

 

  • In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, a doctor's signature is not needed.
  • The signature of the doctor is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is performed for which of these indications?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenocarcinoma of the stomach

 

  • Radical gastrectomy is primarily performed as a curative treatment for gastric adenocarcinoma, aiming for complete tumor resection with lymph node dissection.
  • Adenocarcinoma of the stomach: 
    • Radical gastrectomy is the standard treatment for localized gastric adenocarcinoma, especially in advanced cases requiring extensive lymph node removal.
    • The procedure involves subtotal or total gastrectomy, along with lymphadenectomy to improve survival rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GIST of the stomach: Incorrect.

 

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are typically managed with segmental resection rather than radical gastrectomy.
  • Radical gastrectomy is not necessary unless the GIST is very large or infiltrating extensively.

 

Option C. Intractable peptic ulcer disease: Incorrect.

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease is usually treated with medical therapy (PPIs, eradication of H. pylori) or limited surgical procedures like vagotomy.
  • Radical gastrectomy is not performed for ulcers, unless complicated by malignancy or non-healing perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical gastrectomy is primarily performed for gastric adenocarcinoma to achieve tumor resection and improve survival by removing the stomach and nearby lymph nodes. It is not typically indicated for GISTs or peptic ulcer disease, unless there are complications like malignancy or extensive infiltration.

questions.text:
Match the position with its use: 

 

 

  1. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy 
  2. Shoulder surgery
  3. Shifting unconscious patients 
  4. Robotic prostatectomy
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

 1→ C. Recovery Position → Shifting unconscious patients:

 

  • This lateral recumbent position is used for unconscious patients to maintain a clear airway and reduce the risk of aspiration. 
  • It’s commonly used during first aid or postictal recovery (after seizures).

 

2 → A. Reverse Trendelenburg Position → Laparoscopic cholecystectomy:

 

  • In this position, the head is elevated higher than the feet. 
  • It helps displace abdominal contents caudally, providing better visualization of upper abdominal organs such as the gallbladder. Commonly used in laparoscopic upper GI surgeries.

 

3→ D. Steep Trendelenburg Position → Robotic prostatectomy:

 

  • Here, the patient’s head is lower than the pelvis. 
  • This improves pelvic organ exposure and is essential in robotic pelvic surgeries such as prostatectomy and gynecologic procedures.

 

4→ B. Beach Chair Position → Shoulder surgery:

 

  • The patient is positioned in a semi-upright seated position. 
  • This allows easy access to the shoulder joint and is frequently used in arthroscopic and open shoulder surgeries.
  • It is also used in neurosurgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Recovery position: Recovery position is used for unconscious patients to prevent aspiration and maintain airway.
  2. Reverse Trendelenburg: Reverse Trendelenburg helps in laparoscopic cholecystectomy by improving view of upper abdomen.
  3. Steep Trendelenburg: Steep Trendelenburg is ideal for robotic pelvic surgeries like prostatectomy due to better pelvic access.
  4. Beach chair position: Beach chair position is commonly used for shoulder surgeries as it provides optimal joint exposure.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a 10-year history of schizophrenia is brought to the emergency department by police after creating a disturbance at a shopping mall. She was agitated and screaming at several different shoppers, accusing them all of being her ex-husband who was "disguising himself" to follow her. She insists that although these people look completely different from one another, they are all the same person (her ex-husband) who keeps changing his appearance to spy on her. Her medical records show she has been non-compliant with risperidone for the past 3 months. Which syndrome best describes this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
