Ans. B) Frégoli syndrome

 

  • This patient is exhibiting Frégoli syndrome, a rare delusional misidentification syndrome in which the person believes that different people are actually a single person who changes appearances or is in disguise. 
  • In this case, the patient believes that multiple different-looking individuals at the mall are all actually her ex-husband in disguise. 
  • This syndrome is named after the Italian actor Leopoldo Frégoli who was known for his ability to make quick changes of appearance during his performances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capgras syndrome: Capgras syndrome is incorrect. In Capgras syndrome, patients believe that familiar persons have been replaced by identical-looking impostors. The mnemonic for Capgras is "Close Person Got Replaced by a Stranger." This patient instead believes different-looking strangers are the same person (her ex-husband).

 

Option C. Cotard syndrome: Cotard syndrome is incorrect. Cotard syndrome involves nihilistic delusions about oneself or parts of oneself, like believing one is dead or that parts of one's body are missing or rotting. The patient shows no such beliefs.

 

Option D. De Clerambault syndrome: De Clerambault syndrome is incorrect. De Clerambault syndrome, also known as erotomania, is a delusional disorder in which a person believes that another person, usually of higher social status, is in love with them. This patient shows no erotomanic delusions but rather persecutory delusions involving her ex-husband.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frégoli syndrome is characterized by the delusion that a persecutor (often associated with paranoid schizophrenia) is disguising themselves as different people, representing the opposite phenomenon to Capgras syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling, and rash. The rash appears as erythematous, scaly plaques over the cheeks and buttocks. Parents report that symptoms flare up periodically and are often associated with fever. On physical examination, there is synovitis in multiple joints and uveitis on eye exam. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the NOD2 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blau Syndrome

 

The classic triad in this child—arthritis, skin rash, and uveitis—along with the NOD2 gene mutation strongly suggests Blau Syndrome, a rare autoinflammatory disorder with granulomatous inflammation of the skin, joints, and eyes.

 

  • Mnemonic: "BLAU = Bones, Lids, Autoimmune, Unusual gene"
    • B-Bones → Arthritis (boggy, symmetric)
    • L-Lids → Uveitis (can lead to blindness)
    • A-Autoimmune granulomas → Skin rash, systemic features
    • U-Uncommon gene → NOD2/ CARD15

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):  Incorrect. While JIA can present with arthritis and occasionally uveitis, the scaly rash and genetic NOD2 mutation do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): Incorrect. SLE may present with joint pain, rash, and systemic symptoms, but it usually affects older children/adolescents, and NOD2 mutation is not associated. Uveitis is also not characteristic. These patients will have butterfly malar rash on cheeks and not on buttocks.

 

Option D. Kawasaki Disease: Incorrect. Kawasaki presents with fever, conjunctival injection, rash, and mucosal involvement, but not chronic arthritis or uveitis, and is not linked to NOD2 mutation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought with altered mental status and fatigue. His pulse is regular, but alternate Korotkoff sounds are heard during BP measurement, unrelated to respiration. His arterial pressure tracings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe left ventricular dysfunction

 

  • Pulsus alternans is defined as alternating strong and weak pulses in a regular rhythm, commonly due to advanced left ventricular systolic dysfunction. 
  • It is not dependent on respiration and reflects impaired calcium handling and contractility.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: Associated with Kussmaul sign, not pulsus alternans.

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Associated with pulsus paradoxus, may cause shock or RV strain but not this pulse pattern.

 

Option C. Cardiac tamponade: Associated with electrical alternans in the ECG, not pulsus alternans.

 

Educational Objective:


Pulsus alternans is a bedside clue to advanced LV dysfunction and should prompt urgent heart failure evaluation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a BMI of 37 kg/m² and no history of diabetes is being evaluated for pharmacologic therapy for obesity. Despite structured dietary changes and physical activity for the past 6 months, she has only achieved 2% weight loss. She now seeks medical treatment to maximize further reduction. Among the FDA-approved options, which of the following medications has demonstrated the greatest average weight loss in clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tirzepatide

 

  • Tirzepatide is a dual GIP (glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide) and GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) receptor agonist. 
  • In clinical trials, it has shown superior weight reduction compared to other anti-obesity agents. 
  • Average weight loss with tirzepatide has reached over 20% of baseline body weight, depending on the dose and trial duration, making it the most effective currently approved anti-obesity medication.
  • Its dual mechanism enhances insulin secretion, suppresses appetite, delays gastric emptying, and promotes significant satiety — all of which contribute to maximum weight loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semaglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist, semaglutide is highly effective, inducing ~15% weight loss at the approved obesity dose (2.4 mg weekly). However, it is less effective than tirzepatide, which combines GLP-1 and GIP effects.

 

Option C. Orlistat: A gastrointestinal lipase inhibitor, orlistat prevents dietary fat absorption. It leads to modest weight loss (~5–7%) and is associated with GI side effects like oily stools, which limit its tolerability. It is far less effective than GLP-1 or dual agonists.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Also, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, approved for weight loss at 3.0 mg daily, liraglutide achieves around 8–10% weight loss on average — less than semaglutide and tirzepatide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tirzepatide, a dual GIP and GLP-1 receptor agonist, produces the greatest average weight loss among currently approved anti-obesity drugs.

choices.text: Item 7 enhances the scale's internal consistency and should be retained
Item 7 may not align well with the overall construct and could be considered for removal
The increase in alpha is negligible; no action is needed regarding item 7
Item 7 is essential for maintaining the scale's validity

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating the reliability of a newly developed 10-item self-report scale intended to measure depressive symptoms in a college population. Upon running an internal consistency analysis, she finds that the Cronbach’s alpha for the entire scale is 0.78. However, when item 7 is removed, the Cronbach’s alpha increases to 0.82. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this finding regarding item 7?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Item 7 may not align well with the overall construct and could be considered for removal.

 

  • Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency, or how well the items in a scale correlate with each other to measure the same underlying construct (e.g., depression). A higher alpha suggests that the scale items are more homogeneous and consistently reflect the target trait.
  • If the removal of an item results in a notable increase in Cronbach’s alpha, it suggests that the item was not contributing positively to the overall consistency of the scale. It may be measuring a different concept, be ambiguous, or poorly worded, and thus diluting the reliability of the scale.
  • In this scenario, removing item 7 raises alpha from 0.78 to 0.82—a meaningful improvement—indicating that item 7 likely does not align well with the intended construct of depression. The researcher should review or consider removing the item to improve the scale’s overall internal consistency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Item 7 enhances the scale's internal consistency and should be retained: Incorrect. If item 7 truly enhanced internal consistency, removing it would cause a drop in alpha—not an increase.

 

Option C. The increase in alpha is negligible; no action is needed regarding item 7: Incorrect. An increase from 0.78 to 0.82 is meaningful, especially when the original alpha was borderline. This justifies further evaluation of item 7.

 

Option D. Item 7 is essential for maintaining the scale's validity: Incorrect. While validity is important, this finding speaks to reliability (internal consistency), not whether the item is essential for validity. Moreover, poor internal consistency could actually harm the scale's validity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If removing an item increases Cronbach’s alpha, it suggests the item is not internally consistent with the other items and may be misaligned with the overall construct. 
  • Such items should be carefully reviewed or revised to improve scale reliability.

choices.text: To determine the virus strain or serotype
To qualitatively assess cytopathic effect of virus
To confirm the presence of the virus in a clinical sample
To quantify the number of infectious viral particles

questions.text: In a virology research lab, a scientist is working on measuring the infectivity of a newly isolated virus. A plaque assay is performed using a monolayer of host cells. Each clear zone that appears corresponds to viral lysis of host cells. What is the primary purpose of performing this plaque assay?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To quantify the number of infectious viral particles

 

  • The plaque assay is a quantitative virological technique used to measure the infectivity titer of a virus (i.e., how many infectious virions are present in a given volume)
  • Results are expressed in plaque-forming units (PFU)/mL
  • Each plaque corresponds to one infectious virus particle that has infected a cell, replicated, and caused cytolysis, leading to a clear zone
  • This assay helps determine the exact concentration of infectious virus, making it a quantitative assay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine the virus strain or serotype: Incorrect. Strain or serotype determination requires genotyping or serologic assays, not plaque assays.

 

Option B. To qualitatively assess cytopathic effect of virus: Incorrect. Although plaques result from cytopathic effects, the assay’s primary use is quantitative, not merely qualitative.

 

Option C. To confirm the presence of the virus in a clinical sample: Incorrect. Other assays such as PCR or antigen detection are better suited for diagnosis. Plaque assay is typically used in research and vaccine development settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plaque assays are used to quantify the number of infectious virus particles in a sample, expressed as plaque-forming units per milliliter (PFU/mL).

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is true, but Reason is false
Assertion is false, but Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion and Reason Question: 

 

Assertion (A): The Paul-Bunnell test is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

 

Reason (R): This test detects heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum that agglutinate sheep red blood cells.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion.

 

  • The Paul-Bunnell test is a heterophile agglutination test used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, a disease caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • It detects heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum, which are IgM antibodies that cross-react with antigens on sheep red blood cells.
  • The agglutination of sheep RBCs indicates the presence of these cross-reactive antibodies, confirming recent EBV infection.
  • Thus, the reason correctly explains the assertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test detects heterophile IgM antibodies in infectious mononucleosis using sheep RBCs, making it a diagnostic tool for EBV infection.

choices.text: Secondary arrest after progression of labor
Prolonged latent phase/primary arrest of labor

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida in active labor is being monitored for cervical dilatation over time. The progression is as depicted in the graph provided. Based on this pattern, which of the following diagnoses is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary arrest after progression of labor

 

  • Secondary arrest refers to a cessation of cervical dilation after a previously normal progression during the active phase of labor. 
  • The partograph demonstrates an initial normal labor progression followed by a plateau, indicative of secondary arrest.  
  • This may occur due to cephalopelvic disproportion, inadequate uterine contractions, or fetal malposition. Prompt identification and management are essential to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prolonged active phase of labor: Characterized by a slower-than-expected rate of cervical dilation during the active phase. However, in this case, there is a clear cessation rather than just a slowing.

 

Option C. Prolonged latent phase/primary arrest of labor: Involves a failure to progress from the latent phase to the active phase of labor. This condition occurs before reaching 6 cm of dilation, which is inconsistent with the given case.

 

Option D. Normal labor in a primigravida: Normal labor typically progresses without a prolonged plateau in cervical dilation, as seen in the mean labor curve. The observed plateau clearly deviates from normal progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary arrest of labor is defined as a cessation of cervical dilation after initially normal progression during the active phase. 
  • Accurate diagnosis and timely intervention are critical to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A phenotypically female child presents with ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly. On examination, she is found to have hypertension. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11β-hydroxylase

 

The child is phenotypically female but presents with ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly, suggesting excess androgen exposure in utero. This is a clue toward a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

 

The additional clue is the presence of hypertension, which is critical for identifying the correct enzyme deficiency.

 

In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, there is impaired conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) to corticosterone in the adrenal cortex. This leads to:

 

  • Excess DOC, a potent mineralocorticoid, resulting in hypertension
  • Excess androgen production, causing virilization in genotypic females (leading to ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly)

 

Hence, this is the most likely cause of the phenotype described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21-hydroxylase: This is the most common form of CAH and also causes virilization in females due to excess androgens. However, it leads to salt-wasting (hypotension) because of aldosterone deficiency, not hypertension. This directly contradicts the clue of hypertension in the question.

 

Option B. 17,20-lyase: Deficiency here would impair sex steroid synthesis, leading to undervirilization, not virilization. So, it would not cause clitoromegaly or ambiguous genitalia in a female. Hypertension is also not a feature of this defect.

 

Option D. 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase: Deficiency would impair the synthesis of all steroids (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens), leading to hypotension and lack of androgen effects, not clitoromegaly. This contradicts both main findings in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a phenotypic female presenting with ambiguous genitalia, clitoromegaly, and hypertension, suspect 11β-hydroxylase deficiency.”

 

Note: HTN in CAH is due to – 11β hydroxylase and 17α hydroxylase deficiency

choices.text: Only A, B and E are true
Only A, B and D are true
Only B, C and E are true

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding pemphigus vulgaris are true? 

 

  1. Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disorder caused by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, leading to acantholysis.
  2. The characteristic clinical features include flaccid blisters and painful erosions.
  3. Rituximab, an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, is considered first-line treatment for mild disease.
  4. Systemic corticosteroids combined with steroid-sparing agents like azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil are standard first-line therapy.
  5. Methotrexate is preferred in severe refractory cases.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only A, B, and D are true

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement A. Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disorder caused by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, leading to acantholysis: True. Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease caused by IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, which are important components of desmosomes involved in cell-to-cell adhesion. The loss of adhesion between keratinocytes is known as acantholysis, and it is a hallmark histopathological finding in this condition.

 

Statement B. The characteristic clinical features include flaccid blisters and painful erosions: True. The clinical presentation of pemphigus vulgaris typically includes flaccid intraepidermal blisters that rupture easily, leaving behind painful erosions on the skin and mucous membranes. These erosions are a key clinical clue, especially when oral mucosal involvement is present.

 

Statement D. Systemic corticosteroids combined with steroid-sparing agents like azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil are standard first-line therapy: True. The first-line treatment for pemphigus vulgaris consists of systemic corticosteroids in combination with steroid-sparing immunosuppressive agents such as azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil. This approach helps control disease activity while minimizing long-term corticosteroid side effects.

 

Incorrect Statements:
 

Statement C. Rituximab, an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, is considered first-line treatment for mild disease: False. While rituximab, an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, is highly effective and often used in moderate to severe or refractory cases, it is not the first-line treatment for mild disease. Instead, it is reserved for more severe or steroid-resistant cases due to its immunosuppressive profile and cost.

 

Statement E. Methotrexate is preferred in severe refractory cases: False. Methotrexate is a steroid-sparing agent sometimes used in pemphigus vulgaris. It is generally not preferred in severe refractory cases. More potent immunosuppressants like rituximab or cyclophosphamide are typically considered in such situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disorder characterized by IgG-mediated acantholysis, leading to flaccid blisters and erosions. 
  • First-line treatment includes systemic corticosteroids with immunosuppressive agents, while rituximab is reserved for severe or refractory cases.
  • Methotrexate is generally used in patients of psoriasis. In pemphigus vulgaris, it may be used sometimes, but generally not preferred.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman presents at 17 weeks gestation and is being counseled for a diagnostic prenatal procedure as part of her genetic screening. The image below represents the procedure. Which of the following statements regarding this procedure are true?

 

 

  1. It is most appropriately performed between 15–20 weeks of gestation for prenatal genetic diagnosis
  2. It can be used to diagnose fetal infections and assess Rh alloimmunization severity
  3. Lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio and phosphatidylglycerol in fluid assess fetal lung maturity
  4. The risk of procedure-related fetal loss is approximately 5%
  5. Vaginal spotting and amniotic fluid leakage are potential complications
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B, C, E

 

The test depicted is amniocentesis.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement A. It is most appropriately performed between 15–20 weeks of gestation for prenatal genetic diagnosis: True. Amniocentesis is typically performed between 15–20 weeks for prenatal diagnosis of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Statement B. It can be used to diagnose fetal infections and assess Rh alloimmunization severity: True. It helps detect congenital infections and assess bilirubin levels in Rh isoimmunization.

 

Statement C. Lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio and phosphatidylglycerol in fluid assess fetal lung maturity: True. Later in pregnancy, it is used to assess fetal lung maturity via L/S ratio and phosphatidylglycerol presence.

 

Statement E. Vaginal spotting and amniotic fluid leakage are potential complications: True. Vaginal spotting and amniotic fluid leakage are recognized complications.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement D. The risk of procedure-related fetal loss is approximately 5%: False. The actual procedure-related loss rate is very low (~0.1–0.3%), not 5%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amniocentesis is the most commonly used prenatal diagnostic procedure. 
  • It is safe when done between 15–20 weeks for detecting fetal chromosomal abnormalities and congenital infections. 
  • It also serves as a tool for assessing Rh isoimmunization and fetal lung maturity. While generally safe, risks include minimal fetal loss, fluid leakage, and spotting.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with COPD and diabetes is admitted after a fall. She is found to be dehydrated, in pain, and has an irregularly irregular pulse. ECG tracing is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain control and IV hydration

 

  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is commonly seen in elderly patients with pulmonary disease, especially when hypoxia, pain, or dehydration is present. 
  • Treating underlying triggers or symptomatic treatment usually resolves the arrhythmia without the need for antiarrhythmics or cardioversion. 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adenosine 6 mg: Only effective for PSVT; not indicated for MAT.
 

Option B. Direct current Cardioversion: Ineffective in MAT, which lacks a reentrant circuit.
 

Option C. Metoprolol 5 mg IV: May worsen bronchospasm in COPD.

 

Educational Objective:


Initial MAT management focuses on correcting precipitating factor.

questions.text: A 42-year-old fisherman from Scandinavia presents with fatigue, glossitis, and paresthesias. Laboratory workup reveals macrocytic anemia, and serum levels show a marked deficiency of vitamin B12. Stool examination reveals ova consistent with a fish tapeworm infection. Which of the following helminths is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diphyllobothrium latum

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum, also known as the fish tapeworm, is the largest human tapeworm and is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater fish. It is most commonly found in regions like Scandinavia, Russia, and North America.
  • Key clinical feature: This parasite competes with the host for vitamin B12 in the ileum, leading to:
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
    • Megaloblastic (pernicious-like) anemia
    • Neurologic symptoms including paresthesia, ataxia, and glossitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hymenolepis nana: Also known as the dwarf tapeworm, it causes mild gastrointestinal symptoms, especially in children. It does not cause vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Option B. Taenia solium: The pork tapeworm causes intestinal taeniasis or neurocysticercosis when its larvae invade the CNS. It is not associated with megaloblastic anemia or B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: A roundworm causing intestinal obstruction, eosinophilia, and pulmonary symptoms (Löffler’s syndrome) during migration, but has no role in vitamin B12 metabolism or deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphyllobothrium latum causes vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia by competing for B12 absorption in the ileum, distinguishing it from other helminths.

choices.text: Patients who are resistant to sulfonylureas

questions.text: In which of the following groups of patients is metformin least likely to reduce blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-diabetic individuals

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide and first-line agent for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus, particularly in overweight or obese individuals. It reduces blood glucose by:
    • Inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis
    • Improving insulin sensitivity
    • Enhancing peripheral glucose uptake
  • However, in non-diabetic individuals, metformin does not lower blood glucose significantly because their baseline glucose levels and insulin sensitivity are within normal range. 
  • Thus, its glucose-lowering effect is minimal to negligible in those without insulin resistance or elevated hepatic glucose production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus: These patients typically benefit the most from metformin, which reduces both fasting and postprandial glucose levels.

 

Option B. Obese individuals with type 2 diabetes: Metformin is especially effective in obese diabetics due to its weight-neutral or mild weight-reducing effect and improvement in insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Patients who are resistant to sulfonylureas: Metformin acts via a different mechanism than sulfonylureas (which stimulate insulin secretion), so it may still work in patients who do not respond to sulfonylureas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin does not significantly lower blood glucose in non-diabetic individuals, as its primary effects depend on the presence of insulin resistance and elevated hepatic glucose production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy after receiving prophylactic antibiotics. What is the expected rate of surgical site infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3% 

 

  • After the administration of prophylactic antibiotics, the anticipated rate of surgical site infection in a patient with a clean-contaminated wound, such as lap. cholecystectomy is 3%.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding esophageal varices is/are correct? 

 

  1. Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins that most commonly occur in the upper third of the esophagus.
  2. They are a consequence of portal hypertension, typically due to cirrhosis.
  3. The distal esophageal vein normally drains into the portal circulation via the left gastric vein.
  4. In portal hypertension, backflow through the left gastric vein leads to dilation of submucosal veins in the esophagus.
  5. Esophageal varices may remain asymptomatic but carry a risk of life-threatening rupture.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4 and 5

 

Statement 2. They are a consequence of portal hypertension, typically due to cirrhosis: This statement is correct. Esophageal varices are most often a result of portal hypertension, which typically occurs due to cirrhosis. Cirrhosis leads to increased pressure in the portal vein, and blood is rerouted to smaller veins, including those in the esophagus, causing them to dilate.

 

Statement 3. The distal esophageal vein normally drains into the portal circulation via the left gastric vein: This statement is correct. The distal esophageal vein drains into the left gastric vein, which is a branch of the portal vein. This connection is critical in the pathophysiology of portal hypertension leading to varices.

 

Statement 4. In portal hypertension, backflow through the left gastric vein leads to dilation of submucosal veins in the esophagus: This statement is correct. In portal hypertension, increased pressure in the portal system causes backflow into the left gastric vein, which then leads to the dilation of submucosal veins in the esophagus, resulting in varices.

 

Statement 5. Esophageal varices may remain asymptomatic but carry a risk of life-threatening rupture: This statement is correct. Esophageal varices often remain asymptomatic unless they rupture. When rupture occurs, it can lead to massive gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening. This is a key feature of esophageal varices.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 1. Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins that most commonly occur in the upper third of the esophagus: This statement is incorrect. Esophageal varices most commonly occur in the lower third of the esophagus, not the upper third. this is because the lower esophagus is primarily drained by the left gastric vein, which is part of the portal venous system. In contrast, the upper esophagus is drained by veins that do not participate in the portal venous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins primarily in the lower esophagus, caused by portal hypertension, typically due to cirrhosis. 
  • They result from backflow through the left gastric vein and carry a risk of life-threatening rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) First part of the duodenum

 

  • The epiploic (omental) foramen is an anatomical passage that connects the greater and lesser sacs of the peritoneal cavity. It is clinically significant due to its proximity to major vascular structures and its involvement in internal hernias.
  • Posterior boundary includes:
    • Suprarenal gland (right)
    • Inferior vena cava (IVC)
    • T12 vertebra
  • Anterior boundary:
    • Lesser omentum containing the portal triad (hepatic artery, portal vein, bile duct)
  • Superior boundary:
    • Caudate process of liver
  • Inferior boundary:
    • First part of the duodenum
    • Horizontal part of hepatic artery
  • Thus, while the first part of the duodenum is an inferior boundary, it is not part of the posterior boundary, making Option D the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epiploic (Omental) Foramen – Boundaries

choices.text: ALT is abundant in cardiac muscle and red cells
AST elevation is more specific for liver damage than ALT
AST and ALT >1000 IU/L occur in ischemic or toxin-induced injury
AST: ALT >3 is typical of acute viral hepatitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about liver transaminase patterns is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AST and ALT >1000 IU/L occur in ischemic or toxin-induced injury

 

  • Very high aminotransferase levels (>1000 IU/L) suggest severe hepatocellular injury, such as ischemic hepatitis or drug/toxin-induced injury. 
  • ALT is more liver-specific than AST. AST: ALT >2 is typical of alcoholic hepatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALT is abundant in cardiac muscle and red cells: ALT is primarily liver specific not cardiac muscle or red cells.

 

Option B. AST elevation is more specific for liver damage than ALT: AST is less specific due to presence in other tissues.

 

Option D. AST: ALT >3 is typical of acute viral hepatitis: AST: ALT >3 is not a feature of viral hepatitis. It should be <1

 

Educational Objective:


Markedly elevated AST and ALT suggest ischemic or toxic liver injury; ALT is more specific for liver than AST.

choices.text: The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence
Dr. Singh, because he must prove that his clinical decision was based on standard medical practice
The hospital, because it is the employer and responsible for the actions of its staff under vicarious liability
Shared between the patient's family and the hospital, as both need to provide evidence to support or refute the claim

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, Mr. Sharma without any relevant past medical history, visits Dr Singh in a hospital with abdominal discomfort. Dr. Singh makes a diagnosis of gastritis and prescribes antacids. Hours later, he suffers a heart attack and is hospitalized. His family sues Dr. Singh and the hospital for medical negligence, alleging failure to order cardiac tests. Who bears the onus of proof in this civil negligence case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.

 

  • In civil medical negligence cases, the burden (onus) of proof lies with the plaintiff—in this case, Mr. Sharma’s family—because they are the ones alleging negligence.
  • They must prove all three essential elements of medical negligence:
    • Duty of care existed (doctor-patient relationship),
    • There was a breach of that duty (i.e., standard care not followed),
    • That breach directly caused harm to the patient (causation and damage).
  • The doctor (defendant) does not need to prove innocence. Rather, once the plaintiff has presented evidence of negligence, the doctor may then present justifications or explain clinical reasoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dr. Singh, because he must prove that his clinical decision was based on standard medical practice: The doctor may defend his actions, but the initial burden lies on the complainant.

 

Option C. The hospital, because it is the employer and responsible for the actions of its staff under vicarious liability: While the hospital may be vicariously liable if negligence is proven, it does not bear the initial onus.

 

Option D. Shared between the patient's family and the hospital, as both need to provide evidence to support or refute the claim: The burden is not shared initially; it is solely on the plaintiff to prove negligence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In civil medical negligence cases, the burden of proof lies with the plaintiff, who must establish that: 

 

  • A duty of care existed, 
  • There was a breach of that duty, 
  • The breach caused the harm. The defendant (doctor or hospital) is not required to prove innocence unless rebutting the presented claim.

questions.text: A health economist is analyzing various global indices that measure development and deprivation. She notes that one specific indicator appears in both the Global Hunger Index (GHI) and the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MDPI). Which of the following indicators is common to both the Global Hunger Index (GHI) and the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MDPI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Child stunting

 

  • The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a composite indicator that reflects undernourishment and child undernutrition, particularly through:
    • Undernourishment (population-level food access)
    • Child stunting
    • Child wasting
    • Child mortality
  • The Multidimensional Poverty Index (MDPI) captures deprivations across three broad dimensions: Health, Education, and Standard of Living. Under the Health dimension, it includes:
    • Nutrition
    • Child mortality
  • Although the MDPI does not list “stunting” by name, the nutrition indicator often operationalizes child stunting (height-for-age) and/or underweight as proxies in household surveys to reflect chronic malnutrition.
  • Hence, child stunting is a shared indicator (direct in GHI, indirect in MDPI through “nutrition”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Literacy rate: Included in PQLI and indirectly in HDI but not used in GHI or MDPI.

 

Option C. Sanitation: Included under the standard of living domain of MDPI, but not part of GHI.

 

Option D. Life expectancy at birth: This is a key component of HDI, not GHI or MDPI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indices:

choices.text: Immune complex deposition causes necrotizing vasculitis and crescentic glomerulonephritis
Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina leads to aneurysm formation in medium-sized arteries
Lipid-laden macrophages accumulate in the vessel wall, leading to plaque formation and thrombosis
Proliferation of smooth muscle cells causes "onion-skin" appearance of arterioles, leading to end-organ ischemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset headache and blurred vision. His blood pressure is recorded at 240/130 mmHg. Laboratory studies show elevated serum creatinine. A renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following best describes the pathological process and its potential consequences?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferation of smooth muscle cells causes "onion-skin" appearance of arterioles, leading to end-organ ischemia.

 

  • This patient presents with features of malignant hypertension (BP > 180/120 mmHg) including headache, blurred vision, and acute renal impairment (elevated serum creatinine). 
  • The renal biopsy shows hyperplasia of smooth muscle in arterioles, creating a concentric, laminated "onion-skin" appearance, which is the hallmark of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis.
  • This vascular change is a consequence of malignant hypertension and results in thickening of the vessel wall, leading to reduced vessel caliber. As a result, end-organ ischemia develops — especially in the kidneys, where this can lead to fibrinoid necrosis and hemorrhage. When this occurs, the kidneys may develop a characteristic 'flea-bitten' appearance, and acute renal failure can result.
  • Thus, this option fully captures the process: smooth muscle hyperplasia → onion-skin appearance → vessel narrowing → end-organ ischemia, which may progress to fibrinoid necrosis and renal hemorrhage in malignant hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune complex deposition causes necrotizing vasculitis and crescentic glomerulonephritis: This describes a different pathological process, such as immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, seen in conditions like lupus nephritis or post-infectious GN. These involve immune complex deposition, necrotizing inflammation, and formation of crescents in glomeruli — not smooth muscle hyperplasia, not onion-skinning, and not associated with malignant hypertension.

 

Option B. Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina leads to aneurysm formation in medium-sized arteries: This option describes the pathogenesis of aneurysms, especially in vasculitides like polyarteritis nodosa or connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome, not hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. There is no mention of smooth muscle proliferation, onion-skinning, or flea-bitten kidneys in such settings.

 

Option C. Lipid-laden macrophages accumulate in the vessel wall, leading to plaque formation and thrombosis: This option refers to atherosclerosis, which involves intimal lipid accumulation, macrophages (foam cells), and plaque formation in large and medium arteries — not arterioles. It is not related to malignant hypertension, onion-skin lesions, or acute renal failure with a flea-bitten kidney appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis is a consequence of malignant hypertension, characterized by concentric smooth muscle hyperplasia in arterioles ("onion-skin" appearance), which leads to reduced vessel caliber, end-organ ischemia, and may result in acute renal failure with a characteristic flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of occasional alcohol consumption presented to the casualty with acute colicky abdominal pain, distention of the abdomen, and vomiting. On x-ray, the following was noticed. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CECT abdomen immediately

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of acute mechanical small bowel obstruction. The dilated air fluid levels in step-ladder pattern suggest a mechanical block.
  • Thus, CECT needs to be done immediately to identify the site and the status of the bowel ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum lipase: Serum lipase is done when suspecting acute pancreatitis, which is unlikely here.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: Exploratory laparotomy may be done depending on etiology of acute obstruction, which would require CECT to confirm prior.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen after 72 hours: It is done for assessing extent of necrosis in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of acute mechanical small bowel obstruction, CECT is required to assess site of obstruction and presence of ischemia.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is started on methotrexate as a first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD). Which of the following best describes the most important mechanism of methotrexate when used in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of AICAR transformylase

 

  • Although methotrexate is widely known for inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) in high doses (e.g., in cancer therapy), its anti-inflammatory effect in rheumatoid arthritis is primarily mediated through a different mechanism.
  • At low doses used for RA, methotrexate inhibits the enzyme AICAR transformylase (aminoimidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide transformylase), leading to accumulation of AICAR. AICAR then inhibits adenosine deaminase, resulting in increased extracellular adenosine, a potent anti-inflammatory molecule. 
  • This mechanism modulates immune response and reduces inflammation in joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase: This is the mechanism of leflunomide, another DMARD. It inhibits pyrimidine synthesis, which is distinct from methotrexate’s action in RA.

 

Option C. Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase enzyme: This is the primary mechanism in oncology, were methotrexate blocks folate metabolism and DNA synthesis. While this occurs at higher doses, it is not the dominant anti-inflammatory mechanism in RA therapy.

 

Option D. Activation of TNF-alpha: TNF-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine. Methotrexate and other DMARDs aim to suppress, not activate, TNF-alpha. This choice is the opposite of the drug’s intended immune modulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate exerts its anti-inflammatory effects in rheumatoid arthritis primarily through inhibition of AICAR transformylase, leading to increased adenosine levels and immune suppression.

choices.text: They are separated from adjacent segments by connective tissue septa
They are the largest subdivisions of a lobe
They are named according to the segmental bronchus supplying them

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bronchopulmonary segments is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They are not resectable

 

  • Bronchopulmonary segments are functionally and anatomically discrete units of the lung. Each segment is:
    • Supplied by its own segmental (tertiary) bronchus and artery
    • Drained by intersegmental pulmonary veins
    • Surrounded by connective tissue septa, which separate it from adjacent segments
    • Pyramid-shaped, with the apex directed toward the lung root and the base facing the pleural surface
    • Named based on the supplying segmental bronchus
  • Most importantly, they are independently resectable, meaning a surgeon can remove a diseased segment without affecting others. 
  • This makes them clinically important in segmental lung resections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A bronchopulmonary segment is the largest resectable unit of the lung, each supplied by its own segmental bronchus and artery, separated by connective tissue, and shaped like a pyramid. 
  • Because of these features, individual segments can be surgically removed in localized disease.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is true, but Reason is false
Assertion is false, but Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) is associated with Kaposi sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma, and Castleman disease.

 

Reason (R): T-cell leukemia is caused by Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1).
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion.

 

Assertion is true:

 

  • HHV-8 (Human herpesvirus-8) is a gamma herpesvirus linked to the development of:
    • Kaposi sarcoma, particularly in HIV/AIDS patients
    • Primary effusion lymphoma, a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
    • Multicentric Castleman disease, a lymphoproliferative disorder

 

Reason is also true:

 

  • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell leukemia/lymphoma virus type 1) is a retrovirus that causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL), an aggressive malignancy of CD4+ T cells.

 

However, the Reason does not explain the Assertion, as HTLV-1 and HHV-8 are unrelated viruses affecting different cell types and diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HHV-8 is associated with Kaposi sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma, and Castleman disease, while HTLV-1 causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, but they are distinct viruses with unrelated disease mechanisms.

choices.text: Phagocytosis is an example of endocytosis
Facilitated diffusion is when carrier proteins move substances against their chemical gradient
Aquaporins are ion channels selective for transporting water molecules

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding transport across cell membranes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facilitated diffusion is when carrier proteins move substances against their chemical gradient

 

  • Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process where substances move along (not against) their chemical or concentration gradient with the help of specific carrier or channel proteins. 
  • No ATP is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exocytosis is a Ca²⁺-dependent process: Correct. Exocytosis, such as neurotransmitter release, is a Ca²⁺-dependent process, where an increase in intracellular calcium triggers vesicle fusion with the plasma membrane.

 

Option B. Phagocytosis is an example of endocytosis: Correct. Phagocytosis is a type of endocytosis involving engulfment of large particles or microbes by the plasma membrane.

 

Option D. Aquaporins are ion channels selective for transporting water molecules: Correct. Aquaporins are specialized water channels, not ion channels, that selectively allow water molecules to pass through the membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Facilitated diffusion involves the passive movement of molecules down their concentration gradient with the help of membrane proteins. 
  • It is distinct from active transport, which requires energy (e.g., ATP) to move substances against their gradient.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. Blood cultures are pending, and sputum Gram stain reveals gram-positive cocci in clusters. Given the high suspicion of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia, the attending physician considers starting a broad-spectrum beta-lactam antibiotic with activity against MRSA. Which of the following agents would be the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftobiprole

 

  • Ceftobiprole is a fifth-generation cephalosporin with broad-spectrum activity, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae, along with gram-negative coverage, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 
  • It is approved in some regions (e.g., Europe) for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), excluding ventilator-associated pneumonia.
  • Unlike earlier-generation cephalosporins, ceftobiprole binds to PBP2a, the penicillin-binding protein responsible for methicillin resistance in MRSA, making it one of the few beta-lactams effective against this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefepime: A fourth-generation cephalosporin with excellent gram-negative coverage including Pseudomonas but lacks activity against MRSA.

 

Option C. Ceftazidime: A third-generation cephalosporin with strong antipseudomonal activity but limited gram-positive activity and no MRSA coverage.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: A widely used third-generation cephalosporin effective against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but ineffective against MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftobiprole is a fifth-generation cephalosporin with broad-spectrum activity including MRSA and should be considered when beta-lactam therapy is desired in suspected MRSA infections.

choices.text: The prescribed Clofazimine dose is appropriate, but both Dapsone and Rifampicin doses are higher than recommended for a child
The patient is receiving a correct regimen as per the revised pediatric MB guidelines
The Rifampicin and Clofazimine doses are excessive for a child, but Dapsone is appropriately dosed
All three drugs are overdosed compared to the pediatric MB leprosy regimen

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with multibacillary (MB) leprosy. He is initiated on WHO-recommended multidrug therapy. After 6 months of regular treatment, his family moves to a different state where he is seen by another physician unfamiliar with the revised pediatric dosing schedule. The physician prescribes Clofazimine 150 mg once a month and 50 mg on alternate day, and Rifampicin 600 mg monthly, along with Dapsone 100 mg daily. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this modified regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The prescribed Clofazimine dose is appropriate, but both Dapsone and Rifampicin doses are higher than recommended for a child.

 

  • According to the Revised National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) guidelines, for a child aged 9–14 years with multibacillary (MB) leprosy, the correct monthly and daily doses are:
    • Dapsone: 50 mg daily (not 100 mg as in the adult dose)
    • Clofazimine: 150 mg once a month & 50 mg on alternate days
    • Rifampicin: 450 mg once a month (not 600 mg as in adults)
  • In the given scenario:
    • Dapsone 100 mg daily and Rifampicin 600 mg monthly clearly reflect adult dosing, which exceeds the recommended pediatric dosing and may increase risk of adverse effects like anemia and hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pediatric patients (aged 9–14 years) with multibacillary leprosy, appropriate drug dosages must be used to avoid toxicity. 
  • Adult doses of Dapsone and Rifampicin should not be used in children, while Clofazimine requires adjusted monthly and alternate-day dosing.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with right knee swelling and dactylitis three weeks after a diarrheal illness. He also reports dysuria. Several children at his workplace had similar GI symptoms. What is the most likely causative pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Shigella flexneri

 

  • Reactive arthritis commonly follows infections with Shigella, Yersinia, Chlamydia, or Salmonella. 
  • Dactylitis, arthritis, and post-GI symptoms support the diagnosis. Shigella is a common trigger in post-enteric cases.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Campylobacter jejuni: Can cause reactive arthritis, but less frequently.
 

Option B. Clostridium difficile: Not a common trigger.
 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Rare cause of reactive arthritis. It produce classic HUS (Hemolytic uremic syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:


Reactive arthritis classically follows enteric infections like Shigella flexneri and features arthritis, dactylitis, and mucocutaneous involvement.

choices.text: Vaccination with the 9-valent HPV vaccine offers protection against high-risk oncogenic types including 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
If previously infected with one HPV type, vaccination can still offer protection against other vaccine-included types.
HPV vaccination eliminates the need for routine cervical cancer screening in vaccinated individuals.
The recommended schedule for HPV vaccination in adults aged 15 years and older is three doses at 0, 1–2, and 6 months.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman attends a gynecology clinic requesting HPV vaccination. She is sexually active, has had three lifetime partners, and recently tested negative for HPV on a cervical screening test. Regarding the use of HPV vaccines in her case and the broader public health implications, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV vaccination eliminates the need for routine cervical cancer screening in vaccinated individuals.

 

  • Vaccination does not eliminate the need for screening, as the vaccine does not cover all oncogenic types and is not therapeutic. 
  • Routine cervical cancer screening (e.g., Pap smear or HPV DNA testing) must still be followed per guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaccination with the 9-valent HPV vaccine offers protection against high-risk oncogenic types including 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58: True. The 9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9) covers HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58. Of these, types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 are oncogenic (high-risk).

 

Option B. If previously infected with one HPV type, vaccination can still offer protection against other vaccine-included types: True. Even if a person has been infected with one type of HPV, the vaccine can still prevent infection with other types included in the vaccine.

 

Option D. The recommended schedule for HPV vaccination in adults aged 15 years and older is three doses at 0, 1–2, and 6 months: True. For individuals ≥15 years old at the time of first dose, three doses (at 0, 1–2, and 6 months) are recommended for full protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV vaccination is a key preventive strategy against cervical and other anogenital cancers caused by oncogenic HPV types. 
  • While highly effective, it does not negate the need for cervical screening, as it does not offer complete protection against all oncogenic strains, and some individuals may already be exposed before vaccination.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is evaluated for progressive yellowing of the skin, unintended weight loss, and dull epigastric discomfort that has persisted for several weeks. On examination, he is found to have scleral icterus and a palpable, non-tender gallbladder. Laboratory studies reveal elevated total bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Cross-sectional abdominal imaging demonstrates a mass at the head of the pancreas causing obstruction of the common bile duct. A tumor marker assay is obtained to support the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following markers is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CA 19-9

 

  • This patient presents with classic features of pancreatic head adenocarcinoma, which include weight loss, painless jaundice, elevated bilirubin, and a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier’s sign).
  • CA 19-9 (carbohydrate antigen 19-9) is the most frequently elevated tumor marker associated with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
  • It is especially elevated in tumors of the head of the pancreas, where it is often used not just for diagnosis but also to monitor treatment response and recurrence.
  • While not diagnostic on its own, its elevated levels in the appropriate clinical setting strongly support the diagnosis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. CA-125: Incorrect. CA-125 is primarily a tumor marker used in epithelial ovarian cancer. It has no specific relevance to pancreatic cancer, and it is not typically elevated in tumors of the pancreas.

 

Option B. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): Incorrect. Although CEA can be mildly elevated in pancreatic, colorectal, and other gastrointestinal malignancies, it is less specific and sensitive than CA 19-9 for pancreatic cancer and is not the preferred marker in this setting.

 

Option D. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): Incorrect. AFP is a tumor marker associated with hepatocellular carcinoma and nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, particularly yolk sac tumors. It does not play a diagnostic role in pancreatic malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CA 19-9 is the most relevant and commonly elevated tumor marker in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, especially when the tumor arises in the head of the pancreas and causes obstructive jaundice.

choices.text: Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis due to SGLT2 inhibitor

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with nausea, abdominal discomfort, and malaise for the past two days. She has no fever, and her blood glucose level is 160 mg/dL. Her medications include metformin and empagliflozin, which she started 3 weeks ago. Laboratory results show: 

 

  • Serum bicarbonate: 14 mEq/L 
  • Arterial pH: 7.28 
  • Serum ketones: positive 
  • Anion gap: elevated 
  • Blood glucose: 162 mg/dL 

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her metabolic disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis due to SGLT2 inhibitor

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors (like empagliflozin) promote urinary glucose loss, leading to normal or only mildly elevated blood glucose levels.
  • They also reduce insulin levels and increase glucagon, promoting lipolysis and ketogenesis, increasing risk for euglycemic DKA.
  • Classically presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, mild hyperglycemia, ketosis, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin-associated lactic acidosis:

 

  • Typically presents with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, but lactate is elevated, and ketones are absent.
  • Glucose levels are not usually elevated, and GI symptoms may mimic this case.
  • Not correct here due to presence of ketones, making DKA more likely.

 

Option C. Starvation ketosis:

 

  • May present with ketonemia but rarely causes significant acidosis (pH usually >7.3).
  • Bicarbonate is only mildly low, and anion gap is not as significantly elevated.
  • Less likely in a type 2 diabetic on medications with normal caloric intake.

 

Option D. Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS):

 

  • Presents with very high glucose (>600 mg/dL), altered mental status, and dehydration, but no significant ketosis or acidosis.
  • Not consistent with this patient's normal glucose and presence of acidosis with ketones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin) are associated with euglycemic DKA, especially in settings of illness, fasting, surgery, or low insulin states. 
  • Always consider this diagnosis when a patient on these agents presents with acidosis and ketones despite normal glucose levels.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with increasing breathlessness, orthopnea, and bilateral leg swelling. Examination reveals elevated JVP and a fourth heart sound. Echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 55% and left atrial enlargement. Which of the following treatments has shown mortality benefit in such patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

  • There is no evidence of mortality benefit from any pharmacologic agent in heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). 
  • Management centers on symptom control and treatment of comorbidities such as hypertension, diabetes, and atrial fibrillation.
  • Drugs which reduce heart failure in patients with HfpEF
    • SGLT2 inhibitors 
    • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (Spironolactone)
    • GLP1 receptor agonists (Semaglutide) and Dual GIP and GLP-1 receptor agonist (Tirzepatide)

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): Studied in CHARM-Preserved trial, no mortality benefit.


Option B. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5 inhibitors): Limited data may reduce filling pressures but no outcome benefit.


Option C. Sodium-potassium-ATPase inhibitors: Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase inhibitors (e.g., digoxin) – Failed to reduce mortality in HFpEF.

 

Educational Objective:


Management of HFpEF focuses on volume and blood pressure control, no drug has been shown to improve survival.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a longstanding history of moderate persistent asthma is being considered for antiviral prophylaxis after a recent exposure to a confirmed case of influenza A. He has been stable on inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists, but he has a history of bronchospasm triggered by inhaled medications. Which of the following antivirals should be avoided in this patient due to its delivery method and potential adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zanamivir

 

  • Zanamivir is an inhaled neuraminidase inhibitor used in the treatment and prevention of influenza A and B. 
  • It is administered via a dry powder inhaler. In patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), inhaled zanamivir can trigger bronchospasm, a potentially life-threatening condition in individuals with reactive airways.
  • Due to this bronchospasm risk, zanamivir is contraindicated in patients with underlying asthma or should be used with extreme caution only when the potential benefits outweigh the risk. 
  • This route of administration is especially critical in a patient who is predisposed to airway reactivity, such as the asthmatic individual described in the scenario. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peramivir: 

 

  • Peramivir is administered intravenously and is generally reserved for the treatment (not prophylaxis) of influenza. 
  • Since it is not inhaled and does not carry a risk of inducing bronchospasm, it is considered safe for use in patients with asthma.

 

Option B. Oseltamivir: 

 

  • Oseltamivir is taken orally and is approved for both the treatment and prophylaxis of influenza A and B. 
  • It does not have any significant risk of causing bronchospasm and is widely used in patients with asthma without concern for respiratory side effects.

 

Option D. Amantadine: 

 

  • Amantadine is an oral antiviral that was historically used for influenza A, though its use has declined significantly due to widespread resistance. 
  • It does not cause bronchospasm and is not contraindicated in asthma, though it is no longer a first-line antiviral option.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Zanamivir is an inhaled neuraminidase inhibitor that can induce bronchospasm and must be avoided in patients with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

choices.text: Emphasizing religious undertones in health care delivery
Shifting focus from curative to purely preventive health services
Making the centers more culturally relatable and accessible at the community level
Redirecting funding away from primary healthcare to spiritual healing centers

questions.text: A 35-year-old medical officer is briefing new community health workers during the rollout of revised Ayushman Bharat services in a rural block. He explains that all existing Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs) are now renamed as "Ayushman Arogya Mandir". What is the most likely policy-driven outcome of changing the name from “Health and Wellness Centre” to “Arogya Mandir”?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Making the centers more culturally relatable and accessible at the community level

 

  • The renaming of Ayushman Bharat Health and Wellness Centres (AB-HWCs) to “Ayushman Arogya Mandir” with the tagline “Arogyam Paramam Dhanam” (Health is the Supreme Wealth) is a strategic move aimed at deepening cultural resonance with the Indian population, especially in rural and underserved areas.
  • The use of the word “Mandir”, which translates to “temple”, invokes a sense of trust, familiarity, reverence, and accessibility—terms that often do not accompany clinical, bureaucratic labels like “centre” or “facility.” The change aligns with the public health goal of:
    • Promoting healthcare-seeking behavior
    • Strengthening community ownership
    • Reinforcing primary care as a sacred, reliable, and compassionate space
  • This initiative also supports public health communication, making the health facility a symbolic center for well-being, not just disease treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emphasizing religious undertones in health care delivery: Incorrect. The name “Arogya Mandir” does not aim to religiously brand health services. The term “Mandir” is used culturally, not theologically, to create emotional trust and enhance community connect, particularly in areas with high traditional beliefs.

 

Option B. Shifting focus from curative to purely preventive health services: Incorrect. The AB-HWC model and Arogya Mandir continue to offer both preventive and curative care. There is no policy to exclude treatment services; instead, there's an integration of health promotion, disease prevention, diagnosis, and treatment under one roof.

 

Option D. Redirecting funding away from primary healthcare to spiritual healing centers: Incorrect. The renaming does not imply any shift in funding towards spiritual or non-allopathic practices. The initiative remains grounded in evidence-based, allopathic primary healthcare within the public health system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The renaming of AB-HWCs to Ayushman Arogya Mandirs is a policy-level communication strategy designed to improve community acceptance, emotional connection, and utilization of primary healthcare services, particularly in culturally rooted rural populations.

choices.text: Time to reach peak plasma concentration (T-max)

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient is being started on a new oral antihypertensive agent. As part of pharmacokinetic profiling, a plasma concentration vs. time graph is reviewed to understand the medication’s absorption characteristics. Which of the following parameters on the graph best represents the rate of absorption of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Time to reach peak plasma concentration (T-max)

 

  • T-max, or Time to reach maximum plasma concentration, is a key parameter derived from the concentration-time graph and serves as a marker for the rate of drug absorption.
  • A shorter T-max implies faster absorption, while a longer T-max suggests slower absorption. 
  • Although it does not provide the exact numeric value of the rate, it reflects how quickly a drug reaches systemic circulation at its peak concentration, hence correlating with absorption rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Area under the curve (AUC): AUC represents the overall exposure of the drug over time and is primarily used to calculate bioavailability and clearance, not the rate of absorption.

 

Option B. Maximum plasma concentration (C-max): C-max shows the peak level of drug in plasma but does not represent the rate of absorption directly. A high C-max may indicate greater extent of absorption but not how fast it occurred.

 

Option D. Bioavailability index: This is a comparative measure of the extent of absorption when compared to a reference (usually IV), but it does not provide information regarding absorption rate or timing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T-max is the pharmacokinetic parameter that best reflects the rate at which a drug is absorbed from the site of administration into the systemic circulation.

choices.text: Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface
Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of previous lower segment cesarean section presents at 30 weeks of gestation with painless vaginal bleeding. Transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound with color Doppler is performed and shows the findings in the image. Which of the following findings is not typically seen in placenta accreta?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thickening of the retroplacental myometrium

 

  • Placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) refers to abnormal adherence of the placenta to the myometrium due to defective decidua basalis. It is commonly associated with previous uterine surgery (e.g., LSCS, curettage) and placenta previa. Ultrasound with color Doppler is the primary modality for antenatal diagnosis.
  • Ultrasound Features Suggestive of Placenta Accreta:
    • Placental lacunae – Irregular vascular spaces within the placenta giving a “Swiss cheese” appearance; highly specific.
    • Thinning or absence of the retroplacental myometrium – Typically <1 mm, indicating invasion into the myometrium.
    • Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface – Suggests deep invasion into the bladder wall (especially in percreta).
    • Bridging vessels – Vessels seen traversing from the placenta across the myometrium into adjacent structures, particularly the bladder.
    • Placental bulge – Focal outward contour bulge of the placenta or uterus due to invasive growth.
  • In contrast, thickening of the retroplacental myometrium is not characteristic of PAS and would rather suggest normal or non-invasive placentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface: Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosa is a sign of placental percreta (the most severe form of PAS) with invasion into adjacent organs.

 

Option C. Placental lacunae: Presence of placental lacunae is a classic hallmark and among the earliest sonographic signs.

 

Option D. Bridging vessels from the placenta to the bladder-serosal interface: Bridging vessels are seen on color Doppler and are highly specific for PAS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta accreta spectrum disorders are characterized by abnormal placental adherence or invasion into the myometrium. 
  • Ultrasound findings such as placental lacunae, thinning of the retroplacental zone, bridging vessels, and disruption of the bladder-uterine interface are diagnostic clues. 
  • Thickening of the retroplacental myometrium is not a feature of PAS. Early identification is crucial for peripartum planning and reducing maternal morbidity.

questions.text: A 22-week primigravida had her LMP on June 10th and had regular 32-day cycles prior to that. What would her EDD be?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) March 21st

 

  • The Expected Date of Delivery (EDD) is calculated using Naegele’s Rule, which assumes a 28-day cycle. Adjustments are made for cycle lengths that differ from 28 days:
    • Naegele’s Formula for 28-day cycles: LMP + 9 months + 7 days
      For an LMP of June 10th:
      June 10 + 9 months = March 10
      March 10 + 7 days = March 17
    • Adjustment for a 32-day cycle:
      Since the cycle is 4 days longer than 28 days, we add 4 days to the EDD calculated above.
      March 17 + 4 days = March 21st.
  • Thus, the corrected EDD for this patient is March 21st.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use Naegele’s Rule to calculate EDD for a standard 28-day cycle, and adjust for longer or shorter cycles by adding or subtracting the difference in cycle days.

choices.text: The dose is sufficient; maximum requirement is 20 IU/kg
This is a suboptimal dose; patient needs 3000 IU of eRIG
No RIG is required if the bite is on the foot
A partial dose can be used only if vaccine is withheld

questions.text: A 60-kg adult male presents to the emergency department with a Category III dog bite, characterized by multiple deep bites to the thigh. The hospital has access only to equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG), and 1500 IU is currently available for administration. Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) This is a suboptimal dose; patient needs 3000 IU of eRIG

 

  • The recommended dose of eRIG is 40 IU/kg body weight and HRIG is 20 IU/Kg
  • For a 60-kg adult:
    • 60 kg × 40 IU = 2400 IU (minimum requirement) up to 3000 IU may be used, especially when wound size or infiltration volume is large.
  • Since only 1500 IU is available, the dose is clearly insufficient for optimal infiltration.
  • In such cases, limited RIG should be infiltrated into and around the wound, and rabies vaccination must still be given immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose is sufficient; maximum requirement is 20 IU/kg: Incorrect. 20 IU/kg is the dose for human RIG (hRIG), not eRIG. eRIG requires 40 IU/kg.

 

Option C. No RIG is required if the bite is on the foot: Incorrect. RIG is required regardless of wound site in Category III exposure; foot bites are still significant.

 

Option D. A partial dose can be used only if vaccine is withheld: Incorrect. RIG is never withheld due to dose constraints, and vaccine should never be delayed or withheld.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Category III rabies exposures, administer RIG at 40 IU/kg for eRIG. If limited RIG is available, infiltrate as much as possible into the wound and initiate the rabies vaccine series without delay.

questions.text: A cell is permeable only to potassium ions. The intracellular K⁺ concentration is 140 mEq/L, and the extracellular K⁺ concentration is initially 14 mEq/L. What change in membrane potential would be expected if the extracellular K⁺ concentration is reduced from 14 to 1.4 mEq/L?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 61 millivolts hyperpolarization

 

To solve this, we apply the Nernst equation, which describes the equilibrium (Nernst) potential for a particular ion:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When extracellular potassium concentration decreases, potassium moves out of the cell, making the inside more negative. 
  • This results in hyperpolarization. A 10-fold decrease in [K⁺]outside causes a 61mV hyperpolarization according to the Nernst equation

questions.text: Under control conditions, flow through a blood vessel is 100 ml/min under a pressure gradient of 50 mm Hg. What would be the approximate flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel diameter to four times normal, assuming that the pressure gradient remains constant at 50 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25,600 ml/min

 

  • To solve this, we apply Poiseuille’s Law, which describes laminar flow of fluid through a cylindrical vessel:

 

 

  • Where:
    • Q = flow
    • ΔP = pressure gradient
    • r = radius of the vessel
    • η = viscosity of the fluid
    • L = length of the vessel
  • Key point:
    • Flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius.
  • Step-by-Step Calculation:
    • Initial flow: 100 ml/min
    • New radius = 4 × original
    • Flow increases by a factor of 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to Poiseuille’s law, blood flow through a vessel is proportional to the fourth power of the radius. 
  • A 4-fold increase in vessel radius results in a 256-fold increase in flow, assuming pressure and other factors remain constant.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in his left knee after a fall during a soccer game. X-rays reveal an epiphyseal injury at the distal femur. Which of the following is the most common complication associated with this type of injury in paediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth disturbance

 

  • The growth plate (physis) is responsible for longitudinal bone growth.
  • Distal femoral physis contributes significantly (~35%) to leg length — so injuries here are high-risk.
  • Damage can lead to:
    • Premature closure of the growth plate
    • Limb length discrepancy
    • Angular deformities
  • This is the most common and significant complication of epiphyseal injuries in children.
  • Growth disturbances are more likely with Salter-Harris type III–V fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteomyelitis:

  • Osteomyelitis (bone infection) is more commonly seen in:
    • Open fractures
    • Hematogenous spread (in younger children)
  • It is not a common complication of closed epiphyseal injuries.
  • While possible, especially in the setting of infection or open injury, it is not the most likely complication here.

 

Option C. Ligament tear:

  • Ligament injuries are more common in adults due to stronger bones and weaker ligaments.
  • In children, growth plates are weaker than ligaments, so trauma often causes physeal fractures instead of ligament tears.
  • A ligament tear is not the most likely consequence of this injury pattern.

 

 

Option D. Joint instability:

  • Joint instability could occur if ligaments or joint capsules are damaged, or if the fracture extends into the joint with poor alignment.
  • However, in isolated epiphyseal injuries, especially if properly treated, this is not the most common complication.
  • Again, growth disturbance remains the more frequent and serious long-term risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In paediatric patients with epiphyseal (growth plate) fractures, especially around the distal femur, the most common and clinically significant complication is growth disturbance. 
  • This is due to potential damage to the physis leading to limb length discrepancy or angular deformities.

questions.text:
Match the following

 

Column A (Color of Amniotic Fluid):

  1. Green-yellow with flakes
  2. Golden color
  3. Straw colored
  4. Dark brown (tobacco juice)

 

Column B (Fetal Condition):

  1. Intrauterine demise
  2. Rh incompatibility
  3. Fetal distress
  4. Term Pregnancy
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

A-3. Green, yellow with flakes: Indicates meconium-stained amniotic fluid, a sign of fetal distress.

 

B-2. Golden color: Associated with Rh incompatibility due to bilirubin in the fluid.

 

C-4. Straw colored: Suggestive of normal amniotic fluid colour (term pregnancy)

 

D-1. Dark brown: Indicates intrauterine demise due to breakdown of blood and tissue in prolonged fetal death.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presents with a 3-week history of sudden painless vision loss in one eye. The patient denies any trauma or injury. On examination, the anterior segment is normal, but there is no fundal glow visible upon fundoscopy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitreous hemorrhage

 

  • The patient's sudden, painless vision loss with normal anterior segment findings and no fundal glow is most likely due to vitreous hemorrhage. 
  • This condition involves bleeding into the vitreous cavity, obscuring the view of the retina and leading to the absence of the fundal glow. 
  • The most common causes of vitreous hemorrhage include diabetic retinopathy, retinal tears, and trauma, although in some cases, the cause may not be immediately identifiable. 
  • The blood in the vitreous prevents light from reaching the retina, thus blocking the typical reflection seen during ophthalmoscopy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal detachment: Retinal detachment typically presents with a sudden onset of visual changes, such as flashes of light or floaters, and can cause loss of vision in the affected part of the retina.
