However, retinal detachment does not typically cause the absence of fundal glow, rather it presents with a dull, whitish glow. The retina is still visible in cases of detachment, though it may appear detached or folded.

 

Option B. Macular degeneration: Macular degeneration, especially age-related macular degeneration, leads to central vision loss due to degeneration of the macula. However, it usually causes a gradual, not sudden, loss of vision. It does not cause the absence of fundal glow, as the retina is still visible on examination. Moreover, macular degeneration often presents with distorted vision or a dark spot in the central vision, rather than complete vision loss in one eye.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: Optic atrophy involves the degeneration of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss, but it does not cause sudden, painless vision loss or absence of fundal glow. The condition typically results in gradual vision loss, often with visible changes in the optic disc. The retina itself would still be visible in cases of optic atrophy, unlike in vitreous hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitreous hemorrhage causes sudden, painless vision loss with normal anterior segment findings and no fundal glow due to the obscuring effect of blood in the vitreous cavity, preventing light from reaching the retina.

choices.text: Microphone → Transmitter → Speech processor → Receiver/stimulator → Electrodes
Speech processor → Microphone → Transmitter → Electrodes → Receiver/stimulator
Microphone → Speech processor → Transmitter → Receiver/stimulator → Electrodes
Microphone → Speech processor → Receiver/stimulator → Transmitter → Electrodes

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with congenital bilateral sensorineural hearing loss undergoes cochlear implantation. Postoperatively, the audiologist explains the working mechanism of the implant to the parents. Which of the following is the correct sequence in which sound is transmitted using a cochlear implant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microphone → Speech processor → Transmitter → Receiver/stimulator → Electrodes

 

  • The correct order of sound transmission in a cochlear implant is:
    1. Microphone: Picks up sound from the environment.
    2. Speech Processor: Converts sound into digital signals.
    3. Transmitter (External): Sends digital signals across the skin.
    4. Receiver/Stimulator (Internal): Receives, decodes signals, and transmits to electrodes.
    5. Electrode array (in cochlea): Stimulates the spiral ganglion cells in the scala tympani, bypassing damaged hair cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise mechanism of sound signal transmission in a cochlear implant includes the transition from external components (sound reception and digital conversion) to internal components (electrical stimulation of cochlear nerve).

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a complaint of persistent watering and mucopurulent discharge from one eye. Ocular examination reveals a normal anterior chamber and fundus, and there are no signs of systemic infection. Based on the clinical findings, what is the initial treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Massage over lacrimal sac

 

  • The clinical picture is typical of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (CNLDO), also known as dacryostenosis, which commonly presents in the first few months of life with:
    • Epiphora (watering of the eyes)
    • Mucopurulent discharge
    • Normal anterior and posterior segment findings
  • The first-line treatment in infants under 6 months is Crigler's massage, which involves downward pressure over the medial canthal area to create a hydrostatic pressure. 

 

 

  • This maneuver helps to open up the nasolacrimal duct, especially if the obstruction is at the valve of Hasner.
  • Spontaneous resolution is common with this method.
  • No surgical intervention is typically required initially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balloon catheter dilation: This is a second-line or adjunctive intervention, often reserved for older children or those in whom probing has failed. Not the first-line treatment in a 3-month-old.

 

Option C. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): A surgical procedure to create a new drainage pathway. This is typically indicated only in older children or adults with failed conservative and probing treatments. It is considered beyond 18 months of age, while the preferred age being 4 years.

 

Option D. Syringing and probing: While probing is effective, it is not the first line in infants under 6 months. It is considered after 6 months of age if massage fails, up to 18 months of age. The probe is first inserted vertically, then turn horizontally, and finally turned vertically down. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction, massage over the lacrimal sac is the initial treatment of choice, as it promotes spontaneous opening of the obstructed duct.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 7 years ago) is asymptomatic and presents for preventive care. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test for lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annual low-dose CT scan

 

  • Low-dose CT (LDCT) screening reduces lung cancer mortality in high-risk patients aged 50–80 years with ≥20 pack-years of smoking. 
  • Chest X-ray has no mortality benefit. Genetic testing and vitamins are not recommended for screening.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Annual Chest X-ray: Ineffective for screening; lacks sensitivity.
 

Option C. Genetic screening for lung cancer: No proven utility in lung cancer prevention.
 

Option D. Daily vitamin E supplementation: Not beneficial; may even increase risk in smokers.

 

Educational Objective:


LDCT is the only validated screening tool to reduce lung cancer mortality in patients with significant smoking history.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman reports 6 years of daily green sputum, frequent sinus infections, and occasional hemoptysis. Lung auscultation reveals coarse crackles. Spirometry shows FEV₁/FVC = 54%. Sputum grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-resolution CT scan

 

  • HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis, which is suspected in patients with chronic productive cough and Pseudomonas colonization. 
  • It detects bronchial dilation, lack of tapering, and signet ring sign, unlike chest X-ray.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Chest X-ray: May miss early or subtle bronchiectasis.
 

Option C. Bronchoscopy: Reserved for localized or unclear etiologies.
 

Option D. Sweat chloride testing: Done post-diagnosis to evaluate for CF in young or atypical cases.

 

Educational Objective:


HRCT is the preferred diagnostic test for bronchiectasis in patients with recurrent infections and chronic sputum production.

questions.text: A 6-month-old female infant is brought for evaluation of refractory infantile spasms and delayed milestones. The child was born at term with no perinatal complications. MRI brain is as shown below. Which of the following findings, if present, would most strongly argue against the diagnosis of Aicardi Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 46, XY karyotype

 

  • Aicardi syndrome is a rare, classically X-linked dominant disorder that almost exclusively affects females. It presents with a triad of:
    1. Agenesis of the corpus callosum
    2. Chorioretinal lacunae (pathognomonic)
    3. Infantile spasms (refractory seizures)
  • Additional features may include:
    • Intellectual disability
    • Vertebral anomalies (e.g., hemivertebrae, scoliosis)
    • Optic nerve colobomas
    • Polymicrogyria or cortical dysplasia on imaging

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agenesis of corpus callosum: Seen in >90% of Aicardi syndrome patients. Strongly supportive of diagnosis.

 

Option B. Infantile spasms: Part of the classic triad. Refractory epilepsy is often the presenting feature.

 

Option D. Chorioretinal lacunae: Pathognomonic finding on fundoscopy in Aicardi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin >2.6% and elevated GGT

questions.text: A 30-year-old man drinks daily and reports hangovers and one blackout. He denies social or legal issues. Which lab markers best detect chronic heavy alcohol use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin >2.6% and elevated GGT

 

  • Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) are the most specific markers for chronic heavy alcohol use. 
  • Used together, they improve diagnostic accuracy over individual markers like MCV or AST:ALT ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AST:ALT ratio >2: Suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis, not screening.

 

Option C. MCV >91 μm³: Can be elevated for many reasons; lacks specificity.

 

Option D. Serum uric acid >7 mg/dL: Non-specific; elevated in many conditions like CKD, metabolic syndrome, etc.

 

Educational Objective:


For detecting covert alcohol use, CDT and GGT together offer optimal sensitivity and specificity among lab tests.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease stage 3 and long-standing hypertension is found to have recurrent episodes of hyperkalemia during routine lab monitoring. He is currently taking an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor as part of his antihypertensive regimen. Which of the following diuretics is the most suitable choice to address his blood pressure and electrolyte imbalance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Furosemide

 

  • The presence of recurrent hyperkalemia in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3 who is also on an ACE inhibitor (which reduces aldosterone and impairs potassium excretion) raises the need for a potassium-wasting agent.
  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that increases urinary excretion of sodium, chloride, and potassium, making it highly beneficial for patients with hyperkalemia and moderate-to-severe CKD. 
  • It is more effective than thiazides in patients with reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR), particularly in CKD stage 3 or worse. Thus, furosemide addresses both:
    • Hypertension control
    • Reduction of serum potassium

 

Other Options:


Option A. Acetazolamide: 

 

  • This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, leading to bicarbonate loss and mild diuresis. 
  • It is not effective in controlling blood pressure or in managing hyperkalemia, making it unsuitable for this scenario.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: 

 

  • A potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist, which would worsen hyperkalemia, especially when combined with ACE inhibitors. 
  • This combination can lead to life-threatening elevations in serum potassium, particularly in CKD.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide:

 

  • Although it can cause hypokalemia, its effectiveness decreases in patients with moderate to advanced CKD due to poor efficacy at lower GFR. 
  • Thus, it is not as effective as furosemide in stage 3 CKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Furosemide is the preferred diuretic in patients with stage 3 chronic kidney disease and recurrent hyperkalemia, particularly when they are receiving an ACE inhibitor.

choices.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents for a routine antenatal visit at 32 weeks of gestation. Her previous pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, her symphysis-fundal height is found to be lagging by 4 weeks. An obstetric ultrasound confirms fetal growth restriction (FGR) with an estimated fetal weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age. Umbilical artery Doppler is as follows. Fetal heart rate is 146 bpm. She is otherwise asymptomatic and has no signs of preeclampsia. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weekly Doppler of umbilical artery

 

  • This is the standard recommendation in early-onset FGR with normal umbilical artery Doppler:
    • Surveillance with weekly Doppler velocimetry is done to detect early signs of placental insufficiency.
    • If flow becomes absent or reversed, or other signs of compromise appear, delivery may be considered.
  • This strategy balances the risks of prematurity with those of intrauterine hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS): Incorrect.

 

  • Emergency LSCS is indicated in cases of fetal distress, such as:
    • Reversed or absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery
    • Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns
    • Severe oligohydramnios or worsening maternal condition (e.g., preeclampsia, eclampsia)
  • In this patient, Doppler is normal, and there's no fetal or maternal instability, so emergency LSCS is not justified.

 

Option B. Induction of labor: Incorrect.

 

  • Induction of labor at 32 weeks is generally avoided unless:
    • There is non-reassuring fetal status, or
    • Fetal/maternal complications mandate early delivery.
  • Spontaneous labor is not favorable at this gestational age without lung maturity. Also, FGR with normal Doppler should be monitored, not delivered prematurely.

 

Option C. Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor: Incorrect.

 

  • While corticosteroids are given between 24 and 34 weeks to accelerate fetal lung maturity in anticipation of preterm birth, induction of labor is not needed immediately unless fetal monitoring deteriorates.
  • Here, fetal Doppler is normal, and no immediate threat exists. Hence, the approach is close monitoring, not planned early delivery yet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In early-onset FGR with normal Doppler flow, the best approach is weekly umbilical artery Doppler monitoring. 
  • Early intervention is considered only if Doppler findings worsen or other complications develop.

choices.text: Antibody to viral capsid antigen (VCA) IgM

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presents with fever, sore throat, generalized lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. Monospot test is negative, but Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) serology is sent to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following antibodies, if present, would indicate a past EBV infection rather than an acute one?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody to EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA)

 

  • EBV-specific antibody detection involves serologic evaluation of responses to three key antigens:
    • Viral capsid antigen (VCA):
      • IgM → Indicates acute or recent infection
      • IgG → Appears in both acute and past infection
    • Early antigen (EA):
      • Appears transiently during acute infection, then fades
    • EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA):
      • Appears late, typically 6–8 weeks after infection
      • Remains positive for life, thus marker of past infection
  • So, detection of anti-EBNA antibodies confirms that the patient has had past EBV exposure and is not in the acute phase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibody to early antigen (EA): Suggests acute or active infection; it disappears in recovery phase.

 

Option B. Antibody to viral capsid antigen (VCA) IgM: A marker of early/acute infection, not past infection.

 

Option D. Antibody to capsular antigen: No such thing as capsular antigen in EBV 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antibodies to EBV nuclear antigen (EBNA) are detected only after the acute phase and persist lifelong, serving as a marker of past EBV infection.

choices.text: Non-weight bearing with follow-up X-ray in 6 weeks
Initiate weight-bearing with analgesics and physical therapy

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents to the emergency department after a fall from standing height. She is unable to bear weight on her right leg and reports severe hip pain. On examination, the right leg appears shortened and externally rotated. The patient has a history of osteoporosis and is currently on long-term corticosteroid therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hip replacement surgery

 

  • It is indicated in:
    • Elderly patients (≥65 years old) with displaced femoral neck fractures or intra-capsular fractures
    • Poor bone healing potential (e.g., due to osteoporosis or steroid use)
    • To restore mobility and reduce the risk of complications from immobility
  • Types:
    • Hemiarthroplasty: Replaces only the femoral head and neck
    • Total hip replacement: Replaces both acetabulum and femoral head (may be used in active, mobile elderly patients); preferred choice for the arthritis patient of any age. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Closed Reduction and Internal Fixation (CRIF):

  • Indicated in:
    • Younger patients or those with non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures
    • Better bone healing potential
  • Not ideal here:
    • The patient is elderly and likely has a displaced femoral neck fracture
    • Osteoporotic bone may not hold fixation well
    • Higher risk of non-union or avascular necrosis (AVN)

 

 

Option C. Non-weight bearing with follow-up X-ray in 6 weeks:

  • Indicated in:
    • Stable fractures, particularly pelvic or acetabular fractures that don’t require surgery
    • Occasionally for nondisplaced fractures in non-surgical candidates
  • Not appropriate:
    • This is an unstable fracture with classic signs of a displaced hip fracture
    • Delaying intervention increases risk of complications: thromboembolism, pneumonia, pressure sores

 

 

Option D. Initiate weight-bearing with analgesics and physical therapy:

  • Indicated in:
    • Minor injuries or non-fracture pain
    • Stable orthopedic conditions (e.g., osteoarthritis)
  • Not appropriate:
    • The patient has a fracture — weight-bearing would worsen the injury
    • Surgery is needed before any weight-bearing

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 5 and 60 months (peak 12–18 months) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that are not the result of CNS infection
Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 6 and 70 months (peak 12–18 months) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that are not the result of CNS infection
Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 6 and 60 months (peak 18–36 months) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that are not the result of CNS infection
Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 6 and 60 months (peak 12–18 months) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that are not the result of CNS infection

questions.text: Which of the statements given below is correct regarding febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Febrile seizures are seizures that occur between the ages of 6 and 60 months (peak 12–18 months) with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher, that are not the result of CNS infection

 

  • Febrile seizures are the most common type of seizure in children. They are defined by the following criteria:
    • Occur between 6 months and 60 months (5 years) of age
    • Occur in association with fever ≥38°C (100.4°F)
    • No evidence of CNS infection, prior afebrile seizures, or acute metabolic abnormality
    • Most common between 12 and 18 months

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with upper abdominal discomfort, dark stools, and relief with antacids. Endoscopy reveals a 2.2 cm duodenal ulcer and positive H. pylori biopsy. Which of the following is not an appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pantoprazole and Clarithromycin

 

  • Monotherapy with clarithromycin and PPI (without a third agent) is inadequate. 
  • Clarithromycin triple therapy requires amoxicillin or metronidazole. Bismuth quadruple, vonoprazan-based dual therapy, and rifabutin-based regimens are all validated alternatives.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Omeprazole + Bismuth + Metronidazole + Tetracycline: Effective bismuth quadruple regimen. This is the first line treatment as per the most of the guidelines. But, In India we still use triple therapy. 
 

Option B. Vonoprazan-Amoxicillin: Vonoprazan dual therapy is approved. This is long acting, can be taken irrespective of meal time, and can be used as double therapy.
 

Option C. Low-dose Rifabutin Triple: Rifabutin triple is used in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Effective H. pylori treatment requires at least two antibiotics and a PPI; dual regimens without this are inadequate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with gradually progressive patchy hair loss over the scalp for the past 4 months. On examination, the scalp shows well-demarcated erythematous plaques with adherent scales. When one of the scales is gently lifted, multiple horny projections are seen on its underside that had been lodged within the follicular openings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) is a chronic, scarring form of cutaneous lupus that commonly affects the scalp, face, and ears. 
  • It presents as erythematous plaques with adherent scales and follicular plugging. 
  • A characteristic clinical sign is the “carpet tack” sign (also known as the cat's tongue or tin tack sign), where removal of the scale reveals horny plugs on its undersurface that were lodged in dilated follicles. 
  • DLE is a leading cause of scarring alopecia and requires prompt diagnosis to prevent permanent hair loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia areata:

 

  • This autoimmune disorder presents with sudden-onset, non-scarring hair loss in well-circumscribed patches. 
  • The hallmark findings are “exclamation mark” hairs (short broken hairs that are narrower at the base) seen at the periphery of lesions. 
  • There is no erythema or scaling, and the carpet tack sign is not observed. Follicular structures are preserved, allowing for regrowth if the disease is controlled.

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis:

 

  • Though dermatomyositis may involve the scalp, it typically presents with heliotrope rash, Gottron’s papules, and photosensitive poikilodermatous eruptions, not scarring alopecia. 
  • Hair loss, when present, is usually diffuse and non-scarring, and there is no follicular plugging or carpet tack sign. 
  • The associated muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes are key diagnostic features.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris:

 

  • This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, characterized by slowly progressive reddish-brown plaques that may ulcerate. 
  • Commonly seen on the face or extremities, lupus vulgaris is not associated with alopecia or follicular plugging. 
  • The carpet tack sign is not a feature, and diagnosis is confirmed via histopathology, PCR, or culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The carpet tack sign—seen when scales from DLE lesions are removed—is a clinical clue to follicular plugging and chronic scarring alopecia. 
  • Recognizing this sign is important in distinguishing DLE from other causes of hair loss.

choices.text: Movement of K⁺ into the cell
Movement of K⁺ out of the cell
Movement of Na⁺ into the cell

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily responsible for the change in membrane potential between points B and D?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Movement of Na⁺ into the cell

 

  • The change in membrane potential between points B and D represents the depolarization phase of the action potential:
    • At point B, the membrane has reached the threshold potential, which leads to the opening of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels.
    • As a result, Na⁺ ions rapidly flow into the cell down their electrochemical gradient.
    • This influx of Na⁺ causes the interior of the cell to become more positive, producing the sharp rise in membrane potential that characterizes depolarization.
    • Point D marks the peak of depolarization, just before the Na⁺ channels inactivate and K⁺ channels open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of the Na⁺, K⁺-ATPase: This pump maintains resting membrane potential over the long term but is not responsible for rapid voltage changes during an action potential.

 

Option B. Movement of K⁺ into the cell: K⁺ usually moves out of the cell during repolarization, not during the depolarization phase.

 

Option C. Movement of K⁺ out of the cell: This occurs during the falling phase (after point D), contributing to repolarization, not the rising phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During the depolarization phase of an action potential, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open, allowing Na⁺ to flow into the cell. 
  • This inward current causes the membrane potential to rapidly become more positive, a hallmark of the rising phase of the action potential.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and mild abdominal fullness. Examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory tests show lymphocytosis. Lymph node biopsy reveals a population of CD5-positive B cells with overexpression of cyclin D1. Genetic analysis identifies a t(11;14) translocation involving the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) locus and the CCND1 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mantle cell lymphoma

 

  • This patient's clinical presentation with fatigue, splenomegaly, and lymphocytosis, along with histologic and molecular findings, is characteristic of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). 
  • MCL is a mature B-cell neoplasm that typically affects older men and presents with generalized lymphadenopathy, bone marrow involvement, and sometimes gastrointestinal tract polyps (lymphomatous polyposis).
  • The key diagnostic hallmark is the t(11;14)(q13;q32) translocation, which brings the CCND1 (cyclin D1) gene under the control of the IgH enhancer on chromosome 14, resulting in cyclin D1 overexpression. 
  • Cyclin D1 is a cell cycle regulator (cyclin) that promotes the G1-to-S phase transition, leading to unregulated proliferation of neoplastic B cells.
  • The question includes:
    • CCND1 (cyclin D1) – the gene affected
    • Cyclin – the class of protein overexpressed
    • t(11;14) – the translocation
    • IgH – the gene locus involved
    • Mantle cell lymphoma – the disease diagnosis
  • All elements are directly integrated into this clinical question and answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: This lymphoma is associated with t(14;18) translocation, leading to overexpression of BCL2, which inhibits apoptosis. It typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy and lacks cyclin D1 overexpression or t(11;14) translocation.

 

Option B. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL): This is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and usually presents aggressively with rapidly enlarging masses. It does not feature cyclin D1 overexpression or t(11;14). Genetic changes are variable and may include BCL6, BCL2, or MYC rearrangements. A patient with DLBCL may present with a history of pre-existing lymphoma.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: A rare chronic B-cell leukemia characterized by splenomegaly and pancytopenia, and involvement of bone marrow. The patients may present with fine hairy projections. It is associated with BRAF V600E mutations, not translocations. It does not involve CCND1, cyclin, t(11;14), or IgH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mantle cell lymphoma is defined by a t(11;14) translocation involving the CCND1 gene and the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) locus, resulting in cyclin D1 overexpression and dysregulated cell cycle progression.

questions.text: A lethal mutation in a bacterium results in the inability to properly replicate its chromosome. DNA synthesis is initiated, but the process yields numerous short DNA fragments, each containing an RNA segment at their 5′ ends. This mutation is most likely affecting a gene encoding which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA polymerase I

 

  • The key clues in this scenario are:
    • Numerous short DNA fragments: These are Okazaki fragments, formed on the lagging strand during DNA replication.
    • RNA sequences at the 5′ ends: This indicates that RNA primers were laid down to initiate synthesis.
    • The fragments are not being processed properly, i.e., RNA primers are not being removed and replaced with DNA.
  • In bacteria, DNA polymerase I is responsible for:
    • Removing RNA primers (via its 5′→3′ exonuclease activity), and
    • Replacing them with DNA (via its 5′→3′ polymerase activity).
  • A mutation in the gene encoding DNA polymerase I would prevent removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, leaving RNA at the 5′ ends, and disrupting formation of continuous DNA strands—ultimately impairing chromosomal replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA gyrase: This enzyme relieves supercoiling tension ahead of the replication fork. A defect here could slow or stall replication but would not cause persistence of RNA primers on DNA fragments.

 

Option B. DNA helicase: Responsible for unwinding DNA at the replication fork. Its loss would prevent strand separation, leading to a halt in replication initiation, not accumulation of RNA-tagged fragments.

 

Option C. DNA ligase: DNA ligase joins DNA-DNA nicks between Okazaki fragments after RNA primers are removed and replaced. It cannot act if RNA primers remain and is not involved in removing RNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DNA polymerase I in prokaryotes removes RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and replaces them with DNA.
  • A mutation impairing this function leads to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA at their 5′ ends, disrupting chromosome replication.

choices.text: Immediate cesarean followed by bilateral internal iliac artery ligation
Administration of corticosteroids, transfuse blood, followed by a planned cesarean at 37 weeks.
Serial ultrasound monitoring with plans of delivery if evidence of increasing vascularity in the placenta
Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman, G4P3 at 28 weeks of gestation, presents with recurrent episodes of painless vaginal bleeding over the past 1 week. Her medical history is significant for 1 previous cesarean delivery and 1 dilatation and curettage of a previous incomplete abortion. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and the fetal heart rate is reassuring. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a placenta located near the cervix with multiple hypoechoic areas and irregular vascular spaces within the placenta. Laboratory results show an Hb of 8g%. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy

 

  • This is a clinical scenario of placenta accreta syndromes as the history of previous cesarean and D & C with the current ultrasound findings support this diagnosis
  • Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes:
    • Stabilization of the patient
    • Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate cesarean followed by bilateral internal iliac artery ligation: As the patient is stable currently, immediate cesarean is not warranted as she is only 29 weeks

 

Option B. Administration of corticosteroids, transfuse blood, followed by a planned cesarean at 37 weeks: This would have been correct, but option D is a better option in the scenario of accreta. If only placenta previa, this would have been the preferred option

 

Option C. Serial ultrasound monitoring with plans of delivery if evidence of increasing vascularity in the placenta: There is no role of looking at increasing vascularity on ultrasound and it will not change the management. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes:
    • Stabilization of the patient
    • Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage.

choices.text: Brain fingerprinting measures heart rate variability
Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses
Brain fingerprinting determines truthfulness through galvanic skin response

questions.text: A 35-year-old intelligence officer is undergoing screening to ensure loyalty and integrity before receiving a high-security clearance. Investigators decide to use a method based on measuring brain recognition signals, which is unaffected by emotional reactions. Which of the following best differentiates brain fingerprinting from polygraph testing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brain fingerprinting detects cognitive memory-based responses

 

  • Brain fingerprinting is a neuroscientific technique designed to detect whether specific information is stored in a person’s brain, without relying on emotional or physical reactions. 
  • It primarily uses event-related potentials (ERPs), especially the P300 wave and MERMER (Memory and Encoding Related Multifaceted Electroencephalographic Response), to detect whether a subject recognizes crime-related or relevant information.
  • The method is independent of emotional responses and physiological changes (such as sweating, heart rate changes), making it fundamentally different from a polygraph.
  • In contrast, polygraph testing is based on physiological measures like heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and galvanic skin response, which are indirectly affected by emotional arousal (fear, stress, anxiety) during interrogation. 
  • Thus, polygraph results can be unreliable if the subject is nervous even when innocent.
  • Brain fingerprinting focuses purely on recognition memory signals — if a subject has prior knowledge of a specific crime-related stimulus, the brain’s electrical activity will show a specific pattern, regardless of their emotional state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain fingerprinting measures heart rate variability:

 

  • Incorrect. Heart rate variability is a physiological measure used in polygraph testing, not in brain fingerprinting. 
  • Brain fingerprinting strictly records brainwave patterns through EEG.

 

Option B. Brain fingerprinting evaluates emotional arousal:

 

  • Incorrect. Evaluating emotional arousal (e.g., anxiety, fear) is the primary principle behind polygraph testing, not brain fingerprinting. 
  • Brain fingerprinting assesses recognition memory, not emotional states.

 

Option D. Brain fingerprinting determines truthfulness through galvanic skin response:

 

  • Incorrect. Galvanic skin response (GSR), or skin conductance, is another emotion-based physiological measure used in polygraphs. 
  • Brain fingerprinting does not measure GSR; it purely analyzes EEG brain signals linked to memory recognition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unlike polygraphy, which depends on emotional and autonomic responses (e.g., heart rate, sweating), brain fingerprinting directly measures brain recognition responses (P300 and MERMER) to known information, offering a more objective tool for detecting concealed knowledge.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is diagnosed with congenital glaucoma and is initiated on medical therapy while awaiting surgical intervention. The ophthalmology team considers several topical antiglaucoma agents. Which of the following medications is contraindicated or unsafe in infants due to the risk of serious central nervous system side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used as an antiglaucoma agent to reduce aqueous humor production and increase uveoscleral outflow. It causes brain suppression. However, it is contraindicated in infants and young children, especially under the age of 2 years, due to the risk of systemic absorption and serious central nervous system (CNS) depression. Documented side effects include:
    • Apnea
    • Bradycardia
    • Hypotension
    • Hypothermia
    • Coma
  • These potentially life-threatening complications make brimonidine unsafe in pediatric populations, particularly infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: A beta-blocker that is generally considered safe for use in infants with proper monitoring. Though systemic absorption may cause bradycardia or bronchospasm, these effects are usually manageable and less severe compared to brimonidine.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: A prostaglandin analog that increases uveoscleral outflow. It is generally safe in pediatric patients and is used off-label in congenital glaucoma when needed.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces aqueous humor production. It is considered safe in pediatric patients, although some local irritation may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brimonidine is contraindicated in infants due to its potential to cause serious CNS depression, including apnea, hypotension, and coma.

choices.text: Increased TLC, reduced VC, low FEV₁/FVC ratio
Reduced TLC, RV, and VC; high FEV₁/FVC; normal MIP
Reduced TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC ratio, low MIP
Normal TLC, RV, FEV₁/FVC, and MIP

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with progressive muscle weakness undergoes pulmonary function testing. She has tested positive for AchRAb and repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Which pattern in pulmonary function testing best corresponds to the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduced TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC ratio, low MIP

 

  • This patient likely has myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular junction disorder characterized by fatigable weakness and positive AchR antibodies. Pulmonary involvement arises due to respiratory muscle weakness, including the diaphragm. In neuromuscular weakness:

     
    • TLC is reduced due to inability to expand the lungs fully.
    • RV is increased due to impaired expiratory muscle function.
    • FEV₁/FVC ratio is normal or slightly increased, since both FEV₁ and FVC are proportionally reduced.
    • MIP (maximum inspiratory pressure) is low, indicating weakened inspiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Increased TLC, reduced VC, low FEV₁/FVC ratio: Suggests obstructive lung disease (e.g., emphysema), not neuromuscular weakness.


Option B. Reduced TLC, RV, and VC; high FEV₁/FVC; normal MIP: Reduced RV and normal MIP are inconsistent with neuromuscular disease.
 

Option D. Normal TLC, RV, FEV₁/FVC, and MIP: Findings would be normal in a healthy individual, not in someone with myasthenia gravis and muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:


Neuromuscular diseases like myasthenia gravis show a restrictive pattern on PFTs with low TLC, increased RV, normal FEV₁/FVC, and low MIP—reflecting inspiratory muscle weakness and ineffective expiration.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is prescribed mirtazapine for major depressive disorder. After a few days, he reports excessive sleepiness, increased appetite, and noticeable weight gain. These side effects are most likely due to mirtazapine's antagonistic action at which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Histamine H1 receptors

 

  • Mirtazapine is a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) that exerts its effects by blocking presynaptic alpha-2 receptors, thereby increasing norepinephrine and serotonin. It also antagonizes serotonin receptors (5-HT2 and 5-HT3) and histamine H1 receptors. Blockade of H1 receptors leads to:
    • Sedation (excessive sleepiness)
    • Increased appetite
    • Weight gain
  • These antihistaminergic effects are particularly prominent at lower doses and are commonly used to advantage in depressed patients with insomnia or low appetite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine D2 receptors: Mirtazapine does not block D2 receptors — this is the primary mechanism of antipsychotics, not mirtazapine.

 

Option C. NMDA glutamate receptors: Blockade is associated with ketamine and similar agents, not mirtazapine.

 

Option D. GABA-A receptors: These are the target of benzodiazepines and barbiturates, not involved in mirtazapine’s action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mirtazapine is a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) with a unique receptor profile. Its antidepressant and side effect profile is due to actions at multiple receptor sites:
    • α2-adrenergic antagonism → Increases norepinephrine and serotonin release, enhancing antidepressant effect.
    • 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 antagonism → Reduces anxiety, GI symptoms, and sexual side effects.
    • H1 histamine receptor antagonism → Causes sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male is brought in due to increasing fatigue and bruising over the past few weeks. On evaluation, he appears pale and has multiple petechiae over his lower extremities. He also has palpable cervical and axillary lymph nodes. Lab results reveal hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, platelet count of 40,000/µL, and white blood cell count of 120,000/µL. A peripheral smear reveals numerous blasts, and flow cytometry identifies the blasts as TdT-positive, CD10-positive, and CD19-positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia B subtype

 

  • This child presents with classic signs of bone marrow failure (fatigue from anemia, petechiae from thrombocytopenia, infections from neutropenia), and a significantly elevated white blood cell count composed primarily of blasts.
  • The diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is confirmed by the presence of TdT, a marker of lymphoid precursors.
  • Further immunophenotyping with flow cytometry reveals CD10 and CD19 positivity, which are markers specific to the B-cell lineage. 
  • Therefore, this is consistent with B-cell subtype of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).
  • B-ALL is the most common childhood malignancy and is typically seen between ages 2–10 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): CML is exceedingly rare in children and typically presents with mature granulocytes and a left-shifted myeloid series rather than blasts. It is also associated with the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)), not CD10 or TdT positivity. CML would not present with lymphoblast markers such as CD19.

 

Option C. Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML): AML may occur in children but is less common than ALL. AML blasts are negative for TdT (which is specific to lymphoid lineage) and instead may express myeloperoxidase (MPO). CD10 and CD19 are not found in AML blasts.

 

Option D. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia T subtype: T-ALL is also TdT-positive but typically expresses CD2, CD3, CD5, and CD7 markers rather than CD10 and CD19. T-ALL often presents with a mediastinal (thymic) mass, which is absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia B subtype is identified by TdT, CD10, and CD19 positivity and is the most common malignancy in children presenting with anemia, thrombocytopenia, lymphadenopathy, and blasts in peripheral blood.

questions.text:
Match the following brain areas and their functions:

 

Column A (Brain Area)

 

  1. Wernicke’s Area
  2. Broca’s Area
  3. Angular Gyrus
  4. Postcentral Gyrus

 

Column B (Function)

 

  1. Speech production
  2. Language comprehension 
  3. Processing of written language 
  4. Primary somatosensory processing
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A–2, B–1, C–3, D–4

 

A–2. Wernicke’s Area: Located in the superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann area 22), it is responsible for comprehension of speech and language, both spoken and written.

 

B–1. Broca’s Area: Located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), responsible for speech production, particularly motor planning of language.

 

C–3. Angular Gyrus: Found in the parietal lobe, involved in reading and writing, integrating visual, auditory, and language inputs.

 

D–4. Postcentral Gyrus: Corresponds to the primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann areas 3, 1, 2), responsible for processing tactile sensory information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different regions of the brain are specialized for specific aspects of language and sensory function. Wernicke’s area is key for language comprehension, while Broca’s area enables speech production. 
  • The angular gyrus plays a role in reading and writing, and the postcentral gyrus is responsible for primary somatic sensation.

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A.

 

  1. Asch's forceps
  2. Walsham's forceps
  3. Tilly's forceps
  4. Citelli's forceps

 

Column B.

 

  1. Used for punching bones and other tissues
  2. Used for insertion or removal of nasal packing or dressings
  3. Mainly used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum
  4. Mainly used to reduce nasal bone fractures
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. Asch's forceps - C. Mainly used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum:

 

  • Asch's forceps are specifically designed to handle and manipulate fractures of the nasal septum. 
  • They are commonly used in septoplasty procedures to realign or reshape the septum when it is fractured or deviated. 
  • Their structure allows for precise control and manipulation within the confined nasal cavity, making them ideal for treating septal fractures.

 

 

2. Walsham's forceps - D. Mainly used to reduce nasal bone fractures:

 

  • Walsham's forceps are robust and designed to handle fractures of the nasal bones rather than the septum. 
  • They are particularly useful in cases of nasal trauma where the bones need to be reset to restore nasal structure and function. 
  • These forceps provide the necessary leverage and grip to manipulate and reduce bone fractures effectively.

 

 

3. Tilly's forceps - B. Used for insertion or removal of nasal packing or dressings:

 

  • Tilly's forceps are commonly used in ENT practices for inserting and removing nasal packing or dressings in the nasal cavity. 
  • Their design allows for safe and controlled placement and retrieval of packing materials, which are often used post-surgery or to control nasal bleeding. 
  • Tilly's forceps are essential in managing nasal dressings without causing additional trauma to the delicate nasal structures.

 

 

4. Citelli's forceps - A. Used for punching bones and other tissues

 

  • Citelli's forceps are more aggressive instruments designed to punch through bone and other dense tissues. 
  • These forceps are utilized when bony structures need to be removed or shaped, such as during certain sinus or nasal surgeries. 
  • Their sturdy build and cutting edge make them suitable for punching through tough tissue structures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asch’s – For septal fractures
  • Walsham’s – For nasal bone fractures
  • Tilly’s – For nasal packing
  • Citelli’s – For bone punching during nasal/sinus procedures.

questions.text: An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis has been reported in a community following a public event. Multiple individuals presented with fever, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Stool specimens have been collected and sent to the microbiology laboratory to isolate the likely causative organism, Salmonella spp. Which of the following enrichment media is most appropriate to facilitate the isolation of Salmonella from stool samples in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Selenite F broth

 

  • Selenite F broth is the enrichment medium of choice for isolating Salmonella species from fecal specimens, especially during gastroenteritis outbreaks. It works by:
    • Suppressing the growth of normal intestinal flora (like E. coli)
    • Enhancing the growth of Salmonella, which may be present in small numbers
  • It is ideal for use in early phases of infection when prompt and accurate identification is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VR medium (Violet Red Bile Agar): Used for the enumeration of coliforms, not for enrichment of Salmonella. It is used for Vibrio. It is a selective differential medium, not suitable in this context.

 

Option B. Thioglycollate medium: A reducing medium used for culturing anaerobic bacteria, not for enteric pathogens like Salmonella.

 

Option C. Cary-Blair medium: A transport medium, not an enrichment medium. It is used to preserve enteric pathogens during transportation but does not promote selective growth. It is used for Vibrio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is the enrichment medium of choice for isolating Salmonella from stool samples, especially in suspected outbreaks of foodborne gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man experiences an anaphylactic reaction and receives a subcutaneous injection of epinephrine, which is the standard first-line treatment due to its vasoconstrictive (α1) and bronchodilatory (β2) effects. However, instead of vasoconstriction, the patient develops further vasodilation after the injection. Which of the following medications is the patient most likely already taking, thereby interfering with the expected response to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ergotamine for migraine

 

  • Ergotamine is an alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonist, not an agonist as sometimes misunderstood. It blocks alpha-1 receptors, which are the primary receptors through which epinephrine exerts its vasoconstrictive effects. 
  • In a patient taking ergotamine, the vasoconstrictive action of epinephrine is blunted or even reversed, leading to unopposed beta-2 stimulation. 
  • This results in vasodilation, particularly in skeletal muscle vessels, which explains the paradoxical worsening of vasodilation in this patient after epinephrine administration. Even ergotamine was the one of the first drugs, and a significant one, that demonstrated the phenomenon known as “Vasomotor reversal of Dale” 
  • Therefore, ergotamine use best explains the clinical finding described in the scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol for migraine: Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, would block beta-1 and beta-2 receptors. In anaphylaxis, this might worsen the situation by reducing bronchodilation and cardiac output. However, it would lead to unopposed alpha-1 stimulation, which typically causes vasoconstriction, not vasodilation. Thus, propranolol would not explain the vasodilation observed here.

 

Option C. Salbutamol for asthma: Salbutamol is a beta-2 agonist that causes bronchodilation and vasodilation. However, it would not interfere with epinephrine's alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction and would not prevent epinephrine from reversing vasodilation.

 

Option D. Atropine for bradycardia: Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that affects the parasympathetic nervous system, increasing heart rate and reducing secretions. It has no effect on alpha- or beta-adrenergic receptors and therefore does not interfere with epinephrine's vasoconstrictive actions. Thus, ergotamine is the only drug among the options that would specifically block epinephrine’s vasoconstrictive action and lead to further vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epinephrine produces vasodilation when administered in the presence of an alpha-adrenergic blocker like ergotamine due to unopposed beta-2 receptor-mediated effects, a phenomenon known as vasomotor reversal of Dale.

choices.text: It is experiencing rapid growth and will double in 35–47 years
It is growing moderately with a doubling time of less than 70 years
It has slow growth and will double in more than 139 years

questions.text: A newly industrializing country conducts a demographic review and finds that its Annual Growth Rate (AGR) is 0.6%. Based on standard classifications of population growth patterns, which of the following statements best reflects this country's current demographic status?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is growing moderately with a doubling time of less than 70 years

 

  • An AGR of 0.6% places the country in the “moderate growth” category, which corresponds to an approximate doubling time between 139 and 70 years (as per standard demographic classification). Since the AGR is greater than 0.5% but less than 1.0%, the doubling time is less than 139 years but more than 70 years — making Option B the most accurate.
  • Population doubling time is calculated using the Rule of 70, a demographic shortcut:

 

 

  • This confirms moderate growth and eliminates slow growth (>139 years).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is experiencing rapid growth and will double in 35–47 years: Incorrect. Rapid growth corresponds to an AGR of 1.0–1.5%, not 0.6%. A doubling time of 35–47 years would suggest very rapid to explosive growth.

 

Option C. Its population is stationary: Incorrect. A stationary population has no net growth (AGR ≈ 0%). Since AGR is 0.6%, this population is clearly growing, though moderately.

 

Option D. It has slow growth and will double in more than 139 years: Incorrect. Slow growth corresponds to AGR < 0.5%. At 0.6%, the doubling time is under 139 years, not over.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An AGR of 0.6% reflects moderate growth, with the population expected to double in less than 139 but more than 70 years — a key demographic indicator for planning health, education, and infrastructure needs.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals consolidation, and sputum microscopy demonstrates large, round, thick-walled yeast cells with broad-based budding and a double-contoured cell wall. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blastomyces dermatitidis

 

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus found in moist soil, especially in regions of the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys and Great Lakes.
  • It exists as a mold in the environment and transforms into a broad-based budding yeast at body temperature (37°C).
  • The yeast form is thick-walled, double-contoured, and spherical, which is a key diagnostic clue.
  • It often causes pulmonary blastomycosis, presenting with fever, productive cough, and lung infiltrates, and can disseminate to skin, bone, and GU tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma capsulatum: Also, a dimorphic fungus, but appears in tissues as small, oval yeast cells within macrophages. Does not show broad-based budding.

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis: Found in the southwestern U.S., causes valley fever. In tissues, it forms spherules with endospores, not yeast with broad-based buds.

 

Option D. Talaromyces (Penicillium) marneffei: Seen in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., HIV patients in Southeast Asia). Appears as oval yeast cells with central transverse septum, not broad-based budding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomyces dermatitidis is identified in tissue by its broad-based budding yeast with a thick, double-contoured wall and is a known cause of fungal pneumonia in endemic areas.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is being evaluated for pharmacological rhythm control. The cardiologist wishes to prescribe an agent that prolongs the cardiac action potential duration by selectively blocking delayed rectifier potassium channels, without exhibiting additional sodium, beta-blocking, or calcium channel-blocking activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dofetilide

 

  • Dofetilide is a class III antiarrhythmic that works by purely blocking the delayed rectifier potassium current (IKr). 
  • This selectively prolongs the repolarization phase (phase 3) of the cardiac action potential, thereby increasing action potential duration and the QT interval.
  • Importantly, dofetilide does not affect sodium channels, beta-adrenergic receptors, or calcium channels, making it a pure action potential–prolonging drug.
  • It is particularly used for maintenance or conversion to sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation or flutter, especially in patients with structural heart disease, as it has minimal negative inotropic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin:

 

  • A class IB antiarrhythmic that shortens the action potential duration by blocking sodium channels, particularly in ischemic tissues. 
  • It does not prolong the action potential.

 

Option C. Amiodarone:

 

  • Although classified as a class III agent, amiodarone has properties of all four Vaughan-Williams classes:
    • Class I: Sodium channel blockade
    • Class II: Beta-blocking
    • Class III: Potassium channel blockade
    • Class IV: Calcium channel blockade
  • Therefore, it affects multiple phases of the action potential—not a pure action potential–prolonging agent.

 

Option D. Procainamide:

 

  • A class IA antiarrhythmic that prolongs the action potential but also has significant sodium channel-blocking activity. 
  • It also has some anticholinergic properties, making it not selective for action potential prolongation alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dofetilide is a class III antiarrhythmic that selectively prolongs the cardiac action potential without affecting sodium, beta, or calcium channels, making it the purest action potential–prolonging agent.

questions.text: What obstetric complication is this test most specifically being developed to detect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pre-eclampsia

 

  • The image displays the Congo Red Dot (CRD) test, which is a novel point-of-care diagnostic tool being developed to detect pre-eclampsia. 
  • This condition is characterized by abnormal placental development, leading to oxidative stress and release of misfolded proteins into the maternal circulation and urine. 
  • These misfolded proteins have a high affinity for Congo red dye, which allows their detection using this simple test. 
  • A strongly or weakly positive result indicates the presence of these misfolded proteins, supporting a diagnosis of pre-eclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gestational diabetes: This is diagnosed via glucose tolerance testing and does not involve misfolded proteins in the urine. The CRD test has no role in its evaluation.

 

Option C. Abruption (Placental abruption): Abruption refers to premature separation of the placenta and presents with painful bleeding and fetal distress. Diagnosis is clinical and ultrasonographic; it is not associated with Congo red–binding proteins in urine.

 

Option D. APLA (Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome): APLA is an autoimmune condition associated with recurrent miscarriages, thrombosis, and pregnancy complications. It is diagnosed by serological tests (anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, β2 glycoprotein I), not by urinary markers or Congo red dye tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Congo Red Dot (CRD) test is a novel; rapid diagnostic test being evaluated for early identification of pre-eclampsia. 
  • It detects misfolded proteins in maternal urine that are pathognomonic for placental dysfunction. 
  • This low-cost, bedside tool may improve diagnosis and management of pre-eclampsia, especially in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: What is the finding in the cardiotocography (CTG) graph shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deceleration

 

  • The graph shows a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline, characteristic of deceleration. The type of deceleration can be determined by its relationship to uterine contractions:
    • Early deceleration: Mirrors uterine contractions and is caused by fetal head compression. It is usually physiological.
    • Late deceleration: Occurs after the peak of uterine contractions and indicates uteroplacental insufficiency. It is pathological and may require immediate intervention.
    • Variable deceleration: Unrelated to contractions and caused by umbilical cord compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acceleration: Represents an increase in fetal heart rate above baseline, which indicates fetal well-being.

 

Option C. Normal tracing: A normal CTG includes baseline variability of 10–25 bpm with no decelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decelerations on CTG are classified as early, late, or variable, and their interpretation helps determine fetal well-being. 
  • Late and variable decelerations may require prompt intervention to prevent fetal compromise.

choices.text: Increasing the refractory period in ventricular myocytes
Increasing sympathetic tone in systemic arteries
Decreasing the firing rate of carotid baroreceptors

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to emergency with severe sudden-onset heart palpitations. The patient reports symptoms of chest pain, fatigue, and dizziness. Upon examination, his heart rate is 165/min and regular. His blood pressure is 106/74 mmHg. A gentle massage below the level of the left mandible elicits an immediate improvement in the patient, as his heart rate returns to 60/min. What was the mechanism of action of this manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Slowing conduction in AV node

 

  • Suggesting a supraventricular tachyarrhythmia, such as AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), which is commonly seen in young individuals with no structural heart disease.
  • His blood pressure was 106/74 mmHg, which is on the lower side, and further supports the likelihood of a hemodynamically significant arrhythmia.
  • The key diagnostic maneuver in the case is the gentle massage below the level of the left mandible, which elicited immediate improvement — specifically, the heart rate returned to 60/min. This clearly refers to carotid sinus massage, a physical technique used to stimulate the baroreceptors in the carotid sinus.
  • Stimulation of these baroreceptors activates the parasympathetic (vagal) tone, which predominantly affects the atrioventricular (AV) node by:
    • Decreasing AV node conduction velocity
    • Increasing AV node refractory period
  • This action interrupts the reentrant circuit in AVNRT or slows down conduction in other types of supraventricular tachycardia. Thus, the mechanism of action of this manoeuvre is slowing conduction in AV node

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing the refractory period in ventricular myocytes: Incorrect. Because the ventricular myocytes are not the primary site of action in this scenario. The carotid sinus massage affects parasympathetic activity, which predominantly influences the SA and AV nodes, not the ventricular muscle fibers.

 

Option B. Increasing sympathetic tone in systemic arteries: Incorrect. Because the carotid massage stimulates parasympathetic tone, not sympathetic. An increase in sympathetic tone would increase heart rate and vascular resistance, which is the opposite of the therapeutic effect seen here.

 

Option C. Decreasing the firing rate of carotid baroreceptors: Incorrect. This option is not physiologically consistent with the maneuver. Carotid sinus massage increases the firing rate of baroreceptors by simulating increased blood pressure, leading to reflex vagal activation and decreased heart rate. Therefore, the firing rate is increased, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carotid sinus massage increases parasympathetic tone, leading to slowed AV node conduction and termination of supraventricular tachycardias such as AVNRT.

choices.text: The patient experiences limited abduction and adduction
There is a widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction
Head tilt is more common than other types
Sixth nerve palsy is associated with this condition

questions.text: Which of the following is a true characteristic of Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is a widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction

 

  • Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1 (DRS Type 1) is characterized by limited abduction of the affected eye and the widening of the palpebral fissure when the patient attempts to abduct the eye. 

 

 

 

  • This occurs because of an abnormal development of the sixth cranial nerve, which affects the lateral rectus muscle, causing a restricted outward movement of the eye. 
  • The widening of the palpebral fissure is a distinctive feature of DRS Type 1 and occurs during abduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient experiences limited abduction and adduction: This is incorrect for Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1. In Type 1, adduction (the inward movement of the eye) is often normal or even exaggerated, while abduction is restricted. Limited abduction and adduction is seen more commonly in Types 2 and 3.

 

Option C. Head tilt is more common than other types: Head tilt is not a predominant feature of DRS Type 1. It is more common in Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 2 and Type 3, where both abduction and adduction are affected, often requiring the patient to compensate by tilting their head. In Type 1, the main issue is restricted abduction and widened palpebral fissure, so head tilt is less frequent.

 

Option D. Sixth nerve palsy is associated with this condition: Sixth nerve palsy is not associated with Duane Retraction Syndrome. In DRS, the problem is due to abnormal innervation of the lateral rectus muscle, which prevents normal abduction of the eye. While the sixth nerve is involved, it is not a true palsy, as the nerve is structurally present but does not develop appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duane Retraction Syndrome Type 1 is characterized by limited abduction of the affected eye and widening of the palpebral fissure on abduction, caused by abnormal development of the sixth cranial nerve affecting the lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: Match the scenario with the preferred surgical intervention
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

1-D. 27y P3L3 lady with uterocervical prolapse - Manchester repair: The 1st scenario is of a woman with family probably complete (She has 3 children) but is quite young (27y). Prolapse in such a patient can be treated by Manchester repair (which involves cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments over the cervical stump)

 

2-B. 34y nulliparous lady with uterocervical prolapse - Hystero-sacrocpexy: The 2nd scenario is one of nulliparous prolapse. This can be treated with sling surgeries and nowadays, hystero-sacropexy/ cervico-sacropexy (laparoscopic or laparotomy) is done. Another procedure called cervico-pectopexy is done (the cervix is attached to the iliopectineal ligaments)

 

3-C. 52y P2L2 with uterocervical prolapse with cystocele and rectocele - Ward-Mayo’s repair: The 3rd scenario is a peri-menopausal woman with prolapse. Here Ward Mayo is preferred. This includes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpo-perineorrhaphy

 

4-A. 45y P2L1 with cystocele - Anterior colporrhaphy: The 4th scenario is a with cystocele. Here Anterior colporrhaphy is preferred. If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Surgeries for uterine prolapse include: 
    1. If family complete and elderly/ postmenopausal: Vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy (cystocele repair) and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (rectocele repair)
    2. If family complete and young: Manchester repair/ Fothergill repair or Shirodkar modification of Manchester 
    3. If young and nulliparous: Sling surgeries or hysteropexy surgery
    4. If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis

questions.text: A 22-year-old traveller returns from East Africa and is evaluated for fever, chills, and malaise. Blood smear reveals ring-stage parasites inside red blood cells. Further testing is ordered to confirm the species. The patient is found to be negative for Duffy blood group antigen. This genetic trait provides resistance against which of the following Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium vivax

 

  • The Duffy antigen (also known as Duffy blood group antigen or DARC: Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines) is a receptor on red blood cells that is essential for Plasmodium vivax to invade RBCs.
  • Individuals who are Duffy-negative (FyFy genotype)—common in many people of West and Central African descent—are resistant to P. vivax infection because the parasite cannot bind to and enter red cells.
  • P. vivax specifically requires the Duffy antigen to initiate erythrocyte invasion and complete its lifecycle in humans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium falciparum: Uses different erythrocyte receptors (e.g., PfEMP1, glycophorins) for RBC invasion and is not dependent on the Duffy antigen.

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Invades red cells independently of the Duffy antigen; infection is not restricted by Duffy status.

 

Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Like P. malariae, it does not require the Duffy antigen for erythrocyte invasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium vivax requires the Duffy antigen to invade red blood cells; individuals lacking this antigen are naturally resistant to P. vivax infection.

choices.text: Wet clothing should be dried with heat before packaging to prevent bacterial degradation
Wet clothing should be placed in airtight plastic bags to preserve moisture-sensitive evidence
Wet clothing may still yield biological evidence but must be air-dried before packaging in paper bags
Biological evidence cannot be recovered from wet clothing due to dilution and contamination

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman reports a sexual assault that occurred outdoors during heavy rain. She arrives at the emergency department 12 hours later, still wearing the same wet clothes. Which of the following is the most accurate about evidence collection from her clothing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wet clothing may still yield biological evidence but must be air-dried before packaging in paper bags.

 

  • Wet clothing can retain semen, blood, or epithelial cells. However, to prevent mold and bacterial degradation, the clothing should be air-dried at room temperature before being stored in breathable paper bags — not plastic because plastic bag traps moisture which leads to decomposition. 
  • This preserves the evidence better for lab analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wet clothing should be dried with heat before packaging to prevent bacterial degradation:

 

  • Drying with heat (e.g., dryers, hair dryers, or direct sunlight) can destroy or denature DNA and degrade biological stains.
  • Heat may also cause cross-contamination or alter trace patterns.

 

Option B. Wet clothing should be placed in airtight plastic bags to preserve moisture-sensitive evidence:

 

  • Plastic bags trap moisture, which creates a perfect environment for bacterial growth, accelerating DNA degradation.
  • Also, they can smear or spread stains, ruining evidence integrity.

 

Option D. Biological evidence cannot be recovered from wet clothing due to dilution and contamination:

 

  • While rain or water may dilute stains, DNA can still bind to fibers, especially if fluids soaked into inner layers of clothing.
  • Partial profiles may still be obtained, especially if the fabric wasn’t washed or agitated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In forensic evidence collection, wet clothing with potential biological stains (e.g., semen, blood, epithelial cells) should be air-dried at room temperature and stored in paper bags, not plastic, to avoid bacterial growth and preserve DNA integrity. 
  • Proper handling ensures evidence remains admissible and testable.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents with repeated bilateral optic neuritis and weakness of both the legs. MRI is shown below. Which autoantibody is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aquaporin-4

 

  • Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is characterized by longitudinal spinal cord lesions and optic neuritis. 
  • Anti–aquaporin-4 antibodies are diagnostic and pathogenic. 
  • Early diagnosis and immunosuppression are essential. 
  • In patients with features of NMO but negative AchRAb – Do not forget to test for anti-MOG. 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA: Seen in lupus, not NMOSD.
 

Option C. Myeloperoxidase: Found in ANCA-associated vasculitis.
 

Option D. tRNA synthetase: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti–aquaporin-4 antibodies are diagnostic for NMOSD and should be tested in patients with optic-spinal demyelination.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of intermittent numbness, tingling, and weakness in her right hand, particularly after performing overhead activities such as painting or lifting objects. She also reports a sensation of heaviness in the arm, which improves when she rests the arm. On physical examination, there is weakness in the intrinsic hand muscles and diminished sensation in the ulnar aspect of the hand. A radiograph shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 

  • TOS results from compression of the brachial plexus, subclavian artery, or subclavian vein as they pass through the thoracic outlet (between the clavicle and first rib).
  • Common causes include:
    • Cervical rib
    • Scalene muscle hypertrophy
    • Trauma or repetitive overhead motion
  • Neurogenic TOS is most common and presents with:
    • Numbness, tingling, and weakness, especially in the ulnar distribution
    • Symptoms worsened by overhead activity or prolonged arm elevation
    • Heaviness or fatigue in the arm

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical Radiculopathy:

  • Caused by compression of cervical nerve roots (e.g., herniated disc, spondylosis).
  • Presents with:
    • Neck pain that radiates to the arm
    • Dermatomal sensory loss and weakness
    • Often worsened by neck movement
  • If the patient has no neck pain, and the symptoms are activity-related, not positional with neck.
  • Also, cervical radiculopathy typically would not be improved by resting the arm down.

 

Option C. Pancoast Tumour:

  • A superior sulcus tumor at the lung apex that can invade the brachial plexus, causing:
    • Shoulder and arm pain
    • Weakness
    • Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)
  • Seen most often in smokers, with constitutional symptoms (weight loss, cough).
  • Rare in a healthy 32-year-old woman with no systemic signs.
  • Imaging would show a mass in the lung apex, not just a bony anomaly.

 

 

Option D. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome:

  • Caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist.
  • Presents with:
    • Numbness and tingling in the thumb, index, middle, and radial half of ring finger
    • Worse at night and with wrist flexion
    • Thenar muscle weakness
  • This patient has ulnar distribution symptoms (not median), and worsening with overhead activity, which does not fit carpal tunnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Thoracic Outlet Syndrome has:

  • Symptoms worsened by overhead activity
  • Ulnar nerve distribution of numbness and weakness
  • X-ray likely showing a cervical rib

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits the emergency department with sudden onset dizziness, nausea, and difficulty maintaining balance. She reports that the symptoms began while she was having her hair washed in a salon with her head extended backward over a sink. Physical examination reveals nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria. A neurological assessment suggests possible artery damage. Which of the following arteries is most likely damaged in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vertebral artery

 

  • The vertebral artery is susceptible to damage or dissection in situations involving sudden or prolonged neck extension, such as during a hair wash with the head extended backward over a sink. 
  • The vertebral artery supplies blood to the posterior circulation of the brain, including the cerebellum and brainstem. 
  • Damage to this artery can result in vertebrobasilar insufficiency, leading to symptoms such as dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria.
  • These symptoms occur because of reduced blood flow to the brainstem and cerebellum, which are critical for balance and coordination.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery: Incorrect. The anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes, and damage to this artery typically presents with symptoms like contralateral leg weakness and personality changes, not with dizziness and ataxia.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery: Incorrect. The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral aspects of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes, and damage here is typically associated with contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia, or sensory deficits, rather than balance and coordination issues.

 

Option D. Posterior cerebral artery: Incorrect. While the posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the occipital lobe and thalamus, its damage typically causes visual disturbances or sensory loss rather than the cerebellar symptoms (e.g., ataxia and nystagmus) seen with vertebral artery damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vertebral artery damage can occur due to sudden neck hyperextension, leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency and symptoms such as dizziness, nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria.
  • Recognizing the relationship between neck positioning and vertebral artery vulnerability is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effect of various mitochondrial toxins on cellular respiration and energy metabolism. One particular compound is found to disrupt the transfer of ADP into the mitochondria and ATP out of it, thereby inhibiting ATP synthesis indirectly. Which of the following compounds is most likely responsible for this effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atractyloside

 

  • Atractyloside is a toxic glycoside that specifically inhibits the adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT), a transporter embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. This transporter plays a vital role in cellular energy homeostasis by:
    • Importing ADP from the cytosol into the mitochondrial matrix
    • Exporting ATP generated by oxidative phosphorylation back into the cytosol
  • By inhibiting this exchange, atractyloside prevents the proper utilization of ATP and blocks mitochondrial energy output, leading to energy crisis in tissues dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotenone: Inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain, blocking electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone. It disrupts proton pumping and reduces ATP synthesis, but it does not interfere with ADP/ATP exchange.

 

Option B. Oligomycin: Inhibits ATP synthase ( F0 component of Complex V) by blocking the proton channel, directly preventing ATP formation, but does not block ADP or ATP transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

 

Option D. Antimycin: Inhibits Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) of the electron transport chain, blocking electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c. This reduces ATP production but does not affect ADP/ATP translocase activity.

 

Educational Objective:
